Text

ï»¿THE SECRET GARDEN

CHAPTER I

THERE IS NO ONE LEFT

When [Mary Lennox]38-mary was sent to [Misselthwaite Manor]1-misselthwaite manor to live with [[her]38-mary uncle]120-her uncle everybody said [she]38-mary was [the most disagreeable - looking child ever seen]121-the most disagreeable - looking child ever seen . It was true , too . [She]38-mary had a little thin face and a little thin body , thin light hair and a sour expression . [Her]38-mary hair was yellow , and [her]38-mary face was yellow because [she]38-mary had been born in [India]2-india and had always been ill in one way or another . [[Her]38-mary father]122-her father had held a position under [the English Government]123-the english government and had always been busy and ill [himself]122-her father , and [[her]38-mary mother]124-her mother had been [a great beauty who cared only to go to parties and amuse [herself]124-her mother with [gay people]126-gay people]125-a great beauty who cared only to go to parties and amuse herself with gay people . [She]124-her mother had not wanted [a little girl]127-a little girl at all , and when [Mary]38-mary was born [she]124-her mother handed [her]38-mary over to the care of [an Ayah]128-an ayah , who was made to understand that if [she]128-an ayah wished to please [the Mem Sahib]31-mary [she]128-an ayah must keep [the child]129-the child out of sight as much as possible . So when [she]38-mary was [a sickly , fretful , ugly little baby]130-a sickly , fretful , ugly little baby [she]38-mary was kept out of the way , and when [she]38-mary became [a sickly , fretful , toddling thing]131-a sickly , fretful , toddling thing [she]38-mary was kept out of the way also . [She]38-mary never remembered seeing familiarly anything but the dark faces of [[her]38-mary [Ayah]32-ayah]132-her ayah and [the other native servants]133-the other native servants , and as [they]133-the other native servants always obeyed [her]38-mary and gave [her]38-mary [her]38-mary own way in everything , because [the Mem Sahib]31-mary would be angry if [she]38-mary was disturbed by [her]38-mary crying , by the time [she]38-mary was six years old [she]38-mary was as tyrannical and selfish [a little pig as ever lived]134-a little pig as ever lived . [The young English governess who came to teach [her]38-mary to read and write]135-the young english governess who came to teach her to read and write disliked [her]38-mary so much that [she]38-mary gave up [her]38-mary place in three months , and when [other governesses]136-other governesses came to try to fill it [they]136-other governesses always went away in a shorter time than the first one . So if [Mary]31-mary had not chosen to really want to know how to read books [she]31-mary would never have learned [her]31-mary letters at all .

One frightfully hot morning , when [she]31-mary was about nine years old , [she]31-mary awakened feeling very cross , and [she]31-mary became crosser still when [she]31-mary saw that [the servant who stood by [her]31-mary bedside]137-the servant who stood by her bedside was not [[her]31-mary Ayah]132-her ayah .

" Why did [you]139-the strange woman come ? "[31-mary] [she]31-mary said to [the strange woman]139-the strange woman . " [I]31-mary will not let [you]139-the strange woman stay . Send [[my]31-mary Ayah]1757-my ayah to [me]31-mary . "[31-mary]

[The woman]140-the woman looked frightened , but [she]140-the woman only stammered that [the Ayah]141-the ayah could not come and when [Mary]31-mary threw [herself]31-mary into a passion and beat and kicked [her]140-the woman , [she]140-the woman looked only more frightened and repeated that it was not possible for [the Ayah]141-the ayah to come to [Missie Sahib]33-missie sahib .

There was something mysterious in the air that morning . Nothing was done in its regular order and [several of [the native servants]144-the native servants]143-several of the native servants seemed missing , while those whom [Mary]31-mary saw slunk or hurried about with ashy and scared faces . But [no one]145-no one would tell [her]31-mary anything and [her]31-mary Ayah did not come . [She]31-mary was actually left alone as the morning went on , and at last [she]31-mary wandered out into [the garden]146-the garden and began to play by [herself]31-mary under a tree near [the veranda]147-the veranda . [She]31-mary pretended that [she]31-mary was making a flower - bed , and [she]31-mary stuck big scarlet hibiscus blossoms into little heaps of earth , all the time growing more and more angry and muttering to [herself]31-mary the things [she]31-mary would say and the names [she]31-mary would call [Saidie]34-saidie when [she]31-mary returned .

" [Pig]35-pig ! [Pig]1758-pig ! [Daughter of Pigs]1759-daughter of pigs ! "[31-mary] [she]31-mary said , because to call [a native a pig]148-a native a pig is the worst insult of all .

[She]31-mary was grinding [her]31-mary teeth and saying this over and over again when [she]31-mary heard [[her]31-mary mother]124-her mother come out on [the veranda]147-the veranda with [some one]151-some one . [She]31-mary was with [a fair young man]152-a fair young man and [they]153-they stood talking together in low strange voices . [Mary]31-mary knew [the fair young man]154-the fair young man who looked like [a boy]155-a boy . [She]31-mary had heard that [he]154-the fair young man was [a very young officer who had just come from [England]3-england]156-a very young officer who had just come from england . [The child]129-the child stared at [him]154-the fair young man , but [she]129-the child stared most at [[her]31-mary mother]124-her mother . [She]31-mary always did this when [she]31-mary had a chance to see [her]124-her mother , because [the Mem Sahib Mary]31-mary used to call [her]124-her mother that oftener than anything else was such [a tall , slim , pretty person]159-a tall , slim , pretty person and wore such lovely clothes . [Her]124-her mother hair was like curly silk and [she]124-her mother had a delicate little nose which seemed to be disdaining things , and [she]124-her mother had large laughing eyes . All [her]124-her mother clothes were thin and floating , and [Mary]31-mary said they were " full of lace . "[31-mary] They looked fuller of lace than ever this morning , but [her]124-her mother eyes were not laughing at all . They were large and scared and lifted imploringly to [the fair boy officer]160-the fair boy officer 's face .

" Is it so very bad ? Oh , is it ? "[124-her mother] [Mary]31-mary heard [her]124-her mother say .

" Awfully , "[161-the young man] [the young man]161-the young man answered in a trembling voice . " Awfully , [Mrs. Lennox]36-mrs. lennox . [You]31-mary ought to have gone to [the hills]1760-the hills two weeks ago . "[161-the young man]

[The Mem Sahib]31-mary wrung [her]31-mary hands .

" Oh , [I]31-mary know [I]31-mary ought ! "[31-mary] [she]31-mary cried . " [I]31-mary only stayed to go to that silly dinner party . What [a fool]1761-a fool [I]31-mary was ! "[31-mary]

At that very moment such a loud sound of wailing broke out from [[the servants]162-the servants ' quarters]163-the servants ' quarters that [she]124-her mother clutched [the young man]161-the young man 's arm , and [Mary]31-mary stood shivering from head to foot . The wailing grew wilder and wilder . " What is it ? What is it ? "[36-mrs. lennox] [Mrs. Lennox]36-mrs. lennox gasped .

" [Some one]151-some one has died , "[165-the boy officer] answered [the boy officer]165-the boy officer . " [You]165-the boy officer did not say it had broken out among [[your]165-the boy officer servants]1763-your servants . "[36-mrs. lennox]

" [I]31-mary did not know ! "[31-mary] [the Mem Sahib]31-mary cried . " Come with [me]31-mary ! Come with [me]31-mary ! "[31-mary] and [she]31-mary turned and ran into [the house]166-the house .

After that , appalling things happened , and the mysteriousness of the morning was explained to [Mary]31-mary . The cholera had broken out in its most fatal form and [people]167-people were dying like flies . [The Ayah]32-ayah had been taken ill in the night , and it was because [she]32-ayah had just died that [the servants]162-the servants had wailed in [the huts]169-the huts . Before the next day [three other servants]170-three other servants were dead and [others]171-others had run away in terror . There was panic on every side , and dying people in all [the bungalows]172-the bungalows .

During the confusion and bewilderment of the second day [Mary]31-mary hid [herself]31-mary in [the nursery]173-the nursery and was forgotten by [everyone]174-everyone . [Nobody]175-nobody thought of [her]31-mary , [nobody]175-nobody wanted [her]31-mary , and strange things happened of which [she]31-mary knew nothing . [Mary]31-mary alternately cried and slept through the hours . [She]31-mary only knew that [people]167-people were ill and that [she]31-mary heard mysterious and frightening sounds . Once [she]31-mary crept into [the dining - room]178-the dining - room and found [it]178-the dining - room empty , though a partly finished meal was on the table and chairs and plates looked as if they had been hastily pushed back when [the diners]179-the diners rose suddenly for some reason . [The child]129-the child ate some fruit and biscuits , and being thirsty [she]31-mary drank a glass of wine which stood nearly filled . It was sweet , and [she]31-mary did not know how strong it was . Very soon it made [her]31-mary intensely drowsy , and [she]31-mary went back to [[her]31-mary nursery]181-her nursery and shut [herself]31-mary in again , frightened by cries [she]31-mary heard in [the huts]169-the huts and by the hurrying sound of feet . The wine made [her]31-mary so sleepy that [she]31-mary could scarcely keep [her]31-mary eyes open and [she]31-mary lay down on [her]31-mary bed and knew nothing more for a long time .

Many things happened during the hours in which [she]31-mary slept so heavily , but [she]31-mary was not disturbed by the wails and the sound of things being carried in and out of [the bungalow]183-the bungalow .

When [she]31-mary awakened [she]31-mary lay and stared at the wall . [The house]166-the house was perfectly still . [She]31-mary had never known [it]166-the house to be so silent before . [She]31-mary heard neither voices nor footsteps , and wondered if [everybody]185-everybody had got well of the cholera and all the trouble was over . [She]31-mary wondered also who would take care of [her]31-mary now [her]31-mary [Ayah]32-ayah was dead . There would be [a new Ayah]186-a new ayah , and perhaps [she]31-mary would know some new stories . [Mary]31-mary had been rather tired of the old ones . [She]31-mary did not cry because [[her]31-mary nurse]187-her nurse had died . [She]31-mary was not [an affectionate child]188-an affectionate child and had never cared much for [any one]189-any one . The noise and hurrying about and wailing over the cholera had frightened [her]31-mary , and [she]31-mary had been angry because [no one]145-no one seemed to remember that [she]31-mary was alive . [Everyone]174-everyone was too panic - stricken to think of [a little girl [no one]145-no one was fond of]192-a little girl no one was fond of . When [people]167-people had the cholera it seemed that [they]167-people remembered nothing but [themselves]167-people . But if [everyone]174-everyone had got well again , surely [some one]151-some one would remember and come to look for [her]31-mary .

But [no one]145-no one came , and as [she]31-mary lay waiting [the house]166-the house seemed to grow more and more silent . [She]31-mary heard something rustling on the matting and when [she]31-mary looked down [she]31-mary saw a little snake gliding along and watching [her]31-mary with eyes like jewels . [She]31-mary was not frightened , because [he]199-he was [a harmless little thing who would not hurt [her]31-mary and [he]199-he seemed in a hurry to get out of [the room]201-the room]200-a harmless little thing who would not hurt her and he seemed in a hurry to get out of the room . [He]199-he slipped under the door as [she]31-mary watched [him]199-he .

" How queer and quiet it is , "[31-mary] [she]31-mary said . " It sounds as if there were [no one]145-no one in [the bungalow]183-the bungalow but [me]31-mary and the snake . "[31-mary]

Almost the next minute [she]31-mary heard footsteps in [the compound]202-the compound , and then on [the veranda]147-the veranda . [They]204-they were [men]205-men 's footsteps , and [the men]206-the men entered [the bungalow]183-the bungalow and talked in low voices . [No one]145-no one went to meet or speak to [them]206-the men and [they]206-the men seemed to open doors and look into [rooms]209-rooms . " What desolation ! "[210-one voice] [she]31-mary heard [one voice]210-one voice say . " [That pretty , pretty woman]1766-that pretty , pretty woman ! [I]210-one voice suppose [the child]129-the child , too . [I]210-one voice heard there was [a child]1768-a child , though [no one]145-no one ever saw [her]1768-a child . "[210-one voice]

[Mary]31-mary was standing in the middle of [the nursery]173-the nursery when [they]206-the men opened the door a few minutes later . [She]31-mary looked [an ugly , cross little thing]212-an ugly , cross little thing and was frowning because [she]31-mary was beginning to be hungry and feel disgracefully neglected . [The first man who came in]213-the first man who came in was [a large officer [she]31-mary had once seen talking to [[her]31-mary father]122-her father]214-a large officer she had once seen talking to her father . [He]213-the first man who came in looked tired and troubled , but when [he]213-the first man who came in saw [her]31-mary [he]213-the first man who came in was so startled that [he]213-the first man who came in almost jumped back .

" [Barney]37-barney ! "[213-the first man who came in] [he]213-the first man who came in cried out . " There is [a child]1768-a child [here]1771-here ! [A child]1768-a child alone ! In [a place like this]1773-a place like this ! Mercy on [us]1774-us , who is [she]1768-a child ! "[213-the first man who came in]

" [I]216-the little girl am [Mary Lennox]38-mary , "[216-the little girl] [the little girl]216-the little girl said , drawing [herself]216-the little girl up stiffly . [She]31-mary thought [the man]217-the man was very rude to call [[[her]31-mary father]122-her father 's bungalow]219-her father 's bungalow " [A place like this]1773-a place like this ! "[217-the man] " [I]31-mary fell asleep when [everyone]174-everyone had the cholera and [I]31-mary have only just wakened up . Why does [nobody]175-nobody come ? "[31-mary]

" It is [the child]129-the child [no one]145-no one ever saw ! "[217-the man] exclaimed [the man]217-the man , turning to [[his]217-the man companions]221-his companions . " [She]129-the child has actually been forgotten ! "[217-the man]

" Why was [I]38-mary forgotten ? "[38-mary] [Mary]38-mary said , stamping [her]38-mary foot . " Why does [nobody]175-nobody come ? "[38-mary]

[The young man whose name was [Barney]37-barney]222-the young man whose name was barney looked at [her]38-mary very sadly . [Mary]38-mary even thought [she]38-mary saw [him]222-the young man whose name was barney wink [his]222-the young man whose name was barney eyes as if to wink tears away .

" [Poor little kid]1781-poor little kid ! "[222-the young man whose name was barney] [he]222-the young man whose name was barney said . " There is [nobody left to come]1782-nobody left to come . "[222-the young man whose name was barney]

It was in that strange and sudden way that [Mary]38-mary found out that [she]38-mary had neither [father]223-father nor [mother]224-mother left ; that [they]225-they had died and been carried away in the night , and that [the few native servants who had not died]226-the few native servants who had not died also had left [the house]166-the house as quickly as [they]226-the few native servants who had not died could get out of [it]166-the house , none of [them]226-the few native servants who had not died even remembering that there was a [Missie Sahib]33-missie sahib . That was why [the place]228-the place was so quiet . It was true that there was [no one]145-no one in [the bungalow]183-the bungalow but [herself]38-mary and [the little rustling snake]231-the little rustling snake .

CHAPTER II

[MISTRESS MARY QUITE CONTRARY

Mary]38-mary had liked to look at [[her]38-mary mother]124-her mother from a distance and [she]38-mary had thought [her]124-her mother very pretty , but as [she]38-mary knew very little of [her]124-her mother [she]38-mary could scarcely have been expected to love [her]124-her mother or to miss [her]124-her mother very much when [she]124-her mother was gone . [She]38-mary did not miss [her]124-her mother at all , in fact , and as [she]38-mary was [a self - absorbed child]233-a self - absorbed child [she]38-mary gave [her]38-mary entire thought to [herself]38-mary , as [she]38-mary had always done . If [she]38-mary had been older [she]38-mary would no doubt have been very anxious at being left alone in [the world]234-the world , but [she]38-mary was very young , and as [she]38-mary had always been taken care of , [she]38-mary supposed [she]38-mary always would be . What [she]38-mary thought was that [she]38-mary would like to know if [she]38-mary was going to nice people , who would be polite to [her]38-mary and give [her]38-mary [her]38-mary own way as [[her]38-mary Ayah]132-her ayah and [the other native servants]133-the other native servants had done .

[She]38-mary knew that [she]38-mary was not going to stay at [[the English clergyman]237-the english clergyman 's house]238-the english clergyman 's house where [she]38-mary was taken at first . [She]38-mary did not want to stay . [The English clergyman]237-the english clergyman was poor and [he]237-the english clergyman had [five children]240-five children nearly all the same age and [they]240-five children wore shabby clothes and were always quarreling and snatching toys from [each other]241-each other . [Mary]38-mary hated [[their]240-five children untidy bungalow]242-their untidy bungalow and was so disagreeable to [them]240-five children that after the first day or two [nobody]175-nobody would play with [her]38-mary . By the second day [they]240-five children had given [her]38-mary a nickname which made [her]38-mary furious .

It was [Basil]39-basil who thought of it first . [Basil]39-basil was [a little boy with impudent blue eyes and a turned - up nose]244-a little boy with impudent blue eyes and a turned - up nose , and [Mary]38-mary hated [him]39-basil . [She]38-mary was playing by [herself]38-mary under a tree , just as [she]38-mary had been playing the day the cholera broke out . [She]38-mary was making heaps of earth and paths for [a garden]245-a garden and [Basil]39-basil came and stood near to watch [her]38-mary . Presently [he]39-basil got rather interested and suddenly made a suggestion .

" Why do n't [you]38-mary put a heap of stones there and pretend it is a rockery ? "[39-basil] [he]39-basil said . " There in the middle , "[39-basil] and [he]39-basil leaned over [her]38-mary to point .

" Go away ! "[38-mary] cried [Mary]38-mary . " [I]38-mary do n't want [boys]1783-boys . Go away ! "[38-mary]

For a moment [Basil]39-basil looked angry , and then [he]39-basil began to tease . [He]39-basil was always teasing [[his]39-basil sisters]246-his sisters . [He]39-basil danced round and round [her]38-mary and made faces and sang and laughed .

" [Mistress Mary]38-mary , quite contrary , How does [[your]38-mary garden]1784-your garden grow ? With silver bells , and cockle shells , And marigolds all in a row . "[39-basil] [He]39-basil sang it until [the other children]247-the other children heard and laughed , too ; and the crosser [Mary]38-mary got , the more [they]247-the other children sang " [Mistress Mary]38-mary , quite contrary "[247-the other children] ; and after that as long as [she]38-mary stayed with [them]247-the other children [they]247-the other children called [her]38-mary " [Mistress Mary]38-mary Quite Contrary "[247-the other children] when [they]247-the other children spoke of [her]38-mary to [each other]241-each other , and often when [they]247-the other children spoke to [her]38-mary .

" [You]38-mary are going to be sent [home]1785-home , "[39-basil] [Basil]39-basil said to [her]38-mary , " at the end of the week . And [we]247-the other children 're glad of it . "[39-basil]

" [I]38-mary am glad of it , too , "[38-mary] answered [Mary]38-mary . " Where is [home]1785-home ? "[39-basil]

" [She]38-mary does n't know where [home]1785-home is ! "[39-basil] said [Basil]39-basil , with seven - year - old scorn . " It 's [England]3-england , of course . [[Our]247-the other children grandmama]1788-our grandmama lives there and [[our]247-the other children sister]1789-our sister [Mabel]40-mabel was sent to [her]1788-our grandmama last year . [You]38-mary are not going to [[your]38-mary grandmama]1790-your grandmama . [You]38-mary have none . [You]38-mary are going to [[your]38-mary uncle]1791-your uncle . [His]1791-your uncle name is [Mr. Archibald Craven]41-mr. craven . "[39-basil]

" [I]38-mary do n't know anything about [him]1791-your uncle , "[38-mary] snapped [Mary]38-mary .

" [I]39-basil know [you]38-mary do n't , "[39-basil] [Basil]39-basil answered . " [You]38-mary do n't know anything . [Girls]1792-girls never do . [I]39-basil heard [father]223-father and [mother]224-mother talking about [him]1791-your uncle . [He]1791-your uncle lives in [a great , big , desolate old house in [the country]1796-the country]1795-a great , big , desolate old house in the country and [no one]145-no one goes near [him]1791-your uncle . [He]1791-your uncle 's so cross [he]1791-your uncle wo n't let [them]1792-girls , and [they]1792-girls would n't come if [he]1791-your uncle would let [them]1792-girls . [He]1791-your uncle 's [a hunchback]1798-a hunchback , and [he]1791-your uncle 's horrid . "[39-basil] " [I]38-mary do n't believe [you]1791-your uncle , "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary ; and [she]38-mary turned [her]38-mary back and stuck [her]38-mary fingers in [her]38-mary ears , because [she]38-mary would not listen any more .

But [she]38-mary thought over it a great deal afterward ; and when [Mrs. Crawford]42-mrs. crawford told [her]38-mary that night that [she]38-mary was going to sail away to [England]3-england in a few days and go to [[her]38-mary uncle]120-her uncle , [Mr. Archibald Craven]41-mr. craven , who lived at [Misselthwaite Manor]1-misselthwaite manor , [she]38-mary looked so stony and stubbornly uninterested that [they]250-they did not know what to think about [her]38-mary . [They]250-they tried to be kind to [her]38-mary , but [she]38-mary only turned [her]38-mary face away when [Mrs. Crawford]42-mrs. crawford attempted to kiss [her]38-mary , and held [herself]38-mary stiffly when [Mr. Crawford]43-mr. crawford patted [her]38-mary shoulder .

" [She]38-mary is such [a plain child]1799-a plain child , "[42-mrs. crawford] [Mrs. Crawford]42-mrs. crawford said pityingly , afterward . " And [[her]38-mary mother]124-her mother was such [a pretty creature]1801-a pretty creature . "[42-mrs. crawford]

" Perhaps if [[her]38-mary mother]124-her mother had carried [her]38-mary pretty face and [her]38-mary pretty manners oftener into [the nursery]173-the nursery [Mary]38-mary might have learned some pretty ways too . " [I]42-mrs. crawford believe [she]124-her mother scarcely ever looked at [her]38-mary , "[42-mrs. crawford] sighed [Mrs. Crawford]42-mrs. crawford . "[42-mrs. crawford]

[Mary]38-mary made the long voyage to [England]3-england under the care of [[an officer]251-an officer 's wife]252-an officer 's wife , who was taking [[her]252-an officer 's wife children]253-her children to leave [them]253-her children in [a boarding - school]254-a boarding - school . What sort of a place was it , and what would [he]120-her uncle be like ? What was a hunchback ? [She]38-mary had never seen one . Perhaps there were none in [India]2-india .

Since [she]38-mary had been living in [[other people]273-other people 's houses]274-other people 's houses and had had no Ayah , [she]38-mary had begun to feel lonely and to think queer thoughts which were new to [her]38-mary . [She]38-mary had begun to wonder why [she]38-mary had never seemed to belong to [anyone]275-anyone even when [[her]38-mary father]122-her father and [mother]224-mother had been alive . [Other children]278-other children seemed to belong to [[their]278-other children fathers]279-their fathers and [mothers]280-mothers , but [she]38-mary had never seemed to really be [anyone 's little girl]281-anyone 's little girl . [She]38-mary had had [servants]282-servants , and food and clothes , but [no one]145-no one had taken any notice of [her]38-mary . [She]38-mary did not know that this was because [she]38-mary was [a disagreeable child]284-a disagreeable child ; but then , of course , [she]38-mary did not know [she]38-mary was disagreeable . [She]38-mary often thought that [other people]273-other people were , but [she]38-mary did not know that [she]38-mary was so [herself]38-mary .

[She]38-mary thought [Mrs. Medlock]45-mrs. medlock [the most disagreeable person [she]38-mary had ever seen , with [her]45-mrs. medlock common , highly colored face and [her]45-mrs. medlock common fine bonnet]286-the most disagreeable person she had ever seen , with her common , highly colored face and her common fine bonnet . But [Mrs. Medlock]45-mrs. medlock was not in the least disturbed by [her]45-mrs. medlock and [her]45-mrs. medlock thoughts . " At least , that is what [she]45-mrs. medlock would have said if [she]45-mrs. medlock had been asked . [Mary]38-mary sat in [her]38-mary corner of [the railway carriage]289-the railway carriage and looked plain and fretful . [She]38-mary had nothing to read or to look at , and [she]38-mary had folded [her]38-mary thin little black - gloved hands in [her]38-mary lap . " [I]45-mrs. medlock suppose [you]38-mary might as well be told something to prepare [you]38-mary . [You]38-mary are going to [a queer place]1831-a queer place . "[45-mrs. medlock]

[Mary]38-mary said nothing at all , and [Mrs. Medlock]45-mrs. medlock looked rather discomfited by [her]45-mrs. medlock apparent indifference , but , after taking a breath , [she]45-mrs. medlock went on .

" Not but that [it]1831-a queer place 's [a grand big place]1832-a grand big place in a gloomy way , and [Mr. Craven]41-mr. craven 's proud of [it]1831-a queer place in [his]41-mr. craven way and that 's gloomy enough , too . [The house]166-the house is six hundred years old and [it]166-the house 's on [the edge of [the moor]1835-the moor]1834-the edge of the moor , and there 's near [a hundred rooms in [it]166-the house]1836-a hundred rooms in it , though most of [them]1836-a hundred rooms in it 's shut up and locked . "[45-mrs. medlock] [She]45-mrs. medlock paused and took another breath . " But there 's nothing else , "[45-mrs. medlock] [she]45-mrs. medlock ended suddenly .

[Mary]38-mary had begun to listen in spite of [herself]38-mary . It all sounded so unlike [India]2-india , and anything new rather attracted [her]38-mary . But [she]38-mary did not intend to look as if [she]38-mary were interested . That was one of [her]38-mary unhappy , disagreeable ways . So [she]38-mary sat still .

" Well , "[45-mrs. medlock] said [Mrs. Medlock]45-mrs. medlock . " What do [you]38-mary think of it ? "[45-mrs. medlock]

" Eh ! "[45-mrs. medlock] [she]45-mrs. medlock said , " but [you]38-mary are like [an old woman]1839-an old woman . Do n't [you]38-mary care ? "[45-mrs. medlock]

" [You]38-mary are right enough there , "[45-mrs. medlock] said [Mrs. Medlock]45-mrs. medlock . " It does n't . [She]45-mrs. medlock stopped [herself]45-mrs. medlock as if [she]45-mrs. medlock had just remembered something in time .

" [He]1840-he 's got a crooked back , "[45-mrs. medlock] [she]45-mrs. medlock said . " That set [him]1840-he wrong . [He]1840-he was [a sour young man]1842-a sour young man and got no good of all [his]1840-he money and big place till [he]1840-he was married . "[45-mrs. medlock]

[Mary]38-mary 's eyes turned toward [her]45-mrs. medlock in spite of [her]38-mary intention not to seem to care . " [She]45-mrs. medlock was [a sweet , pretty thing]1843-a sweet , pretty thing and [he]1840-he 'd have walked [the world]234-the world over to get [her]45-mrs. medlock a blade o ' grass [she]45-mrs. medlock wanted . [Mary]38-mary gave a little involuntary jump .

" Oh ! did [she]45-mrs. medlock die ! "[38-mary] [she]38-mary exclaimed , quite without meaning to . [She]38-mary had just remembered a French fairy story [she]38-mary had once read called " Riquet a la Houppe . "[38-mary] It had been about a poor hunchback and [a beautiful princess]302-a beautiful princess and it had made [her]38-mary suddenly sorry for [Mr. Archibald Craven]41-mr. craven .

" Yes , [she]45-mrs. medlock died , "[45-mrs. medlock] [Mrs. Medlock]45-mrs. medlock answered . " And it made [him]1840-he queerer than ever . [He]1840-he cares about [nobody]175-nobody . [He]1840-he wo n't see [people]167-people . "[45-mrs. medlock]

It sounded like something in a book and it did not make [Mary]38-mary feel cheerful . [A house with a hundred rooms]303-a house with a hundred rooms , nearly all shut up and with [their]304-their doors locked [a house on the edge of [a moor]306-a moor]305-a house on the edge of a moor whatsoever [a moor]306-a moor was sounded dreary . [A man with a crooked back who shut [himself]308-a man with a crooked back who shut himself up also up also]308-a man with a crooked back who shut himself up also ! [She]38-mary stared out of the window with [her]38-mary lips pinched together , and it seemed quite natural that the rain should have begun to pour down in gray slanting lines and splash and stream down the window - panes . If [the pretty wife]309-the pretty wife had been alive [she]309-the pretty wife might have made things cheerful by being something like [[her]309-the pretty wife own mother]310-her own mother and by running in and out and going to parties as [she]309-the pretty wife had done in frocks " full of lace . "[309-the pretty wife] But [she]309-the pretty wife was not there any more .

" [You]38-mary need n't expect to see [him]308-a man with a crooked back who shut himself up also , because ten to one [you]38-mary wo n't , "[45-mrs. medlock] said [Mrs. Medlock]45-mrs. medlock . " And [you]38-mary must n't expect that there will be [people]167-people to talk to [you]38-mary . [You]38-mary 'll have to play about and look after [yourself]38-mary . [You]38-mary 'll be told what [rooms]209-rooms [you]38-mary can go into and [what [rooms]209-rooms [you]38-mary 're to keep out of]1855-what rooms you 're to keep out of . There 's gardens enough . " [I]38-mary shall not want to go poking about , "[38-mary] said [sour little Mary]38-mary and just as suddenly as [she]38-mary had begun to be rather sorry for [Mr. Archibald Craven]41-mr. craven [she]38-mary began to cease to be sorry and to think [he]41-mr. craven was unpleasant enough to deserve all that had happened to [him]41-mr. craven .

And [she]38-mary turned [her]38-mary face toward the streaming panes of the window of [the railway carriage]289-the railway carriage and gazed out at the gray rain - storm which looked as if it would go on forever and ever . [She]38-mary watched it so long and steadily that the grayness grew heavier and heavier before [her]38-mary eyes and [she]38-mary fell asleep .

CHAPTER III

ACROSS [THE MOOR]7-the moor

[She]38-mary slept a long time , and when [she]38-mary awakened [Mrs. Medlock]45-mrs. medlock had bought a lunchbasket at [one of [the stations]313-the stations]312-one of the stations and [they]314-they had some chicken and cold beef and bread and butter and some hot tea . The rain seemed to be streaming down more heavily than ever and [[everybody]185-everybody in [the station]288-the station]316-everybody in the station wore wet and glistening waterproofs . [The guard]318-the guard lighted the lamps in [the carriage]319-the carriage , and [Mrs. Medlock]45-mrs. medlock cheered up very much over [her]45-mrs. medlock tea and chicken and beef . [She]45-mrs. medlock ate a great deal and afterward fell asleep [herself]45-mrs. medlock , and [Mary]38-mary sat and stared at [her]45-mrs. medlock and watched [her]45-mrs. medlock fine bonnet slip on one side until [she]45-mrs. medlock [herself]45-mrs. medlock fell asleep once more in the corner of [the carriage]319-the carriage , lulled by the splashing of the rain against the windows . It was quite dark when [she]38-mary awakened again . [The train]321-the train had stopped at [a station]322-a station and [Mrs. Medlock]45-mrs. medlock was shaking [her]38-mary .

" [You]38-mary have had a sleep ! "[45-mrs. medlock] [she]45-mrs. medlock said . " It 's time to open [your]38-mary eyes ! [We]1858-we 're at [Thwaite Station]8-thwaite station and [we]1858-we 've got a long drive before [us]1858-we . "[45-mrs. medlock]

[Mary]38-mary stood up and tried to keep [her]38-mary eyes open while [Mrs. Medlock]45-mrs. medlock collected [her]38-mary parcels . [The little girl]216-the little girl did not offer to help [her]38-mary , because in [India]2-india [native servants]324-native servants always picked up or carried things and it seemed quite proper that [other people]273-other people should wait on one .

[The station]288-the station was a small one and [[nobody]175-nobody but [themselves]175-nobody]328-nobody but themselves seemed to be getting out of [the train]321-the train . [The station - master]330-the station - master spoke to [Mrs. Medlock]45-mrs. medlock in a rough , good - natured way , pronouncing [his]330-the station - master words in a queer broad fashion which [Mary]38-mary found out afterward was [Yorkshire]50-martha .

" [I]330-the station - master see tha 's got back , "[330-the station - master] [he]330-the station - master said . " An ' tha 's browt th ' young ' un with [thee]38-mary . "[330-the station - master]

" Aye , that 's [her]38-mary , "[45-mrs. medlock] answered [Mrs. Medlock]45-mrs. medlock , speaking with a Yorkshire accent [herself]45-mrs. medlock and jerking [her]45-mrs. medlock head over [her]45-mrs. medlock shoulder toward [Mary]38-mary . " How 's [[thy]38-mary [Missus]1860-missus]1859-thy missus ? "[45-mrs. medlock]

" Well enow . [Th ' carriage]1861-th ' carriage is waitin ' outside for [thee]38-mary . "[45-mrs. medlock]

[A brougham]331-a brougham stood on [the road]332-the road before [the little outside platform]333-the little outside platform . [Mary]38-mary saw that it was [a smart carriage]334-a smart carriage and that it was [a smart footman who helped [her]38-mary in]335-a smart footman who helped her in . [His]335-a smart footman who helped her in long waterproof coat and the waterproof covering of [his]335-a smart footman who helped her in hat were shining and dripping with rain as everything was , [the burly station - master]336-the burly station - master included .

When [he]336-the burly station - master shut the door , mounted the box with [the coachman]337-the coachman , and [they]338-they drove off , [the little girl]216-the little girl found [herself]216-the little girl seated in a comfortably cushioned corner , but [she]216-the little girl was not inclined to go to sleep again . [She]38-mary sat and looked out of the window , curious to see something of [the road over which [she]38-mary was being driven to [the queer place [Mrs. Medlock]45-mrs. medlock had spoken of]341-the queer place mrs. medlock had spoken of]340-the road over which she was being driven to the queer place mrs. medlock had spoken of . [She]38-mary was not at all [a timid child]342-a timid child and [she]38-mary was not exactly frightened , but [she]38-mary felt that there was no knowing what might happen in [a house with [a hundred rooms]344-a hundred rooms]303-a house with a hundred rooms nearly all shut up [a house standing on the edge of [a moor]306-a moor]345-a house standing on the edge of a moor .

" What is [a moor]306-a moor ? "[38-mary] [she]38-mary said suddenly to [Mrs. Medlock]45-mrs. medlock .

" Look out of the window in about ten minutes and [you]38-mary 'll see , "[140-the woman] [the woman]140-the woman answered . " [We]348-they 've got to drive five miles across [Missel Moor]9-missel moor before [we]348-they get to [the Manor]1863-the manor . [You]38-mary wo n't see much because it 's a dark night , but [you]38-mary can see something . "[140-the woman]

[Mary]38-mary asked no more questions but waited in the darkness of [her]38-mary corner , keeping [her]38-mary eyes on the window . The carriage lamps cast rays of light a little distance ahead of [them]348-they and [she]38-mary caught glimpses of the things [they]348-they passed . After [they]348-they had left [the station]288-the station [they]348-they had driven through [a tiny village]350-a tiny village and [she]38-mary had seen [whitewashed cottages]351-whitewashed cottages and the lights of [a public house]352-a public house . Then [they]348-they had passed [a church]353-a church and [a vicarage]354-a vicarage and [a little shop]355-a little shop - window or so in [a cottage with toys and sweets and odd things set out for sale]356-a cottage with toys and sweets and odd things set out for sale . Then [they]348-they were on [the highroad]357-the highroad and [she]38-mary saw hedges and trees . After that there seemed nothing different for a long time or at least it seemed a long time to [her]38-mary .

At last the horses began to go more slowly , as if [they]348-they were climbing up - hill , and presently there seemed to be no more hedges and no more trees . [She]38-mary could see nothing , in fact , but a dense darkness on either side . [She]38-mary leaned forward and pressed [her]38-mary face against the window just as [the carriage]319-the carriage gave a big jolt .

" Eh ! [We]348-they 're on [the moor]1835-the moor now sure enough , "[45-mrs. medlock] said [Mrs. Medlock]45-mrs. medlock .

The carriage lamps shed a yellow light on [a rough - looking road which seemed to be cut through bushes and low - growing things which ended in the great expanse of dark apparently spread out before and around [them]348-they]359-a rough - looking road which seemed to be cut through bushes and low - growing things which ended in the great expanse of dark apparently spread out before and around them . A wind was rising and making a singular , wild , low , rushing sound .

" It 's it 's not [the sea]1865-the sea , is it ? "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary , looking round at [[her]38-mary companion]360-her companion .

" No , not it , "[45-mrs. medlock] answered [Mrs. Medlock]45-mrs. medlock . " Nor it is n't fields nor [mountains]1866-mountains , it 's just miles and miles and miles of [wild land]1867-wild land that nothing grows on but heather and gorse and broom , and nothing lives on but wild ponies and sheep . "[45-mrs. medlock]

" [I]38-mary feel as if it might be [the sea]1865-the sea , if there were water on it , "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary . " It sounds like [the sea]1865-the sea just now . "[38-mary]

" That 's the wind blowing through the bushes , "[45-mrs. medlock] [Mrs. Medlock]45-mrs. medlock said . " It 's [a wild , dreary enough place]1870-a wild , dreary enough place to [my]45-mrs. medlock mind , though there 's plenty that likes it particularly when the heather 's in bloom . "[45-mrs. medlock]

On and on [they]361-they drove through the darkness , and though the rain stopped , the wind rushed by and whistled and made strange sounds . [The road]332-the road went up and down , and several times [the carriage]319-the carriage passed over [a little bridge beneath which water rushed very fast with a great deal of noise]364-a little bridge beneath which water rushed very fast with a great deal of noise . [Mary]38-mary felt as if the drive would never come to an end and that [the wide , bleak moor]365-the wide , bleak moor was a wide expanse of black ocean through which [she]38-mary was passing on [a strip of dry land]366-a strip of dry land .

" [I]38-mary do n't like it , "[38-mary] [she]38-mary said to [herself]38-mary . " [I]38-mary do n't like it , "[38-mary] and [she]38-mary pinched [her]38-mary thin lips more tightly together .

The horses were climbing up [a hilly piece of road]367-a hilly piece of road when [she]38-mary first caught sight of a light . [Mrs. Medlock]45-mrs. medlock saw it as soon as [she]38-mary did and drew a long sigh of relief .

" Eh , [I]45-mrs. medlock am glad to see that bit o ' light twinkling , "[45-mrs. medlock] [she]45-mrs. medlock exclaimed . " It 's the light in the lodge window . [We]319-the carriage shall get a good cup of tea after a bit , at all events . "[45-mrs. medlock]

It was " after a bit , "[45-mrs. medlock] as [she]45-mrs. medlock said , for when [the carriage]319-the carriage passed through [the park]369-the park gates there was still [two miles of avenue to drive through]370-two miles of avenue to drive through and the trees which nearly met overhead made it seem as if [they]319-the carriage were driving through [a long dark vault]371-a long dark vault .

[They]319-the carriage drove out of [the vault]372-the vault into [a clear space]373-a clear space and stopped before [an immensely long but low - built house which seemed to ramble round [a stone court]375-a stone court]374-an immensely long but low - built house which seemed to ramble round a stone court . At first [Mary]38-mary thought that there were no lights at all in the windows , but as [she]38-mary got out of [the carriage]319-the carriage [she]38-mary saw that [one room in a corner upstairs]377-one room in a corner upstairs showed a dull glow .

The entrance door was a huge one made of massive , curiously shaped panels of oak studded with big iron nails and bound with great iron bars . It opened into [an enormous hall]378-an enormous hall , which was so dimly lighted that the faces in the portraits on the walls and [the figures in the suits of armor]379-the figures in the suits of armor made [Mary]38-mary feel that [she]38-mary did not want to look at [them]319-the carriage . As [she]38-mary stood on the stone floor [she]38-mary looked [a very small , odd little black figure]380-a very small , odd little black figure , and [she]38-mary felt as small and lost and odd as [she]38-mary looked .

[A neat , thin old man]381-a neat , thin old man stood near the manservant who opened the door for [them]382-them .

" [You]38-mary are to take [her]380-a very small , odd little black figure to [[her]380-a very small , odd little black figure room]1871-her room , "[381-a neat , thin old man] [he]381-a neat , thin old man said in a husky voice . " [He]381-a neat , thin old man does n't want to see [her]380-a very small , odd little black figure . [He]381-a neat , thin old man 's going to [London]4-london in the morning . "[381-a neat , thin old man]

" Very well , [Mr. Pitcher]49-pitcher , "[45-mrs. medlock] [Mrs. Medlock]45-mrs. medlock answered . " So long as [I]45-mrs. medlock know what 's expected of [me]45-mrs. medlock , [I]45-mrs. medlock can manage . "[45-mrs. medlock]

" What 's expected of [you]38-mary , [Mrs. Medlock]45-mrs. medlock , "[49-pitcher] [Mr. Pitcher]49-pitcher said , " is that [you]38-mary make sure that [he]381-a neat , thin old man 's not disturbed and that [he]381-a neat , thin old man does n't see what [he]381-a neat , thin old man does n't want to see . "[49-pitcher]

And then [Mary Lennox]38-mary was led up a broad staircase and down [a long corridor]383-a long corridor and up [a short flight of steps]384-a short flight of steps and through [another corridor]385-another corridor and another , until a door opened in a wall and [she]38-mary found [herself]38-mary in [a room]386-a room with a fire in [it]386-a room and a supper on a table .

[Mrs. Medlock]45-mrs. medlock said unceremoniously :

" Well , here [you]38-mary are ! [This room]1872-this room and the next are where [you]38-mary 'll live and [you]38-mary must keep to [them]1873-them . Do n't [you]38-mary forget that ! "[45-mrs. medlock]

It was in this way [Mistress Mary]38-mary arrived at [Misselthwaite Manor]1-misselthwaite manor and [she]38-mary had perhaps never felt quite so contrary in all [her]38-mary life .

CHAPTER IV

[MARTHA]50-martha

When [she]50-martha opened [her]50-martha eyes in the morning it was because [a young housemaid]387-a young housemaid had come into [[her]50-martha room]1871-her room to light the fire and was kneeling on the hearth - rug raking out the cinders noisily . [Mary]38-mary lay and watched [her]387-a young housemaid for a few moments and then began to look about [the room]201-the room . [She]38-mary had never seen [a room]386-a room at all like [it]201-the room and thought [it]201-the room curious and gloomy . The walls were covered with tapestry with a forest scene embroidered on it . There were [fantastically dressed people under the trees]391-fantastically dressed people under the trees and in the distance there was a glimpse of [the turrets of [a castle]393-a castle]392-the turrets of a castle . There were [hunters]394-hunters and horses and dogs and [ladies]395-ladies . [Mary]38-mary felt as if [she]38-mary were in [the forest]396-the forest with [them]397-them . Out of a deep window [she]38-mary could see [a great climbing stretch of land]398-a great climbing stretch of land which seemed to have no trees on [it]398-a great climbing stretch of land , and to look rather like [an endless , dull , purplish sea]399-an endless , dull , purplish sea .

" What is that ? "[38-mary] [she]38-mary said , pointing out of the window .

[Martha]50-martha , [the young housemaid , who had just risen to [her]50-martha feet]400-the young housemaid , who had just risen to her feet , looked and pointed also . " That there ? "[50-martha] [she]50-martha said .

" Yes . "[50-martha]

" That 's [th ' moor]1874-th ' moor , "[50-martha] with a good - natured grin . " Does [tha]1875-tha ' like it ? "[50-martha]

" No , "[38-mary] answered [Mary]38-mary . " [I]38-mary hate it . "[38-mary]

" That 's because [tha'rt]1875-tha not used to it , "[50-martha] [Martha]50-martha said , going back to [her]50-martha hearth . " [Tha]1875-tha ' thinks it 's too big an ' bare now . But [tha]1875-tha ' will like it . "[50-martha]

" Do [you]50-martha ? "[38-mary] inquired [Mary]38-mary .

" Aye , that [I]50-martha do , "[50-martha] answered [Martha]50-martha , cheerfully polishing away at the grate . " [I]50-martha just love it . It 's none bare . It 's covered wi ' growin ' things as smells sweet . It 's fair lovely in spring an ' summer when th ' gorse an ' broom an ' heather 's in flower . It smells o ' honey an ' there 's such a lot o ' fresh air an ' th ' sky looks so high an ' th ' bees an ' skylarks makes such a nice noise hummin ' an ' singin ' . Eh ! [I]50-martha would n't live away from [th ' moor]1874-th ' moor for anythin ' . "[50-martha]

[Mary]38-mary listened to [her]50-martha with a grave , puzzled expression . [The native servants [she]38-mary had been used to in [India]2-india]401-the native servants she had been used to in india were not in the least like this . [They]401-the native servants she had been used to in india were obsequious and servile and did not presume to talk to [[their]401-the native servants she had been used to in india masters]402-their masters as if [they]401-the native servants she had been used to in india were [[their]401-the native servants she had been used to in india equals]403-their equals . [They]401-the native servants she had been used to in india made salaams and called [them]401-the native servants she had been used to in india " protector of [the poor "[401-the native servants she had been used to in india] and names of that sort]1877-the poor " and names of that sort . [Indian servants]404-indian servants were commanded to do things , not asked . It was not the custom to say " please "[38-mary] and " thank [you]1878-you "[38-mary] and [Mary]38-mary had always slapped [her]38-mary Ayah in the face when [she]38-mary was angry . [She]38-mary wondered a little what [this girl]405-this girl would do if [one]406-one slapped [her]38-mary in the face . [She]405-this girl was a round , rosy , good - natured - looking creature , but [she]405-this girl had a sturdy way which made [Mistress Mary]38-mary wonder if [she]38-mary might not even slap back if [the person who slapped]407-the person who slapped [her]38-mary was only [a little girl]127-a little girl .

" [You]405-this girl are [a strange servant]1879-a strange servant , "[38-mary] [she]38-mary said from [her]38-mary pillows , rather haughtily .

[Martha]50-martha sat up on [her]50-martha heels , with [her]50-martha blacking - brush in [her]50-martha hand , and laughed , without seeming the least out of temper .

" Eh ! [I]50-martha know that , "[50-martha] [she]50-martha said . " If there was [a grand Missus at [Misselthwaite]5-misselthwaite]1880-a grand missus at misselthwaite [I]50-martha should never have been even [one of [th ' under house - maids]1882-th ' under house - maids]1881-one of th ' under house - maids . [I]50-martha might have been let to be [scullerymaid]1883-scullerymaid but [I]50-martha 'd never have been let [upstairs]1884-upstairs . [I]50-martha 'm too common an ' [I]50-martha talk too much [Yorkshire]50-martha . But this is [a funny house]1885-a funny house for all it 's so grand . Seems like there 's [neither Master]1886-neither master nor [Mistress]1887-mistress except [Mr. Pitcher]49-pitcher an ' [Mrs. Medlock]45-mrs. medlock . [Mr. Craven]41-mr. craven , [he]41-mr. craven wo n't be troubled about anythin ' when [he]41-mr. craven 's [here]1771-here , an ' [he]41-mr. craven 's nearly always away . [Mrs. Medlock]45-mrs. medlock gave [me]50-martha th ' place out o ' kindness . [She]45-mrs. medlock told [me]50-martha [she]45-mrs. medlock could never have done it if [Misselthwaite]5-misselthwaite had been like [other big houses]1889-other big houses . "[50-martha] " Are [you]50-martha going to be [[my]38-mary servant]1890-my servant ? "[38-mary] [Mary]38-mary asked , still in [her]38-mary imperious little Indian way .

[Martha]50-martha began to rub [her]50-martha grate again .

" [I]50-martha 'm [[Mrs. Medlock]45-mrs. medlock 's servant]1891-mrs. medlock 's servant , "[50-martha] [she]50-martha said stoutly . " An ' [she]50-martha 's [[Mr. Craven 's]1892-mr. craven 's]1892-mr. craven 's but [I]50-martha 'm to do [the housemaid]1894-the housemaid 's work up here an ' wait on [you]50-martha a bit . But [you]50-martha wo n't need much waitin ' on . "[50-martha]

" Who is going to dress [me]38-mary ? "[38-mary] demanded [Mary]38-mary .

[Martha]50-martha sat up on [her]50-martha heels again and stared . [She]50-martha spoke in broad Yorkshire in [her]50-martha amazement .

" Canna ' [tha]1895-tha ' dress [thysen]50-martha ! "[50-martha] [she]50-martha said .

" What do [you]50-martha mean ? [I]38-mary do n't understand [your]50-martha language , "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary .

" Eh ! [I]50-martha forgot , "[50-martha] [Martha]50-martha said . " [Mrs. Medlock]45-mrs. medlock told [me]50-martha [I]50-martha 'd have to be careful or [you]50-martha would n't know what [I]50-martha was sayin ' . [I]50-martha mean ca n't [you]50-martha put on [your]50-martha own clothes ? "[50-martha]

" No , "[38-mary] answered [Mary]38-mary , quite indignantly . " [I]38-mary never did in [my]38-mary life . [[My]38-mary Ayah]1757-my ayah dressed [me]38-mary , of course . "[38-mary]

" Well , "[50-martha] said [Martha]50-martha , evidently not in the least aware that [she]50-martha was impudent , " it 's time [tha]50-martha ' should learn . [Tha]50-martha ' can not begin younger . It 'll do [thee]50-martha good to wait on thysen a bit . [[My]50-martha mother]1897-my mother always said [she]1897-my mother could n't see why [[grand people]1898-grand people 's children]1899-grand people 's children did n't turn out [fair fools]1900-fair fools what with [nurses]1901-nurses an ' bein ' washed an ' dressed an ' took out to walk as if [they]1899-grand people 's children was puppies ! "[50-martha]

" It is different in [India]2-india , "[38-mary] said [Mistress Mary]38-mary disdainfully . [She]38-mary could scarcely stand this .

But [Martha]50-martha was not at all crushed .

" Eh ! [I]50-martha can see it 's different , "[50-martha] [she]50-martha answered almost sympathetically . " [I]50-martha dare say it 's because there 's such a lot o ' blacks there instead o ' [respectable white people]1902-respectable white people . When [I]50-martha heard [you]50-martha was comin ' from [India]2-india [I]50-martha thought [you]50-martha was [a black]1903-a black too . "[50-martha]

[Mary]38-mary sat up in bed furious .

" What ! "[38-mary] [she]38-mary said . " What ! [You]50-martha thought [I]38-mary was [a native]1904-a native . [You]50-martha [[you]50-martha daughter]1905-you daughter of a pig ! "[38-mary]

[Martha]50-martha stared and looked hot .

" Who are [you]50-martha callin ' names ? "[38-mary] [she]38-mary said . " [You]50-martha need n't be so vexed . That 's not th ' way for [a young lady]1906-a young lady to talk . [I]38-mary 've nothin' against [th ' blacks]1907-th ' blacks . When [you]50-martha read about ['em]1907-th ' blacks in [tracts]1908-tracts [they]1907-th ' blacks 're always very religious . [You]50-martha always read as [a black]1903-a black 's [a man]1910-a man an ' [a brother]1911-a brother . [I]38-mary 've never seen [a black]1903-a black an ' [I]38-mary was fair pleased to think [I]38-mary was goin' to see one close . When [I]38-mary come in to light [your]50-martha fire this mornin ' [I]38-mary crep ' up to [your]50-martha bed an ' pulled th ' cover back careful to look at [you]50-martha . An ' there [you]50-martha was , "[38-mary] disappointedly , " no more black than [me]38-mary for all [you]50-martha 're so yeller . "[38-mary]

[Mary]38-mary did not even try to control [her]38-mary rage and humiliation . " [You]50-martha thought [I]38-mary was [a native]1904-a native ! [You]50-martha dared ! [You]50-martha do n't know anything about [natives]1914-natives ! [They]1914-natives are not [people]167-people [they]1914-natives 're [servants who must salaam to [you]50-martha]1916-servants who must salaam to you . [You]50-martha know nothing about [India]2-india . [You]50-martha know nothing about anything ! "[38-mary]

[She]38-mary was in such a rage and felt so helpless before [the girl]409-the girl 's simple stare , and somehow [she]38-mary suddenly felt so horribly lonely and far away from everything [she]38-mary understood and which understood [her]38-mary , that [she]38-mary threw [herself]38-mary face downward on the pillows and burst into passionate sobbing . [She]38-mary sobbed so unrestrainedly that good - natured [Yorkshire Martha]50-martha was a little frightened and quite sorry for [her]38-mary . [She]50-martha went to the bed and bent over [her]38-mary .

" Eh ! [you]38-mary must n't cry like that there ! "[50-martha] [she]50-martha begged . " [You]38-mary must n't for sure . [I]50-martha did n't know [you]38-mary 'd be vexed . [I]50-martha do n't know anythin ' about anythin ' just like [you]38-mary said . [I]50-martha beg [your]38-mary pardon , [Miss.]52-miss. Do stop cryin ' . "[50-martha]

There was something comforting and really friendly in [her]38-mary queer Yorkshire speech and sturdy way which had a good effect on [Mary]38-mary . [She]38-mary gradually ceased crying and became quiet . [Martha]50-martha looked relieved .

" It 's time for [thee]38-mary to get up now , "[50-martha] [she]50-martha said . " [Mrs. Medlock]45-mrs. medlock said [I]50-martha was to carry [tha]1917-tha ' breakfast an ' tea an ' dinner into [th ' room]1918-th ' room next to this . [It]1918-th ' room 's been made into a nursery for [thee]38-mary . [I]50-martha 'll help [thee]38-mary on with [thy]38-mary clothes if [tha'll]1917-tha get out o ' bed . If th ' buttons are at th ' back [tha]1917-tha ' can not button them up tha'self . "[50-martha]

When [Mary]38-mary at last decided to get up , the clothes [Martha]50-martha took from [the wardrobe]410-the wardrobe were not the ones [she]50-martha had worn when [she]50-martha arrived the night before with [Mrs. Medlock]45-mrs. medlock .

" Those are not mine , "[50-martha] [she]50-martha said . " [Mine]50-martha are black . "[50-martha]

[She]50-martha looked the thick white wool coat and dress over , and added with cool approval :

" Those are nicer than [mine]50-martha . "[50-martha]

" These are th ' ones [tha]1917-tha ' must put on , "[50-martha] [Martha]50-martha answered . " [Mr. Craven]41-mr. craven ordered [Mrs. Medlock]45-mrs. medlock to get 'em in [London]4-london . [He]41-mr. craven said ' [I]50-martha wo n't have [a child dressed in black]1919-a child dressed in black wanderin ' about like a lost soul , ' [he]41-mr. craven said . ' It 'd make the place sadder than it is . Put color on [her]1919-a child dressed in black . ' [Mother]53-mother [she]53-mother said [she]53-mother knew what [he]41-mr. craven meant . [Mother]53-mother always knows what a body means . [She]53-mother does n't hold with black hersel ' . "[50-martha]

" [I]38-mary hate black things , "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary .

The dressing process was one which taught [them]411-them both something . [Martha]50-martha had " buttoned up "[38-mary] [[her]50-martha little sisters]412-her little sisters and [brothers]413-brothers but [she]50-martha had never seen [a child who stood still and waited for [another person]415-another person to do things for [her]50-martha as if [she]50-martha had neither hands nor feet of [her]50-martha own]414-a child who stood still and waited for another person to do things for her as if she had neither hands nor feet of her own .

" Why does n't tha ' put on [tha]1920-tha ' own shoes ? "[50-martha] [she]50-martha said when [Mary]38-mary quietly held out [her]38-mary foot .

" [My]38-mary Ayah did it , "[38-mary] answered [Mary]38-mary , staring . " It was the custom . "[38-mary]

[She]50-martha said that very often " It was the custom . "[50-martha] [The native servants]144-the native servants were always saying it . If [one]406-one told [them]144-the native servants to do a thing [[their]144-the native servants ancestors]418-their ancestors had not done for a thousand years [they]144-the native servants gazed at one mildly and said , " It is not the custom "[144-the native servants] and [one]406-one knew that was the end of the matter .

It had not been the custom that [Mistress Mary]38-mary should do anything but stand and allow [herself]38-mary to be dressed like a doll , but before [she]38-mary was ready for breakfast [she]38-mary began to suspect that [her]38-mary life at [Misselthwaite Manor]1-misselthwaite manor would end by teaching [her]38-mary a number of things quite new to [her]38-mary things such as putting on [her]38-mary own shoes and stockings , and picking up things [she]38-mary let fall . If [Martha]50-martha had been [a well - trained fine young lady 's maid]420-a well - trained fine young lady 's maid [she]50-martha would have been more subservient and respectful and would have known that it was [her]50-martha business to brush hair , and button boots , and pick things up and lay them away . [She]50-martha was , however , only [an untrained Yorkshire rustic who had been brought up in [a moorland cottage]422-a moorland cottage with [a swarm of [little brothers]424-little brothers and [sisters]425-sisters who had never dreamed of doing anything but waiting on [themselves]423-a swarm of little brothers and sisters who had never dreamed of doing anything but waiting on themselves and on the younger ones who were either babies in arms or just learning to totter about and tumble over things and on [the younger ones]426-the younger ones who were either [babies in arms or just learning to totter about and tumble over things]427-babies in arms or just learning to totter about and tumble over things]423-a swarm of little brothers and sisters who had never dreamed of doing anything but waiting on themselves and on the younger ones who were either babies in arms or just learning to totter about and tumble over things]421-an untrained yorkshire rustic who had been brought up in a moorland cottage with a swarm of little brothers and sisters who had never dreamed of doing anything but waiting on themselves and on the younger ones who were either babies in arms or just learning to totter about and tumble over things .

If [Mary Lennox]38-mary had been [a child who was ready to be amused]428-a child who was ready to be amused [she]38-mary would perhaps have laughed at [Martha]50-martha 's readiness to talk , but [Mary]38-mary only listened to [her]38-mary coldly and wondered at [her]38-mary freedom of manner . At first [she]38-mary was not at all interested , but gradually , as [the girl]409-the girl rattled on in [her]409-the girl good - tempered , homely way , [Mary]38-mary began to notice what [she]38-mary was saying .

" Eh ! [you]38-mary should see ['em]1921-'em all , "[38-mary] [she]38-mary said . " There 's twelve of [us]1922-us an ' [[my]38-mary father]1923-my father only gets sixteen shilling a week . [I]38-mary can tell [you]38-mary [[my]38-mary mother]1897-my mother 's put to it to get porridge for ['em]1921-'em all . [They]1925-they tumble about on [th ' moor]1874-th ' moor an ' play there all day an ' [mother]224-mother says th ' air of th ' moor fattens 'em . [She]1897-my mother says [she]1897-my mother believes [they]1925-they eat th ' grass same as [th ' wild ponies]1928-th ' wild ponies do . [[Our]1922-us [Dickon]54-dickon]1929-our dickon , [he]54-dickon 's twelve years old and [he]54-dickon 's got a young pony [he]54-dickon calls [his]54-dickon own . "[38-mary]

" Where did [he]54-dickon get [it]1930-it ? "[38-mary] asked [Mary]38-mary .

" [He]54-dickon found it on [th ' moor]1874-th ' moor with [[its]1930-it mother]1932-its mother when it was [a little one]1933-a little one an ' [he]54-dickon began to make [friends]1934-friends with [it]1930-it an ' give it bits o ' bread an ' pluck young grass for it . And [it]1930-it got to like [him]54-dickon so it follows [him]54-dickon about an ' it lets [him]54-dickon get on its back . [Dickon]54-dickon 's [a kind lad]1935-a kind lad an ' animals likes [him]54-dickon . "[38-mary]

[Mary]38-mary had never possessed an animal pet of [her]38-mary own and had always thought [she]38-mary should like one . So [she]38-mary began to feel a slight interest in [Dickon]54-dickon , and as [she]38-mary had never before been interested in any one but [herself]38-mary , it was the dawning of a healthy sentiment . When [she]38-mary went into [the room which had been made into [a nursery]431-a nursery for [her]38-mary]430-the room which had been made into a nursery for her , [she]38-mary found that [it]430-the room which had been made into a nursery for her was rather like [the one [she]38-mary had slept in]432-the one she had slept in . It was not [[a child]1768-a child 's room]434-a child 's room , but [[a grown - up person]435-a grown - up person 's room]436-a grown - up person 's room , with gloomy old pictures on the walls and heavy old oak chairs . A table in the center was set with a good substantial breakfast . But [she]38-mary had always had a very small appetite , and [she]38-mary looked with something more than indifference at the first plate [Martha]50-martha set before [her]38-mary .

" [I]38-mary do n't want it , "[38-mary] [she]38-mary said .

" Tha ' does n't want [thy]50-martha porridge ! "[50-martha] [Martha]50-martha exclaimed incredulously .

" No . "[50-martha]

" Tha ' does n't know how good it is . Put a bit o ' treacle on it or a bit o ' sugar . "[50-martha]

" [I]38-mary do n't want it , "[38-mary] repeated [Mary]38-mary .

" Eh ! "[50-martha] said [Martha]50-martha . " [I]50-martha ca n't abide to see good victuals go to waste . If [[our]1936-our children]1937-our children was at this table [they]1937-our children 'd clean it bare in five minutes . "[50-martha]

" Why ? "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary coldly . " Why ! "[50-martha] echoed [Martha]50-martha . " Because [they]1937-our children scarce ever had [their]1937-our children stomachs full in [their]1937-our children lives . [They]1937-our children 're as hungry as [young hawks an ' foxes]1938-young hawks an ' foxes . "[50-martha]

" [I]38-mary do n't know what it is to be hungry , "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary , with the indifference of ignorance .

[Martha]50-martha looked indignant .

" Well , it would do [thee]50-martha good to try it . [I]50-martha can see that plain enough , "[50-martha] [she]50-martha said outspokenly . " [I]50-martha 've no patience with [folk]1939-folk as sits an ' just stares at good bread an ' meat . "[50-martha]

[Mary]38-mary drank some tea and ate a little toast and some marmalade .

" [You]38-mary wrap up warm an ' run out an ' play [you]38-mary , "[50-martha] said [Martha]50-martha . " It 'll do [you]38-mary good and give [you]38-mary some stomach for [your]38-mary meat . "[50-martha]

[Mary]38-mary went to the window . There were [gardens]1837-gardens and paths and big trees , but everything looked dull and wintry .

" Out ? Why should [I]38-mary go out on a day like this ? "[38-mary] " Well , if tha ' does n't go out [tha'lt]1943-tha'lt have to stay in , an ' what has tha ' got to do ? "[38-mary]

[Mary]38-mary glanced about [her]38-mary . There was nothing to do . When [Mrs. Medlock]45-mrs. medlock had prepared [the nursery]173-the nursery [she]45-mrs. medlock had not thought of amusement . Perhaps it would be better to go and see what [the gardens]439-the gardens were like .

" Who will go with [me]45-mrs. medlock ? "[45-mrs. medlock] [she]45-mrs. medlock inquired .

[Martha]50-martha stared .

" [You]38-mary 'll go by [yourself]38-mary , "[45-mrs. medlock] [she]45-mrs. medlock answered . " [You]38-mary 'll have to learn to play like [other children]278-other children does when [they]278-other children have n't got [sisters]425-sisters and [brothers]413-brothers . It was really this mention of [Dickon]54-dickon which made [Mary]38-mary decide to go out , though [she]38-mary was not aware of it . There would be , birds outside though there would not be ponies or sheep . They would be different from the birds in [India]2-india and it might amuse [her]38-mary to look at them .

[Martha]50-martha found [her]50-martha coat and hat for [her]38-mary and a pair of stout little boots and [she]50-martha showed [her]38-mary [her]38-mary way [downstairs]440-downstairs .

" If tha ' goes round that way tha'll come to [th ' gardens]1954-th ' gardens , "[38-mary] [she]38-mary said , pointing to a gate in a wall of shrubbery . " There 's lots o ' flowers in summer - time , but there 's nothin' bloomin ' now . " Why ? "[38-mary] asked [Mary]38-mary in spite of [herself]38-mary . Here was another locked door added to the hundred in [the strange house]441-the strange house .

" [Mr. Craven]41-mr. craven had it shut when [[his]41-mr. craven wife]1821-his wife died so sudden . [He]41-mr. craven wo n't let [no one]145-no one go inside . After [she]38-mary was gone [Mary]38-mary turned down the walk which led to the door in [the shrubbery]442-the shrubbery . [She]38-mary could not help thinking about [the garden which [no one]145-no one had been into for ten years]443-the garden which no one had been into for ten years . [She]38-mary wondered what it would look like and whether there were any flowers still alive in [it]443-the garden which no one had been into for ten years . There were trees , and flower - beds , and evergreens clipped into strange shapes , and a large pool with an old gray fountain in its midst . But the flower - beds were bare and wintry and the fountain was not playing . This was not [the garden which was shut up]447-the garden which was shut up . How could [a garden]245-a garden be shut up ? [You]449-you could always walk into [a garden]245-a garden .

[She]38-mary was just thinking this when [she]38-mary saw that , at the end of the path [she]38-mary was following , there seemed to be a long wall , with ivy growing over it . [She]38-mary was not familiar enough with [England]3-england to know that [she]38-mary was coming upon [the kitchen - gardens]451-the kitchen - gardens where the vegetables and fruit were growing . [She]38-mary went toward the wall and found that there was a green door in the ivy , and that it stood open . This was not [the closed garden]452-the closed garden , evidently , and [she]38-mary could go into [it]443-the garden which no one had been into for ten years .

[She]38-mary went through the door and found that [it]443-the garden which no one had been into for ten years was [a garden with walls all round [it]443-the garden which no one had been into for ten years and that [it]443-the garden which no one had been into for ten years was only one of [several walled gardens which seemed to open into one another]454-several walled gardens which seemed to open into one another]453-a garden with walls all round it and that it was only one of several walled gardens which seemed to open into one another . [She]38-mary saw another open green door , revealing bushes and pathways between beds containing winter vegetables . Fruit - trees were trained flat against the wall , and over some of the beds there were glass frames . [The place]228-the place was bare and ugly enough , [Mary]38-mary thought , as [she]38-mary stood and stared about [her]38-mary . It might be nicer in summer when things were green , but there was nothing pretty about it now .

Presently [an old man with a spade over [his]456-an old man with a spade over his shoulder shoulder]456-an old man with a spade over his shoulder walked through the door leading from [the second garden]457-the second garden . [He]456-an old man with a spade over his shoulder looked startled when [he]456-an old man with a spade over his shoulder saw [Mary]38-mary , and then touched [his]456-an old man with a spade over his shoulder cap . [He]456-an old man with a spade over his shoulder had a surly old face , and did not seem at all pleased to see [her]38-mary but then [she]38-mary was displeased with [[his]456-an old man with a spade over his shoulder garden]458-his garden and wore [her]38-mary " quite contrary "[38-mary] expression , and certainly did not seem at all pleased to see [him]456-an old man with a spade over his shoulder .

" What is [this place]1962-this place ? "[38-mary] [she]38-mary asked .

" If tha ' likes . But there 's nowt to see . "[38-mary]

[Mary]38-mary made no response . [She]38-mary went down [the path]459-the path and through the second green door . There , [she]38-mary found more walls and winter vegetables and glass frames , but in the second wall there was another green door and it was not open . Perhaps it led into [the garden]146-the garden which [no one]145-no one had seen for ten years . As [she]38-mary was not at all [a timid child]342-a timid child and always did what [she]38-mary wanted to do , [Mary]38-mary went to the green door and turned the handle . [Mary]38-mary looked for it , and yet when [she]38-mary had entered the upper end of [the garden]146-the garden [she]38-mary had noticed that the wall did not seem to end with [the orchard]466-the orchard but to extend beyond [it]463-the mysterious garden as if it enclosed a place at the other side . [She]38-mary could see the tops of trees above the wall , and when [she]38-mary stood still [she]38-mary saw a bird with a bright red breast sitting on the topmost branch of one of them , and suddenly [he]467-he burst into [his]467-he winter song almost as if [he]467-he had caught sight of [her]38-mary and was calling to [her]38-mary .

[She]38-mary stopped and listened to [him]467-he and somehow [his]467-he cheerful , friendly little whistle gave [her]38-mary a pleased feeling even [a disagreeable little girl]468-a disagreeable little girl may be lonely , and [the big closed house]469-the big closed house and [big bare moor]470-big bare moor and [big bare gardens]471-big bare gardens had made [this one]472-this one feel as if there was no one left in [the world]234-the world but [herself]38-mary . If [she]38-mary had been [an affectionate child]188-an affectionate child , who had been used to being loved , [she]38-mary would have broken [her]38-mary heart , but even though [she]38-mary was " [Mistress Mary]38-mary Quite Contrary "[38-mary] [she]38-mary was desolate , and the bright - breasted little bird brought a look into [her]38-mary sour little face which was almost a smile . [She]38-mary listened to [him]467-he until [he]467-he flew away . [He]467-he was not like an Indian bird and [she]38-mary liked [him]467-he and wondered if [she]38-mary should ever see [him]467-he again . Perhaps [he]467-he lived in [the mysterious garden]463-the mysterious garden and knew all about it .

Perhaps it was because [she]38-mary had nothing whatever to do that [she]38-mary thought so much of [the deserted garden]476-the deserted garden . [She]38-mary was curious about it and wanted to see what it was like . Why had [Mr. Archibald Craven]41-mr. craven buried the key ? If [he]41-mr. craven had liked [[his]41-mr. craven wife]1821-his wife so much why did [he]41-mr. craven hate [[her]1821-his wife garden]1960-her garden ? [She]38-mary wondered if [she]38-mary should ever see [him]467-he , but [she]38-mary knew that if [she]38-mary did [she]38-mary should not like [him]467-he , and [he]467-he would not like [her]38-mary , and that [she]38-mary should only stand and stare at [him]467-he and say nothing , though [she]38-mary should be wanting dreadfully to ask [him]467-he why [he]467-he had done such a queer thing .

" [People]167-people never like [me]38-mary and [I]38-mary never like [people]167-people , "[38-mary] [she]38-mary thought . " [I]38-mary have been into [the other gardens]1971-the other gardens , "[38-mary] [she]38-mary said .

" [I]38-mary went into [the orchard]466-the orchard . "[38-mary]

" The one on the other side of the wall , "[38-mary] answered [Mistress Mary]38-mary . " There are trees there [I]38-mary saw the tops of them . A bird with a red breast was sitting on one of them and [he]481-the old man sang . "[38-mary]

To [her]38-mary surprise the surly old weather - beaten face actually changed its expression . A slow smile spread over it and [the gardener]482-the gardener looked quite different . It made [her]38-mary think that it was curious how much nicer [a person]483-a person looked when [he]482-the gardener smiled . [She]38-mary had not thought of it before .

[He]481-the old man turned about to the orchard side of [[his]481-the old man garden]458-his garden and began to whistle a low soft whistle . [She]38-mary could not understand how [such a surly man]485-such a surly man could make such a coaxing sound . Almost the next moment a wonderful thing happened . [She]38-mary heard a soft little rushing flight through the air and it was the bird with the red breast flying to [them]486-them , and [he]481-the old man actually alighted on the big clod of earth quite near to [the gardener]482-the gardener 's foot .

" Here [he]481-the old man is , "[481-the old man] chuckled [the old man]481-the old man , and then [he]481-the old man spoke to the bird as if [he]481-the old man were speaking to [a child]1768-a child .

" Where has [tha]1975-tha ' been , [tha ' cheeky little beggar]1976-tha ' cheeky little beggar ? "[481-the old man] [he]481-the old man said . "[481-the old man]

The bird put [his]481-the old man tiny head on one side and looked up at [him]481-the old man with [his]481-the old man soft bright eye which was like a black dewdrop . [He]481-the old man seemed quite familiar and not the least afraid . [He]481-the old man hopped about and pecked [the earth]490-the earth briskly , looking for seeds and insects . It actually gave [Mary]38-mary a queer feeling in [her]38-mary heart , because [he]481-the old man was so pretty and cheerful and seemed so like [a person]483-a person . [He]481-the old man had a tiny plump body and a delicate beak , and slender delicate legs .

" Will [he]481-the old man always come when [you]481-the old man call [him]481-the old man ? "[38-mary] [she]38-mary asked almost in a whisper .

" Aye , that [he]481-the old man will . [I]38-mary 've knowed [him]481-the old man ever since [he]481-the old man was [a fledgling]1977-a fledgling . "[38-mary]

" What kind of a bird is [he]481-the old man ? "[38-mary] [Mary]38-mary asked .

" Does n't [tha]1981-th ' know ? [He]481-the old man 's a robin redbreast an ' [they]481-the old man 're [th]1981-th ' friendliest , curiousest birds alive . Watch [him]481-the old man peckin ' about there an ' lookin ' round at [us]1981-th now an ' again . [He]481-the old man knows [we]1981-th 're talkin ' about [him]481-the old man . "[38-mary]

It was the queerest thing in [the world]234-the world to see [the old fellow]493-the old fellow . [He]494-he looked at the plump little scarlet - waistcoated bird as if [he]494-he were both proud and fond of [him]493-the old fellow .

" [He]481-the old man 's [a conceited one]1984-a conceited one , "[494-he] [he]494-he chuckled . " [He]481-the old man likes to hear [folk]1939-folk talk about [him]481-the old man . An ' curious bless [me]494-he , there never was [his]481-the old man like for curiosity an ' meddlin ' . [He]481-the old man 's always comin ' to see what [I]494-he 'm plantin ' . [He]481-the old man knows all th ' things [Mester]1986-mester [Craven]41-mr. craven never troubles hissel ' to find out . [He]481-the old man 's [th ' head gardener]1987-th ' head gardener , [he]481-the old man is . "[494-he]

[The robin]495-the robin hopped about busily pecking the soil and now and then stopped and looked at [them]496-them a little . [Mary]38-mary thought [his]495-the robin black dewdrop eyes gazed at [her]38-mary with great curiosity . It really seemed as if [he]494-he were finding out all about [her]38-mary . The queer feeling in [her]38-mary heart increased . " Where did the rest of the brood fly to ? "[38-mary] [she]38-mary asked .

" There 's no knowin ' . [The old ones]1988-the old ones turn 'em out o ' [[their]1988-the old ones nest]1989-their nest an ' make 'em fly an ' [they]1988-the old ones 're scattered before [you]38-mary know it . [This one]472-this one was a knowin ' one an ' [he]495-the robin knew [he]495-the robin was lonely . "[38-mary]

[Mistress Mary]38-mary went a step nearer to [the robin]495-the robin and looked at [him]495-the robin very hard .

" [I]38-mary 'm lonely , "[38-mary] [she]38-mary said .

[She]38-mary had not known before that this was one of the things which made [her]38-mary feel sour and cross . [She]38-mary seemed to find it out when [the robin]495-the robin looked at [her]38-mary and [she]38-mary looked at [the robin]495-the robin .

[The old gardener]500-the old gardener pushed [his]500-the old gardener cap back on [his]500-the old gardener bald head and stared at [her]38-mary a minute .

" Art tha ' [th ' little wench from [India]2-india]1991-th ' little wench from india ? "[500-the old gardener] [he]500-the old gardener asked .

[Mary]38-mary nodded .
