" Then no wonder tha'rt lonely . Tha'lt be lonlier before [tha]1992-tha 's done , "[500-the old gardener] [he]500-the old gardener said .

[He]500-the old gardener began to dig again , driving [his]500-the old gardener spade deep into the rich black garden soil while [the robin]495-the robin hopped about very busily employed .

" What is [your]500-the old gardener name ? "[38-mary] [Mary]38-mary inquired .

[He]500-the old gardener stood up to answer [her]38-mary .

" [Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff , "[500-the old gardener] [he]500-the old gardener answered , and then [he]500-the old gardener added with a surly chuckle , " [I]500-the old gardener 'm lonely [mysel]500-the old gardener ' except when [he]500-the old gardener 's with [me]500-the old gardener , "[500-the old gardener] and [he]500-the old gardener jerked [his]500-the old gardener thumb toward [the robin]495-the robin . " [He]500-the old gardener 's [[th]1993-th ' only friend [I]500-the old gardener 've got]1994-th ' only friend i 've got . "[500-the old gardener]

" [I]38-mary have [no friends]1995-no friends at all , "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary . " [I]38-mary never had . [My]38-mary Ayah did n't like [me]38-mary and [I]38-mary never played with [any one]189-any one . "[38-mary]

It is a Yorkshire habit to say what [you]503-you think with blunt frankness , and [old Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff was [a Yorkshire moor man]504-a yorkshire moor man .

" Tha ' an ' [me]57-ben weatherstaff are a good bit alike , "[57-ben weatherstaff] [he]57-ben weatherstaff said . " [We]1997-we was wove out of th ' same cloth . [We]1997-we 're neither of [us]1997-we good lookin ' an ' [we]1997-we 're both of [us]1997-we as sour as [we]1997-we look . [We]1997-we 've got the same nasty tempers , both of [us]1997-we , [I]57-ben weatherstaff 'll warrant . "[57-ben weatherstaff]

This was plain speaking , and [Mary Lennox]38-mary had never heard the truth about [herself]38-mary in [her]38-mary life . [Native servants]324-native servants always salaamed and submitted to [you]503-you , whatever [you]503-you did . [She]38-mary had never thought much about [her]38-mary looks , but [she]38-mary wondered if [she]38-mary was as unattractive as [Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff and [she]38-mary also wondered if [she]38-mary looked as sour as [he]57-ben weatherstaff had looked before the robin came . [She]38-mary actually began to wonder also if [she]38-mary was " nasty tempered . "[38-mary] [She]38-mary felt uncomfortable .

Suddenly a clear rippling little sound broke out near [her]38-mary and [she]38-mary turned round . [She]38-mary was standing a few feet from a young apple - tree and the robin had flown on to one of its branches and had burst out into a scrap of a song . [Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff laughed outright .

" What did [he]57-ben weatherstaff do that for ? "[38-mary] asked [Mary]38-mary .

" [He]57-ben weatherstaff 's made up [his]57-ben weatherstaff mind to make friends with [thee]38-mary , "[57-ben weatherstaff] replied [Ben]57-ben weatherstaff . " Dang [me]57-ben weatherstaff if [he]57-ben weatherstaff has n't took a fancy to [thee]38-mary . "[57-ben weatherstaff]

" To [me]38-mary ? "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary , and [she]38-mary moved toward the little tree softly and looked up .

" Would [you]57-ben weatherstaff make friends with [me]38-mary ? "[38-mary] [she]38-mary said to [the robin]495-the robin just as if [she]38-mary was speaking to [a person]483-a person . " Would [you]57-ben weatherstaff ? "[38-mary] And [she]38-mary did not say it either in [her]38-mary hard little voice or in [her]38-mary imperious Indian voice , but in a tone so soft and eager and coaxing that [Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff was as surprised as [she]38-mary had been when [she]38-mary heard [him]57-ben weatherstaff whistle .

" Why , "[57-ben weatherstaff] [he]57-ben weatherstaff cried out , " [tha]1998-tha [']1998-tha said that as nice an ' human as if [tha]1998-tha ' was [a real child]1999-a real child instead of [a sharp old woman]2000-a sharp old woman . [Tha]58-tha ' said it almost like [Dickon]54-dickon talks to [his]54-dickon wild things on [th ' moor]1874-th ' moor . "[57-ben weatherstaff]

" Do [you]57-ben weatherstaff know [Dickon]54-dickon ? "[38-mary] [Mary]38-mary asked , turning round rather in a hurry .

" [Everybody]185-everybody knows [him]54-dickon . [Dickon]54-dickon 's wanderin ' about everywhere . [Th]1998-tha ' very blackberries an ' heather - bells knows [him]54-dickon . [I]57-ben weatherstaff warrant [th ' foxes]2003-th ' foxes shows [him]54-dickon where [their]2003-th ' foxes cubs lies an ' [th ' skylarks]2004-th ' skylarks does n't hide [their]2003-th ' foxes nests from [him]54-dickon . "[57-ben weatherstaff]

[Mary]38-mary would have liked to ask some more questions . [She]38-mary was almost as curious about [Dickon]54-dickon as [she]38-mary was about [the deserted garden]476-the deserted garden . But just that moment the robin , who had ended [his]54-dickon song , gave a little shake of [his]54-dickon wings , spread them and flew away . [He]54-dickon had made [his]54-dickon visit and had other things to do .

" [He]54-dickon has flown over the wall ! "[38-mary] [Mary]38-mary cried out , watching [him]54-dickon . " [He]54-dickon has flown into [the orchard]466-the orchard [he]54-dickon has flown across the other wall into [the garden]146-the garden where there is no door ! "[38-mary]

" [He]54-dickon lives [there]2007-there , "[57-ben weatherstaff] said [old Ben]57-ben weatherstaff . " [He]54-dickon came out o ' th ' egg [there]2007-there . If [he]54-dickon 's courtin ' , [he]54-dickon 's makin ' up to [some young madam of a robin that lives among th ' old rose - trees [there]2007-there]2009-some young madam of a robin that lives among th ' old rose - trees there . "[57-ben weatherstaff]

" Rose - trees , "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary . " Are there rose - trees ? "[38-mary]

[Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff took up [his]57-ben weatherstaff spade again and began to dig .

" There was ten year ' ago , "[57-ben weatherstaff] [he]57-ben weatherstaff mumbled .

" [I]38-mary should like to see them , "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary . " Where is the green door ? There must be a door somewhere . "[38-mary]

[Ben]57-ben weatherstaff drove [his]57-ben weatherstaff spade deep and looked as uncompanionable as [he]57-ben weatherstaff had looked when [she]38-mary first saw [him]57-ben weatherstaff .

" There was ten year ' ago , but there is n't now , "[57-ben weatherstaff] [he]57-ben weatherstaff said .

" No door ! "[38-mary] cried [Mary]38-mary . " There must be . "[38-mary] " None as [any one]189-any one can find , an ' none as is [any one]189-any one 's business . Do n't [you]2013-you be [a meddlesome wench]2014-a meddlesome wench an ' poke [your]2013-you nose where it 's no cause to go . Here , [I]57-ben weatherstaff must go on with [my]57-ben weatherstaff work . Get [you]2013-you gone an ' play [you]2013-you . [I]57-ben weatherstaff 've no more time . "[57-ben weatherstaff]

And [he]57-ben weatherstaff actually stopped digging , threw [his]57-ben weatherstaff spade over [his]57-ben weatherstaff shoulder and walked off , without even glancing at [her]38-mary or saying good - by .

CHAPTER V

THE CRY IN [THE CORRIDOR]10-the corridor

At first each day which passed by for [Mary Lennox]38-mary was exactly like the others . Every morning [she]38-mary awoke in [[her]38-mary tapestried room]509-her tapestried room and found [Martha]50-martha kneeling upon the hearth building [her]50-martha fire ; every morning [she]50-martha ate [her]50-martha breakfast in [the nursery]173-the nursery which had nothing amusing in it ; and after each breakfast [she]50-martha gazed out of the window across to [the huge moor]511-the huge moor which seemed to spread out on all sides and climb up to the sky , and after [she]50-martha had stared for a while [she]50-martha realized that if [she]50-martha did not go out [she]50-martha would have to stay in and do nothing and so [she]50-martha went out . [She]50-martha did not know that this was the best thing [she]50-martha could have done , and [she]50-martha did not know that , when [she]50-martha began to walk quickly or even run along [the paths]512-the paths and down [the avenue]513-the avenue , [she]50-martha was stirring [her]50-martha slow blood and making [herself]50-martha stronger by fighting with the wind which swept down from [the moor]1835-the moor . [She]50-martha ran only to make [herself]50-martha warm , and [she]50-martha hated the wind which rushed at [her]50-martha face and roared and held [her]50-martha back as if it were some giant [she]50-martha could not see . But the big breaths of rough fresh air blown over the heather filled [her]50-martha lungs with something which was good for [her]50-martha whole thin body and whipped some red color into [her]50-martha cheeks and brightened [her]50-martha dull eyes when [she]50-martha did not know anything about it .

But after a few days spent almost entirely out of doors [she]50-martha wakened one morning knowing what it was to be hungry , and when [she]50-martha sat down to [her]50-martha breakfast [she]50-martha did not glance disdainfully at [her]50-martha porridge and push it away , but took up [her]50-martha spoon and began to eat it and went on eating it until [her]50-martha bowl was empty .

" Tha ' got on well enough with that this mornin ' , did n't tha ' ? "[50-martha] said [Martha]50-martha .

" It tastes nice today , "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary , feeling a little surprised [her]38-mary self .

" It 's th ' air of [th ' moor]1874-th ' moor that 's givin ' [thee]50-martha stomach for tha ' victuals , "[50-martha] answered [Martha]50-martha . " It 's lucky for [thee]50-martha that tha 's got victuals as well as appetite . There 's been twelve in [[our]2016-our cottage]2017-our cottage as had [th]50-martha ' stomach an ' nothin' to put in it . [You]50-martha go on playin ' [you]50-martha out o ' doors every day an ' [you]50-martha 'll get some flesh on [your]50-martha bones an ' [you]50-martha wo n't be so yeller . "[50-martha]

" [I]38-mary do n't play , "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary . " [I]38-mary have nothing to play with . "[38-mary]

" Nothin' to play with ! "[50-martha] exclaimed [Martha]50-martha . " [[Our]2016-our children]1937-our children plays with sticks and stones . [They]1937-our children just runs about an ' shouts an ' looks at things . "[50-martha] [Mary]38-mary did not shout , but [she]38-mary looked at things . There was nothing else to do . [She]38-mary walked round and round [the gardens]439-the gardens and wandered about [the paths in [the park]369-the park]516-the paths in the park . Sometimes [she]38-mary looked for [Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff , but though several times [she]38-mary saw [him]57-ben weatherstaff at work [he]57-ben weatherstaff was too busy to look at [her]38-mary or was too surly . Once when [she]38-mary was walking toward [him]57-ben weatherstaff [he]57-ben weatherstaff picked up [his]57-ben weatherstaff spade and turned away as if [he]57-ben weatherstaff did it on purpose .

One place [she]38-mary went to oftener than to any other . It was the long walk outside [the gardens]439-the gardens with the walls round [them]519-it . There were bare flower - beds on either side of [it]519-it and against the walls ivy grew thickly . There was one part of the wall where the creeping dark green leaves were more bushy than elsewhere . It seemed as if for a long time that part had been neglected . The rest of [it]519-it had been clipped and made to look neat , but at this lower end of the walk it had not been trimmed at all .

A few days after [she]38-mary had talked to [Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff , [Mary]38-mary stopped to notice this and wondered why it was so . [She]38-mary had just paused and was looking up at a long spray of ivy swinging in the wind when [she]38-mary saw a gleam of scarlet and heard a brilliant chirp , and there , on the top of the wall , forward perched [Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff 's robin redbreast , tilting forward to look at [her]38-mary with [his]57-ben weatherstaff small head on one side .

" Oh ! "[38-mary] [she]38-mary cried out , " is it [you]57-ben weatherstaff is it [you]57-ben weatherstaff ? "[38-mary] And it did not seem at all queer to [her]38-mary that [she]38-mary spoke to [him]57-ben weatherstaff as if [she]38-mary were sure that [he]57-ben weatherstaff would understand and answer [her]38-mary .

[He]57-ben weatherstaff did answer . [He]57-ben weatherstaff twittered and chirped and hopped along the wall as if [he]57-ben weatherstaff were telling [her]38-mary all sorts of things . It seemed to [Mistress Mary]38-mary as if [she]38-mary understood [him]57-ben weatherstaff , too , though [he]57-ben weatherstaff was not speaking in words . It was as if [he]57-ben weatherstaff said :

" Good morning ! Is n't the wind nice ? Is n't the sun nice ? Is n't everything nice ? Let [us]2019-us both chirp and hop and twitter . Come on ! Come on ! "[57-ben weatherstaff]

[Mary]38-mary began to laugh , and as [he]57-ben weatherstaff hopped and took little flights along the wall [she]38-mary ran after [him]57-ben weatherstaff . Poor little thin , sallow , ugly [Mary]38-mary [she]38-mary actually looked almost pretty for a moment .

" [I]38-mary like [you]57-ben weatherstaff ! [I]38-mary like [you]57-ben weatherstaff ! "[38-mary] [she]38-mary cried out , pattering down the walk ; and [she]38-mary chirped and tried to whistle , which last [she]38-mary did not know how to do in the least . But [the robin]495-the robin seemed to be quite satisfied and chirped and whistled back at [her]38-mary . At last [he]57-ben weatherstaff spread [his]57-ben weatherstaff wings and made a darting flight to the top of a tree , where [he]57-ben weatherstaff perched and sang loudly . That reminded [Mary]38-mary of the first time [she]38-mary had seen [him]57-ben weatherstaff . [He]57-ben weatherstaff had been swinging on a tree - top then and [she]38-mary had been standing in [the orchard]466-the orchard . Now [she]38-mary was on the other side of [the orchard]466-the orchard and standing in the path outside a wall much lower down and there was the same tree inside .

" It 's in [the garden]146-the garden [no one]145-no one can go into , "[38-mary] [she]38-mary said to [herself]38-mary . " It 's [the garden]146-the garden without a door . [He]57-ben weatherstaff lives in [there]2007-there . How [I]38-mary wish [I]38-mary could see what it is like ! "[38-mary]

[She]38-mary ran up [the walk]523-the walk to the green door [she]38-mary had entered the first morning . Then [she]38-mary ran down [the path]459-the path through the other door and then into [the orchard]466-the orchard , and when [she]38-mary stood and looked up there was the tree on the other side of the wall , and there was the robin just finishing [his]526-his song and , beginning to preen [his]526-his feathers with [his]526-his beak .

" [It]466-the orchard is [the garden]146-the garden , "[38-mary] [she]38-mary said . " [I]38-mary am sure it is . "[38-mary]

[She]38-mary walked round and looked closely at that side of the orchard wall , but [she]38-mary only found what [she]38-mary had found before that there was no door in [it]527-it . Then [she]38-mary ran through [the kitchen - gardens]451-the kitchen - gardens again and out into [the walk]523-the walk outside the long ivy - covered wall , and [she]38-mary walked to the end of [it]527-it and looked at [it]527-it , but there was no door ; and then [she]38-mary walked to the other end , looking again , but there was no door .

" It 's very queer , "[38-mary] [she]38-mary said . " [Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff said there was no door and there is no door . But there must have been one ten years ago , because [Mr. Craven]41-mr. craven buried the key . "[38-mary]

This gave [her]38-mary so much to think of that [she]38-mary began to be quite interested and feel that [she]38-mary was not sorry that [she]38-mary had come to [Misselthwaite Manor]1-misselthwaite manor . In [India]2-india [she]38-mary had always felt hot and too languid to care much about anything . The fact was that the fresh wind from [the moor]1835-the moor had begun to blow the cobwebs out of [her]38-mary young brain and to waken [her]38-mary up a little .

[She]38-mary stayed out of doors nearly all day , and when [she]38-mary sat down to [her]38-mary supper at night [she]38-mary felt hungry and drowsy and comfortable . [She]38-mary did not feel cross when [Martha]50-martha chattered away . [She]38-mary felt as if [she]38-mary rather liked to hear [her]50-martha , and at last [she]38-mary thought [she]38-mary would ask [her]50-martha a question . [She]38-mary asked it after [she]38-mary had finished [her]38-mary supper and had sat down on the hearth - rug before the fire .

" Why did [Mr. Craven]41-mr. craven hate [the garden]146-the garden ? "[38-mary] [she]38-mary said .

[She]38-mary had made [Martha]50-martha stay with [her]38-mary and [Martha]50-martha had not objected at all . [She]50-martha was very young , and used to [a crowded cottage full of [brothers]413-brothers and [sisters]425-sisters]531-a crowded cottage full of brothers and sisters , and [she]50-martha found it dull in [the great servants ' hall]534-the great servants ' hall downstairs where [the footman]535-the footman and [upper - housemaids]536-upper - housemaids made fun of [her]50-martha Yorkshire speech and looked upon [her]50-martha as a common little thing , and sat and whispered among [themselves]537-themselves . [Martha]50-martha liked to talk , and [the strange child who had lived in [India]2-india , and been waited upon by " [blacks]2027-blacks]2026-the strange child who had lived in india , and been waited upon by " blacks , "[50-martha] was novelty enough to attract [her]50-martha .

[She]50-martha sat down on the hearth [herself]50-martha without waiting to be asked .

" Art tha ' thinkin ' about [that garden]2028-that garden yet ? "[50-martha] [she]50-martha said . " [I]50-martha knew [tha]2029-tha ' would . That was just the way with [me]50-martha when [I]50-martha first heard about it . "[50-martha]

" Why did [he]2030-he hate it ? "[38-mary] [Mary]38-mary persisted .

[Martha]50-martha tucked [her]50-martha feet under [her]50-martha and made [herself]50-martha quite comfortable .

" Listen to th ' wind wutherin ' round [the house]166-the house , "[50-martha] [she]50-martha said . " [You]50-martha could bare stand up on [the moor]1835-the moor if [you]50-martha was out on it tonight . "[50-martha]

[Mary]38-mary did not know what " wutherin ' "[38-mary] meant until [she]38-mary listened , and then [she]38-mary understood . It must mean that hollow shuddering sort of roar which rushed round and round [the house]166-the house as if [the giant no one]539-the giant no one could see were buffeting it and beating at the walls and windows to try to break in . But [one]406-one knew [he]541-he could not get in , and somehow it made [one]406-one feel very safe and warm inside [a room with a red coal fire]543-a room with a red coal fire .

" But why did [he]541-he hate it so ? "[50-martha] [she]50-martha asked , after [she]50-martha had listened . [She]50-martha intended to know if [Martha]50-martha did .

Then [Martha]50-martha gave up [her]50-martha store of knowledge .

" Mind , "[50-martha] [she]50-martha said , " [Mrs. Medlock]45-mrs. medlock said it 's not to be talked about . There 's lots o ' things in [this place]1962-this place that 's not to be talked over . That 's [Mr. Craven]41-mr. craven 's orders . [His]541-he troubles are [none servants]2034-none servants ' business , [he]541-he says . But for [th ' garden]2035-th ' garden [he]541-he would n't be like [he]541-he is . It was [[Mrs. Craven]59-mrs. craven 's garden]2036-mrs. craven 's garden that [she]59-mrs. craven had made when first [they]2037-they were married an ' [she]59-mrs. craven just loved it , an ' [they]2037-they used to ' tend the flowers [themselves]2037-they . An ' [none o ' [th ' gardeners]2039-th ' gardeners]2038-none o ' th ' gardeners was ever let to go in . [Him]541-he an ' [her]59-mrs. craven used to go in an ' shut th ' door an ' stay there hours an ' hours , readin ' and talkin ' . An ' [she]59-mrs. craven was just a bit of [a girl]2040-a girl an ' there was an old tree with a branch bent like a seat on it . An ' [she]59-mrs. craven made roses grow over it an ' [she]59-mrs. craven used to sit there . But one day when [she]59-mrs. craven was sittin ' there th ' branch broke an ' [she]59-mrs. craven fell on th ' ground an ' was hurt so bad that next day [she]59-mrs. craven died . [Th ' doctors]2041-th ' doctors thought [he]541-he 'd go out o ' [his]541-he mind an ' die , too . That 's why [he]541-he hates it . [No one]145-no one 's never gone in since , an ' [he]541-he wo n't let [any one]189-any one talk about it . "[50-martha]

[Mary]38-mary did not ask any more questions . [She]38-mary looked at the red fire and listened to the wind " wutherin ' . "[38-mary] It seemed to be " wutherin ' "[38-mary] louder than ever . At that moment a very good thing was happening to [her]38-mary . Four good things had happened to [her]38-mary , in fact , since [she]38-mary came to [Misselthwaite Manor]1-misselthwaite manor . [She]38-mary had felt as if [she]38-mary had understood [a robin]544-a robin and that [he]544-a robin had understood [her]38-mary ; [she]38-mary had run in the wind until [her]38-mary blood had grown warm ; [she]38-mary had been healthily hungry for the first time in [her]38-mary life ; and [she]38-mary had found out what it was to be sorry for [some one]151-some one .

But as [she]38-mary was listening to the wind [she]38-mary began to listen to something else . [She]38-mary did not know what it was , because at first [she]38-mary could scarcely distinguish it from the wind itself . It was a curious sound it seemed almost as if [a child]1768-a child were crying somewhere . Sometimes the wind sounded rather like [a child]1768-a child crying , but presently [Mistress Mary]38-mary felt quite sure this sound was inside [the house]166-the house , not outside it . It was far away , but it was inside . [She]38-mary turned round and looked at [Martha]50-martha .

" Do [you]50-martha hear [any one]189-any one crying ? "[38-mary] [she]38-mary said .

[Martha]50-martha suddenly looked confused .

" No , "[38-mary] [she]38-mary answered . " It 's th ' wind . Sometimes it sounds like as if [some one]151-some one was lost on th ' moor an ' wailin ' . It 's got all sorts o ' sounds . "[50-martha]

" But listen , "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary . " It 's in [the house]166-the house down one of [those long corridors]2047-those long corridors . "[38-mary]

And at that very moment a door must have been opened somewhere [downstairs]440-downstairs ; for a great rushing draft blew along [the passage]550-the passage and the door of [the room]201-the room [they]552-they sat in was blown open with a crash , and as [they]552-they both jumped to [their]552-they feet the light was blown out and the crying sound was swept down [the far corridor]553-the far corridor so that it was to be heard more plainly than ever .

" There ! "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary . " [I]38-mary told [you]50-martha so ! It is [some one]151-some one crying and it is n't [a grown - up person]435-a grown - up person . "[38-mary]

[Martha]50-martha ran and shut the door and turned the key , but before [she]50-martha did it [they]552-they both heard the sound of a door in [some far passage]554-some far passage shutting with a bang , and then everything was quiet , for even the wind ceased " wutherin ' "[38-mary] for a few moments .

" It was th ' wind , "[50-martha] said [Martha]50-martha stubbornly . " An ' if it was n't , it was [little Betty Butterworth]60-little betty butterworth , [th ' scullery - maid]2050-th ' scullery - maid . [She]60-little betty butterworth 's had th ' toothache all day . "[50-martha]

But something troubled and awkward in [her]38-mary manner made [Mistress Mary]38-mary stare very hard at [her]38-mary . [She]38-mary did not believe [she]38-mary was speaking the truth .

CHAPTER VI

" THERE WAS SOME ONE CRYING THERE WAS ! "[38-mary]

The next day the rain poured down in torrents again , and when [Mary]38-mary looked out of [her]38-mary window [the moor]1835-the moor was almost hidden by gray mist and cloud . There could be no going out today .

" What do [you]50-martha do in [[your]50-martha cottage]2051-your cottage when it rains like this ? "[38-mary] [she]38-mary asked [Martha]50-martha .

" Try to keep from under each other 's feet mostly , "[50-martha] [Martha]50-martha answered . " Eh ! there does seem a lot of [us]552-they then . [Mother]53-mother 's [a good - tempered woman]2052-a good - tempered woman but [she]53-mother gets fair moithered . [The biggest ones]2053-the biggest ones goes out in [th ' cow - shed]2054-th ' cow - shed and plays there . [Dickon]54-dickon [he]54-dickon does n't mind th ' wet . [He]54-dickon goes out just th ' same as if th ' sun was shinin ' . [He]54-dickon says [he]54-dickon sees things on rainy days as does n't show when it 's fair weather . [He]54-dickon once found a little fox cub half drowned in its hole and [he]54-dickon brought it [home]1785-home in th ' bosom of [his]54-dickon shirt to keep [it]2056-it warm . [[Its]2056-it mother]1932-its mother had been killed nearby an ' [th ' hole]2058-th ' hole was swum out an ' th ' rest o ' th ' litter was dead . [He]54-dickon 's got it at [home]1785-home now . [He]54-dickon found [a half - drowned young crow]2060-a half - drowned young crow another time an ' [he]54-dickon brought it [home]1785-home , too , an ' tamed [it]2060-a half - drowned young crow . [It]2060-a half - drowned young crow 's named [Soot]61-soot because it 's so black , an ' it hops an ' flies about with [him]54-dickon everywhere . "[50-martha]

The time had come when [Mary]38-mary had forgotten to resent [Martha]50-martha 's familiar talk . [She]38-mary had even begun to find it interesting and to be sorry when [she]38-mary stopped or went away . The stories [she]38-mary had been told by [her]38-mary Ayah when [she]38-mary lived in [India]2-india had been quite unlike those [Martha]50-martha had to tell about [the moorland cottage which held [fourteen people who lived in [four little rooms]558-four little rooms and never had quite enough to eat]557-fourteen people who lived in four little rooms and never had quite enough to eat]556-the moorland cottage which held fourteen people who lived in four little rooms and never had quite enough to eat . [The children]1803-the children seemed to tumble about and amuse [themselves]1803-the children like a litter of rough , good - natured collie puppies . [Mary]38-mary was most attracted by [the mother]560-the mother and [Dickon]54-dickon . When [Martha]50-martha told stories of what " [mother]224-mother "[50-martha] said or did they always sounded comfortable .

" If [I]38-mary had a raven or a fox cub [I]38-mary could play with it , "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary . " But [I]38-mary have nothing . "[38-mary]

[Martha]50-martha looked perplexed .

" Can tha ' knit ? "[50-martha] [she]50-martha asked .

" No , "[38-mary] answered [Mary]38-mary .

" Can tha ' sew ? "[50-martha]

" No . "[50-martha]

" Can [tha]2063-tha ' read ? "[50-martha]

" Yes . "[50-martha]

" Then why does n't [tha]2063-tha , read somethin' , or learn a bit o ' spellin ' ? Tha'st old enough to be learnin ' [thy]2063-tha book a good bit now . "[50-martha]

" [I]38-mary have n't any books , "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary . " Those [I]38-mary had were left in [India]2-india . "[38-mary]

" That 's a pity , "[50-martha] said [Martha]50-martha . " If [Mrs. Medlock'd]62-mrs. medlock'd let [thee]50-martha go into [th ' library]2064-th ' library , there 's thousands o ' books there . "[50-martha]

[Mary]38-mary did not ask where [the library]561-the library was , because [she]38-mary was suddenly inspired by a new idea . [She]38-mary made up [her]38-mary mind to go and find it [herself]38-mary . [She]38-mary was not troubled about [Mrs. Medlock]45-mrs. medlock . [Mrs. Medlock]45-mrs. medlock seemed always to be in [[her]45-mrs. medlock comfortable housekeeper 's sitting - room [downstairs]440-downstairs]562-her comfortable housekeeper 's sitting - room downstairs . In [this queer place]564-this queer place [one]406-one scarcely ever saw [any one]189-any one at all . In fact , there was [no one]145-no one to see but [the servants]162-the servants , and when [[their]162-the servants master]569-their master was away [they]162-the servants lived a luxurious life below stairs , where there was [a huge kitchen hung about with shining brass]570-a huge kitchen hung about with shining brass and pewter , and [a large servants ' hall]571-a large servants ' hall where there were four or five abundant meals eaten every day , and where a great deal of lively romping went on when [Mrs. Medlock]45-mrs. medlock was out of the way .

[Mary]38-mary 's meals were served regularly , and [Martha]50-martha waited on [her]38-mary , but [no one]145-no one troubled [themselves]162-the servants about [her]38-mary in the least . [Mrs. Medlock]45-mrs. medlock came and looked at [her]38-mary every day or two , but [no one]145-no one inquired what [she]38-mary did or told [her]38-mary what to do . [She]38-mary supposed that perhaps this was the English way of treating [children]1816-children . In [India]2-india [she]38-mary had always been attended by [[her]38-mary Ayah]132-her ayah , who had followed [her]38-mary about and waited on [her]38-mary , hand and foot . [She]38-mary had often been tired of [her]38-mary company . Now [she]38-mary was followed by [nobody]175-nobody and was learning to dress [herself]38-mary because [Martha]50-martha looked as though [she]50-martha thought [she]50-martha was silly and stupid when [she]50-martha wanted to have things handed to [her]50-martha and put on .

" Has n't [tha]2065-tha ' got good sense ? "[38-mary] [she]38-mary said once , when [Mary]38-mary had stood waiting for [her]38-mary to put on [her]38-mary gloves for [her]38-mary . " [[Our]2066-our [Susan Ann]38-mary]2067-our susan ann is twice as sharp as [thee]2065-tha an ' [she]38-mary 's only four year ' old . Sometimes tha ' looks fair soft in th ' head . "[38-mary]

[Mary]38-mary had worn [her]38-mary contrary scowl for an hour after that , but it made [her]38-mary think several entirely new things .

[She]38-mary stood at the window for about ten minutes this morning after [Martha]50-martha had swept up the hearth for the last time and gone [downstairs]440-downstairs . [She]38-mary was thinking over the new idea which had come to [her]38-mary when [she]38-mary heard of [the library]561-the library . [She]38-mary did not care very much about [the library itself]579-the library itself , because [she]38-mary had read very few books ; but to hear of [it]579-the library itself brought back to [her]38-mary mind [the hundred rooms with closed doors]580-the hundred rooms with closed doors . [She]38-mary wondered if [they]580-the hundred rooms with closed doors were all really locked and what [she]38-mary would find if [she]38-mary could get into any of [them]580-the hundred rooms with closed doors . Were there a hundred really ? Why should n't [she]38-mary go and see how many doors [she]38-mary could count ? It would be something to do on this morning when [she]38-mary could not go out . [She]38-mary had never been taught to ask permission to do things , and [she]38-mary knew nothing at all about authority , so [she]38-mary would not have thought it necessary to ask [Mrs. Medlock]45-mrs. medlock if [she]45-mrs. medlock might walk about [the house]166-the house , even if [she]45-mrs. medlock had seen [her]45-mrs. medlock .

[She]38-mary opened the door of [the room]201-the room and went into [the corridor]583-the corridor , and then [she]38-mary began [her]38-mary wanderings . It was [a long corridor]383-a long corridor and [it]383-a long corridor branched into [other corridors]585-other corridors and it led [her]38-mary up [short flights of steps]586-short flights of steps which mounted to others again . There were doors and doors , and there were pictures on the walls . Sometimes they were pictures of dark , curious landscapes , but oftenest they were portraits of [men]205-men and [women in queer , grand costumes made of satin and velvet]588-women in queer , grand costumes made of satin and velvet . [She]38-mary found [herself]38-mary in [one long gallery whose walls were covered with these portraits]589-one long gallery whose walls were covered with these portraits . [She]38-mary had never thought there could be so many in [any house]590-any house . [She]38-mary walked slowly down [this place]1962-this place and stared at the faces which also seemed to stare at [her]38-mary . [She]38-mary felt as if [they]592-they were wondering what [a little girl from [India]2-india]593-a little girl from india was doing in [[their]592-they house]594-their house . Some were pictures of [[children]1816-children little girls in thick satin frocks which reached to [their]596-children little girls in thick satin frocks which reached to their feet and stood out about them feet and stood out about [them]596-children little girls in thick satin frocks which reached to their feet and stood out about them]596-children little girls in thick satin frocks which reached to their feet and stood out about them , and [boys with puffed sleeves and lace collars and long hair]597-boys with puffed sleeves and lace collars and long hair , or with big ruffs around [their]597-boys with puffed sleeves and lace collars and long hair necks . [She]38-mary always stopped to look at [the children]1803-the children , and wonder what [their]1803-the children names were , and where [they]1803-the children had gone , and why [they]1803-the children wore such odd clothes . There was [a stiff , plain little girl]599-a stiff , plain little girl rather like [herself]599-a stiff , plain little girl . [She]599-a stiff , plain little girl wore a green brocade dress and held a green parrot on [her]599-a stiff , plain little girl finger . [Her]599-a stiff , plain little girl eyes had a sharp , curious look .

" Where do [you]599-a stiff , plain little girl live now ? "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary aloud to [her]599-a stiff , plain little girl . " [I]38-mary wish [you]599-a stiff , plain little girl were [here]1771-here . "[38-mary]

Surely [no other little girl]600-no other little girl ever spent such a queer morning . It seemed as if there was no one in all [the huge rambling house]601-the huge rambling house but [[her]38-mary own small self]602-her own small self , wandering about upstairs and down , through [narrow passages]603-narrow passages and [wide ones]604-wide ones , where it seemed to [her]38-mary that [no one]145-no one but [herself]38-mary had ever walked . Since so [many rooms]606-many rooms had been built , [people]167-people must have lived in [them]606-many rooms , but it all seemed so empty that [she]38-mary could not quite believe it true .

It was not until [she]38-mary climbed to [the second floor]608-the second floor that [she]38-mary thought of turning the handle of a door . All the doors were shut , as [Mrs. Medlock]45-mrs. medlock had said [they]609-they were , but at last [she]38-mary put [her]38-mary hand on the handle of one of them and turned it . [She]38-mary was almost frightened for a moment when [she]38-mary felt that it turned without difficulty and that when [she]38-mary pushed upon the door itself it slowly and heavily opened . It was a massive door and opened into [a big bedroom]610-a big bedroom . There were embroidered hangings on the wall , and inlaid furniture such as [she]38-mary had seen in [India]2-india stood about [the room]201-the room . A broad window with leaded panes looked out upon [the moor]1835-the moor ; and over the mantel was another portrait of [the stiff , plain little girl]613-the stiff , plain little girl who seemed to stare at [her]38-mary more curiously than ever .

" Perhaps [she]613-the stiff , plain little girl slept [here]1771-here once , "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary . " [She]613-the stiff , plain little girl stares at [me]38-mary so that [she]613-the stiff , plain little girl makes [me]38-mary feel queer . "[38-mary]

After that [she]38-mary opened more doors and more . [She]38-mary saw so [many rooms]606-many rooms that [she]38-mary became quite tired and began to think that there must be a hundred , though [she]38-mary had not counted [them]606-many rooms . In all of them there were old pictures or old tapestries with strange scenes worked on them . There were curious pieces of furniture and curious ornaments in nearly all of them .

In [one room]615-one room , which looked like [[a lady]616-a lady 's sitting - room]617-a lady 's sitting - room , the hangings were all embroidered velvet , and in a cabinet were about a hundred little elephants made of ivory . They were of different sizes , and some had [their]618-their mahouts or palanquins on [their]618-their backs . Some were much bigger than the others and some were so tiny that they seemed only babies . [Mary]38-mary had seen carved ivory in [India]2-india and [she]38-mary knew all about elephants . [She]38-mary opened the door of the cabinet and stood on a footstool and played with these for quite a long time . When [she]38-mary got tired [she]38-mary set the elephants in order and shut the door of the cabinet .

In all [her]38-mary wanderings through [the long corridors]619-the long corridors and [the empty rooms]620-the empty rooms , [she]38-mary had seen nothing alive ; but in [this room]1872-this room [she]38-mary saw something . Just after [she]38-mary had closed the cabinet door [she]38-mary heard a tiny rustling sound . It made [her]38-mary jump and look around at the sofa by the fireplace , from which it seemed to come . In the corner of the sofa there was a cushion , and in the velvet which covered it there was a hole , and out of the hole peeped a tiny head with a pair of frightened eyes in it .

[Mary]38-mary crept softly across [the room]201-the room to look . The bright eyes belonged to a little gray mouse , and the mouse had eaten a hole into the cushion and made a comfortable nest there . Six baby mice were cuddled up asleep near [her]38-mary . If there was [no one else]623-no one else alive in [the hundred rooms]624-the hundred rooms there were [seven mice who did not look lonely at all]625-seven mice who did not look lonely at all .

" If [they]625-seven mice who did not look lonely at all would n't be so frightened [I]38-mary would take [them]625-seven mice who did not look lonely at all back with [me]38-mary , "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary .

[She]38-mary had wandered about long enough to feel too tired to wander any farther , and [she]38-mary turned back . Two or three times [she]38-mary lost [her]38-mary way by turning down [the wrong corridor]626-the wrong corridor and was obliged to ramble up and down until [she]38-mary found [the right one]627-the right one ; but at last [she]38-mary reached [her]38-mary own floor again , though [she]38-mary was some distance from [[her]38-mary own room]628-her own room and did not know exactly where [she]38-mary was .

" [I]38-mary believe [I]38-mary have taken a wrong turning again , "[38-mary] [she]38-mary said , standing still at what seemed the end of [a short passage with tapestry on the wall]629-a short passage with tapestry on the wall . " [I]38-mary do n't know which way to go . How still everything is ! "[38-mary]

It was while [she]38-mary was standing [here]1771-here and just after [she]38-mary had said this that the stillness was broken by a sound . It was another cry , but not quite like the one [she]38-mary had heard last night ; it was only a short one , a fretful childish whine muffled by passing through walls .

" It 's nearer than it was , "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary , [her]38-mary heart beating rather faster . " And it is crying . "[38-mary]

[She]38-mary put [her]38-mary hand accidentally upon the tapestry near [her]38-mary , and then sprang back , feeling quite startled . The tapestry was the covering of a door which fell open and showed [her]38-mary that there was another part of the corridor behind [it]631-it , and [Mrs. Medlock]45-mrs. medlock was coming up [it]631-it with [her]45-mrs. medlock bunch of keys in [her]45-mrs. medlock hand and a very cross look on [her]45-mrs. medlock face .

" What are [you]38-mary doing here ? "[45-mrs. medlock] [she]45-mrs. medlock said , and [she]45-mrs. medlock took [Mary]38-mary by the arm and pulled [her]38-mary away . " What did [I]45-mrs. medlock tell [you]38-mary ? "[45-mrs. medlock]

" [I]38-mary turned round the wrong corner , "[38-mary] explained [Mary]38-mary . " [I]38-mary did n't know which way to go and [I]38-mary heard [some one]151-some one crying . "[38-mary] [She]38-mary quite hated [Mrs. Medlock]45-mrs. medlock at the moment , but [she]38-mary hated [her]45-mrs. medlock more the next .

" [You]38-mary did n't hear anything of the sort , "[632-the housekeeper] said [the housekeeper]632-the housekeeper . " [You]38-mary come along back to [[your]38-mary own nursery]2071-your own nursery or [I]632-the housekeeper 'll box [your]38-mary ears . "[632-the housekeeper]

And [she]632-the housekeeper took [her]38-mary by the arm and half pushed , half pulled [her]38-mary up [one passage]633-one passage and down another until [she]632-the housekeeper pushed [her]38-mary in at the door of [[her]632-the housekeeper own room]628-her own room .

" Now , "[632-the housekeeper] [she]632-the housekeeper said , " [you]38-mary stay where [you]38-mary 're told to stay or [you]38-mary 'll find [yourself]38-mary locked up . [The master]2072-the master had better get [you]38-mary [a governess]2073-a governess , same as [he]2072-the master said [he]2072-the master would . [You]38-mary 're one that needs [some one]151-some one to look sharp after [you]38-mary . [I]632-the housekeeper 've got enough to do . "[632-the housekeeper]

[She]632-the housekeeper went out of [the room]201-the room and slammed the door after [her]632-the housekeeper , and [Mary]38-mary went and sat on the hearth - rug , pale with rage . [She]38-mary did not cry , but ground [her]38-mary teeth .

" There was [some one crying there]2075-some one crying there was there was ! "[38-mary] [she]38-mary said to [herself]38-mary .

[She]38-mary had heard it twice now , and sometime [she]38-mary would find out . [She]38-mary had found out a great deal this morning . [She]38-mary felt as if [she]38-mary had been on a long journey , and at any rate [she]38-mary had had something to amuse [her]38-mary all the time , and [she]38-mary had played with the ivory elephants and had seen the gray mouse and its babies in [their]636-their nest in the velvet cushion .

CHAPTER VII

THE KEY TO [THE GARDEN]146-the garden

Two days after this , when [Mary]38-mary opened [her]38-mary eyes [she]38-mary sat upright in bed immediately , and called to [Martha]50-martha .

" Look at [the moor]1835-the moor ! Look at [the moor]1835-the moor ! "[38-mary]

The rainstorm had ended and the gray mist and clouds had been swept away in the night by the wind . The wind itself had ceased and a brilliant , deep blue sky arched high over [the moorland]638-the moorland . Never , never had [Mary]38-mary dreamed of a sky so blue . In [India]2-india skies were hot and blazing ; this was of a deep cool blue which almost seemed to sparkle like the waters of [some lovely bottomless lake]639-some lovely bottomless lake , and here and there , high , high in the arched blueness floated small clouds of snow - white fleece . [The far - reaching world of [the moor]1835-the moor]640-the far - reaching world of the moor itself looked softly blue instead of gloomy purple - black or awful dreary gray .

" Aye , "[50-martha] said [Martha]50-martha with a cheerful grin . " Th ' storm 's over for a bit . It does like this at this time o ' th ' year . It goes off in a night like it was pretendin ' it had never been [here]1771-here an ' never meant to come again . That 's because th ' springtime 's on its way . It 's a long way off yet , but it 's comin ' . "[50-martha]

" [I]38-mary thought perhaps it always rained or looked dark in [England]3-england , "[38-mary] [Mary]38-mary said .

" Eh ! no ! "[50-martha] said [Martha]50-martha , sitting up on [her]50-martha heels among [her]50-martha black lead brushes . " Nowt o ' th ' soart ! "[50-martha]

" What does that mean ? "[38-mary] asked [Mary]38-mary seriously . In [India]2-india [the natives]642-the natives spoke different dialects which [only a few people]643-only a few people understood , so [she]38-mary was not surprised when [Martha]50-martha used words [she]50-martha did not know .

[Martha]50-martha laughed as [she]50-martha had done the first morning .

" There now , "[38-mary] [she]38-mary said . " [I]50-martha 've talked broad [Yorkshire]50-martha again like [Mrs. Medlock]45-mrs. medlock said [I]50-martha must n't . ' Nowt o ' th ' soart ' means ' nothin'-of - the - sort , ' "[50-martha] slowly and carefully , " but it takes so long to say it . [Yorkshire]50-martha 's [th ' sunniest place on [earth]2080-earth]2079-th ' sunniest place on earth when it is sunny . [I]50-martha told [thee]2081-you tha'd like [th ' moor]1874-th ' moor after a bit . Just [you]2081-you wait till [you]2081-you see [th]2083-th ' gold - colored gorse blossoms an ' th ' blossoms o ' th ' broom , an ' th ' heather flowerin ' , all purple bells , an ' hundreds o ' butterflies flutterin ' an ' bees hummin ' an ' skylarks soarin ' up an ' singin ' . [You]2081-you 'll want to get out on it as sunrise an ' live out on it all day like [Dickon]54-dickon does . "[50-martha] " Could [I]38-mary ever get [there]2007-there ? "[38-mary] asked [Mary]38-mary wistfully , looking through [her]38-mary window at the far - off blue . It was so new and big and wonderful and such a heavenly color .

" [I]50-martha do n't know , "[50-martha] answered [Martha]50-martha . " [Tha]2085-tha 's never used [tha]2085-tha ' legs since [tha]2085-tha ' was born , it seems to [me]50-martha . Tha ' could n't walk five mile . It 's five mile to [[our]2086-our cottage]2017-our cottage . "[50-martha]

" [I]50-martha should like to see [[your]50-martha cottage]2051-your cottage . "[50-martha]

[Martha]50-martha stared at [her]50-martha a moment curiously before [she]50-martha took up [her]50-martha polishing brush and began to rub the grate again . [She]50-martha was thinking that the small plain face did not look quite as sour at this moment as it had done the first morning [she]50-martha saw it . [It]644-it looked just a trifle like [little Susan Ann]38-mary 's when [she]38-mary wanted something very much .

" [I]50-martha 'll ask [[my]50-martha mother]1897-my mother about it , "[50-martha] [she]50-martha said . " [She]1897-my mother 's one o ' [them]2090-them that nearly always sees a way to do things . It 's [my]50-martha day out today an ' [I]50-martha 'm goin' [home]1785-home . Eh ! [I]50-martha am glad . [Mrs. Medlock]45-mrs. medlock thinks a lot o ' [mother]224-mother . Perhaps [she]1897-my mother could talk to [her]1897-my mother . "[50-martha]

" [I]38-mary like [[your]38-mary mother]2093-your mother , "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary .

" [I]50-martha should think [tha]2094-tha ' did , "[50-martha] agreed [Martha]50-martha , polishing away .

" [I]38-mary 've never seen [her]2093-your mother , "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary .

" No , tha ' has n't , "[50-martha] replied [Martha]50-martha .

[She]50-martha sat up on [her]50-martha heels again and rubbed the end of [her]50-martha nose with the back of [her]50-martha hand as if puzzled for a moment , but [she]50-martha ended quite positively .

" Well , [she]2093-your mother 's that sensible an ' hard workin ' an ' goodnatured an ' clean that [no one]145-no one could help likin ' [her]2093-your mother whether [they]2096-they 'd seen [her]2093-your mother or not . When [I]50-martha 'm goin' [home]1785-home to [her]2093-your mother on [my]50-martha day out [I]50-martha just jump for joy when [I]50-martha 'm crossin ' [the moor]1835-the moor . "[50-martha]

" [I]38-mary like [Dickon]54-dickon , "[38-mary] added [Mary]38-mary . " And [I]38-mary 've never seen [him]54-dickon . "[38-mary]

" Well , "[50-martha] said [Martha]50-martha stoutly , " [I]50-martha 've told [thee]2099-thee that [th ' very birds]2100-th ' very birds likes [him]54-dickon an ' th ' rabbits an ' wild sheep an ' ponies , an ' [th ' foxes]2003-th ' foxes [themselves]2003-th ' foxes . [I]50-martha wonder , "[50-martha] staring at [her]50-martha reflectively , " what [Dickon]54-dickon would think of [thee]50-martha ? "[50-martha]

" [He]54-dickon would n't like [me]38-mary , "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary in [her]38-mary stiff , cold little way . " [No one]145-no one does . "[38-mary]

[Martha]50-martha looked reflective again .

" How does tha ' like [thysel]2103-thysel ' ? "[50-martha] [she]50-martha inquired , really quite as if [she]50-martha were curious to know .

[Mary]38-mary hesitated a moment and thought it over .

" Not at all really , "[38-mary] [she]38-mary answered . " But [I]38-mary never thought of that before . "[38-mary]

[Martha]50-martha grinned a little as if at some homely recollection .

" [Mother]224-mother said that to [me]50-martha once , "[50-martha] [she]50-martha said . " [She]224-mother was at [[her]224-mother wash - tub]2105-her wash - tub an ' [I]50-martha was in a bad temper an ' talkin ' ill of [folk]1939-folk , an ' [she]224-mother turns round on [me]50-martha an ' says : ' [Tha ' young vixen]2107-tha ' young vixen , tha ' ! There tha ' stands sayin ' [tha]2108-tha ' does n't like this one an ' [tha]2108-tha ' does n't like that one . How does [tha]2108-tha ' like [thysel]2109-thysel ' ? ' It made [me]50-martha laugh an ' it brought [me]50-martha to [my]50-martha senses in a minute . "[50-martha]

[She]50-martha went away in high spirits as soon as [she]50-martha had given [Mary]38-mary [her]38-mary breakfast . [She]50-martha was going to walk five miles across [the moor]1835-the moor to [the cottage]646-the cottage , and [she]50-martha was going to help [[her]50-martha mother]124-her mother with the washing and do the week 's baking and enjoy [herself]50-martha thoroughly .

[Mary]38-mary felt lonelier than ever when [she]38-mary knew [she]38-mary was no longer in [the house]166-the house . [She]38-mary went out into [the garden]146-the garden as quickly as possible , and the first thing [she]38-mary did was to run round and round [the fountain flower garden]650-the fountain flower garden ten times . [She]38-mary counted the times carefully and when [she]38-mary had finished [she]38-mary felt in better spirits . The sunshine made [the whole place]651-the whole place look different . The high , deep , blue sky arched over [Misselthwaite]5-misselthwaite as well as over [the moor]1835-the moor , and [she]38-mary kept lifting [her]38-mary face and looking up into it , trying to imagine what it would be like to lie down on one of the little snow - white clouds and float about . [She]38-mary went into [the first kitchen - garden]480-the first kitchen - garden and found [Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff working [there]2007-there with [two other gardeners]655-two other gardeners . The change in the weather seemed to have done [him]57-ben weatherstaff good . [He]57-ben weatherstaff spoke to [her]38-mary of [his]57-ben weatherstaff own accord . " Springtime 's comin , ' "[57-ben weatherstaff] [he]57-ben weatherstaff said . " Can not tha ' smell it ? "[57-ben weatherstaff]

[Mary]38-mary sniffed and thought [she]38-mary could .

" [I]38-mary smell something nice and fresh and damp , "[38-mary] [she]38-mary said .

" That 's th ' good rich earth , "[57-ben weatherstaff] [he]57-ben weatherstaff answered , digging away . " It 's in a good humor makin ' ready to grow things . It 's glad when plantin ' time comes . [It]2110-it 's dull in th ' winter when it 's got nowt to do . In [th ' flower gardens]2111-th ' flower gardens out there things will be stirrin ' down below in th ' dark . Th ' sun 's warmin ' 'em . [You]38-mary 'll see bits o ' green spikes stickin ' out o ' th ' black earth after a bit . "[57-ben weatherstaff]

" What will they be ? "[38-mary] asked [Mary]38-mary .

" Crocuses an ' snowdrops an ' daffydowndillys . Has [tha]2112-tha ' never seen them ? "[57-ben weatherstaff]

" No . Everything is hot , and wet , and green after the rains in [India]2-india , "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary . " And [I]38-mary think things grow up in a night . "[38-mary]

" These wo n't grow up in a night , "[57-ben weatherstaff] said [Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff . " [Tha'll]2112-tha have to wait for ['em]2113-'em . [They]2114-they 'll poke up a bit higher here , an ' push out a spike more there , an ' uncurl a leaf this day an ' another that . [You]38-mary watch ['em]2113-'em . "[57-ben weatherstaff]

" [I]38-mary am going to , "[38-mary] answered [Mary]38-mary .

Very soon [she]38-mary heard the soft rustling flight of wings again and [she]38-mary knew at once that the robin had come again . [He]57-ben weatherstaff was very pert and lively , and hopped about so close to [her]38-mary feet , and put [his]57-ben weatherstaff head on one side and looked at [her]38-mary so slyly that [she]38-mary asked [Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff a question .

" Do [you]57-ben weatherstaff think [he]57-ben weatherstaff remembers [me]38-mary ? "[38-mary] [she]38-mary said .

" Remembers [thee]2115-thee ! "[57-ben weatherstaff] said [Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff indignantly . " [He]57-ben weatherstaff knows every cabbage stump in [th ' gardens]1954-th ' gardens , let alone [th ' people]2117-th ' people . [He]57-ben weatherstaff 's never seen [a little wench here]2118-a little wench here before , an ' [he]57-ben weatherstaff 's bent on findin ' out all about [thee]2115-thee . [Tha]58-tha 's no need to try to hide anything from [him]57-ben weatherstaff . "[57-ben weatherstaff]

" Are things stirring down below in the dark in [that garden where]2119-that garden where [he]57-ben weatherstaff lives ? "[38-mary] [Mary]38-mary inquired .

" [What garden]1974-what garden ? "[57-ben weatherstaff] grunted [Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff , becoming surly again .

" [The one where the old rose - trees]2121-the one where the old rose - trees are . "[38-mary] [She]38-mary could not help asking , because [she]38-mary wanted so much to know . " Are all the flowers dead , or do some of them come again in the summer ? Are there ever any roses ? "[38-mary]

" Ask [him]57-ben weatherstaff , "[57-ben weatherstaff] said [Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff , hunching [his]57-ben weatherstaff shoulders toward the robin . " [He]57-ben weatherstaff 's the only one as knows . [No one else]623-no one else has seen inside [it]146-the garden for ten year ' . "[57-ben weatherstaff]

Ten years was a long time , [Mary]38-mary thought . [She]38-mary had been born ten years ago .

[She]38-mary walked away , slowly thinking . [She]38-mary had begun to like [the garden]146-the garden just as [she]38-mary had begun to like the robin and [Dickon]54-dickon and [[Martha]50-martha 's mother]657-martha 's mother . [She]38-mary was beginning to like [Martha]50-martha , too . That seemed a good many people to like when [you]658-you were not used to liking . [She]38-mary thought of [the robin]495-the robin as [one of [the people]661-the people]660-one of the people . [She]38-mary went to [her]38-mary walk outside the long , ivy - covered wall over which [she]38-mary could see the tree - tops ; and the second time [she]38-mary walked up and down the most interesting and exciting thing happened to [her]38-mary , and it was all through [[Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff 's robin]662-ben weatherstaff 's robin .

[She]38-mary heard a chirp and a twitter , and when [she]38-mary looked at the bare flower - bed at [her]38-mary left side there [he]495-the robin was hopping about and pretending to peck things out of the earth to persuade [her]38-mary that [he]495-the robin had not followed [her]38-mary . But [she]38-mary knew [he]495-the robin had followed [her]38-mary and the surprise so filled [her]38-mary with delight that [she]38-mary almost trembled a little .

" [You]495-the robin do remember [me]38-mary ! "[38-mary] [she]38-mary cried out . " [You]495-the robin do ! [You]495-the robin are prettier than anything else in [the world]234-the world ! "[38-mary]

[She]38-mary chirped , and talked , and coaxed and [he]495-the robin hopped , and flirted [his]495-the robin tail and twittered . It was as if [he]495-the robin were talking . [His]495-the robin red waistcoat was like satin and [he]495-the robin puffed [his]495-the robin tiny breast out and was so fine and so grand and so pretty that it was really as if [he]495-the robin were showing [her]38-mary how important and like [a human person]663-a human person [a robin]544-a robin could be . [Mistress Mary]38-mary forgot that [she]38-mary had ever been contrary in [her]38-mary life when [he]495-the robin allowed [her]38-mary to draw closer and closer to [him]495-the robin , and bend down and talk and try to make something like robin sounds .

Oh ! to think that [he]495-the robin should actually let [her]38-mary come as near to [him]495-the robin as that ! [He]495-the robin knew nothing in [the world]234-the world would make [her]38-mary put out [her]38-mary hand toward [him]495-the robin or startle [him]495-the robin in the least tiniest way . [He]495-the robin knew it because [he]495-the robin was [a real person only nicer than [any other person in [the world]234-the world]667-any other person in the world]666-a real person only nicer than any other person in the world . [She]38-mary was so happy that [she]38-mary scarcely dared to breathe .

The flower - bed was not quite bare . [It]669-it was bare of flowers because the perennial plants had been cut down for [their]670-their winter rest , but there were tall shrubs and low ones which grew together at the back of the bed , and as [the robin]495-the robin hopped about under them [she]38-mary saw [him]495-the robin hop over a small pile of freshly turned up earth . [He]495-the robin stopped on it to look for a worm . [The earth]490-the earth had been turned up because a dog had been trying to dig up a mole and [he]495-the robin had scratched quite a deep hole .

[Mary]38-mary looked at it , not really knowing why the hole was there , and as [she]38-mary looked [she]38-mary saw something almost buried in the newly - turned soil . It was something like a ring of rusty iron or brass and when the robin flew up into a tree nearby [she]38-mary put out [her]38-mary hand and picked the ring up . It was more than a ring , however ; it was an old key which looked as if it had been buried a long time .

[Mistress Mary]38-mary stood up and looked at it with an almost frightened face as it hung from [her]38-mary finger .

" Perhaps it has been buried for ten years , "[38-mary] [she]38-mary said in a whisper . " Perhaps it is the key to [the garden]146-the garden ! "[38-mary]

CHAPTER VIII

[THE ROBIN WHO SHOWED THE WAY]64-the robin who showed the way

[She]64-the robin who showed the way looked at the key quite a long time . [She]64-the robin who showed the way turned it over and over , and thought about it . As [I]0-i have said before , [she]64-the robin who showed the way was [not a child who had been trained to ask permission or consult [[her]64-the robin who showed the way elders]674-her elders about things]673-not a child who had been trained to ask permission or consult her elders about things . All [she]64-the robin who showed the way thought about the key was that if it was the key to [the closed garden]452-the closed garden , and [she]64-the robin who showed the way could find out where the door was , [she]64-the robin who showed the way could perhaps open it and see what was inside the walls , and what had happened to the old rose - trees . It was because it had been shut up so long that [she]64-the robin who showed the way wanted to see it . It seemed as if it must be different from [other places]676-other places and that something strange must have happened to it during ten years . Besides that , if [she]64-the robin who showed the way liked it [she]64-the robin who showed the way could go into [it]677-it every day and shut the door behind [her]64-the robin who showed the way , and [she]64-the robin who showed the way could make up some play of [her]64-the robin who showed the way own and play it quite alone , because [nobody]175-nobody would ever know where [she]64-the robin who showed the way was , but would think the door was still locked and the key buried in the earth . The thought of that pleased [her]64-the robin who showed the way very much .

Living as it were , all by [herself]64-the robin who showed the way in [a house with [a hundred mysteriously closed rooms]680-a hundred mysteriously closed rooms and having nothing whatever to do to amuse [herself]64-the robin who showed the way]679-a house with a hundred mysteriously closed rooms and having nothing whatever to do to amuse herself , had set [her]64-the robin who showed the way inactive brain to working and was actually awakening [her]64-the robin who showed the way imagination . There is no doubt that the fresh , strong , pure air from [the moor]1835-the moor had a great deal to do with it . Just as it had given [her]64-the robin who showed the way an appetite , and fighting with the wind had stirred [her]64-the robin who showed the way blood , so the same things had stirred [her]64-the robin who showed the way mind . In [India]2-india [she]64-the robin who showed the way had always been too hot and languid and weak to care much about anything , but in [this place]1962-this place [she]64-the robin who showed the way was beginning to care and to want to do new things . Already [she]64-the robin who showed the way felt less " contrary , "[64-the robin who showed the way] though [she]64-the robin who showed the way did not know why .

[She]64-the robin who showed the way put the key in [her]64-the robin who showed the way pocket and walked up and down [her]64-the robin who showed the way walk . [[No one]145-no one but [herself]64-the robin who showed the way]684-no one but herself ever seemed to come [there]2007-there , so [she]64-the robin who showed the way could walk slowly and look at the wall , or , rather , at the ivy growing on it . The ivy was the baffling thing . Howsoever carefully [she]64-the robin who showed the way looked [she]64-the robin who showed the way could see nothing but thickly growing , glossy , dark green leaves . [She]64-the robin who showed the way was very much disappointed . Something of [her]64-the robin who showed the way contrariness came back to [her]64-the robin who showed the way as [she]64-the robin who showed the way paced the walk and looked over it at the tree - tops inside . It seemed so silly , [she]64-the robin who showed the way said to [herself]64-the robin who showed the way , to be near [it]2007-there and not be able to get in . [She]64-the robin who showed the way took the key in [her]64-the robin who showed the way pocket when [she]64-the robin who showed the way went back to [the house]166-the house , and [she]64-the robin who showed the way made up [her]64-the robin who showed the way mind that [she]64-the robin who showed the way would always carry it with [her]64-the robin who showed the way when [she]64-the robin who showed the way went out , so that if [she]64-the robin who showed the way ever should find the hidden door [she]64-the robin who showed the way would be ready .

[Mrs. Medlock]45-mrs. medlock had allowed [Martha]50-martha to sleep all night at [the cottage]646-the cottage , but [she]50-martha was back at [her]50-martha work in the morning with cheeks redder than ever and in the best of spirits .

" [I]50-martha got up at four o'clock , "[50-martha] [she]50-martha said . " Eh ! it was pretty on [th ' moor]1874-th ' moor with th ' birds gettin ' up an ' th ' rabbits scamperin ' about an ' th ' sun risin ' . [I]50-martha did n't walk all th ' way . [A man]1910-a man gave [me]50-martha a ride in [his]1910-a man cart an ' [I]50-martha did enjoy [myself]50-martha . "[50-martha]

[She]50-martha was full of stories of the delights of [her]50-martha day out . [[Her]50-martha mother]124-her mother had been glad to see [her]50-martha and [they]689-they had got the baking and washing all out of the way . [She]124-her mother had even made [each of [the children]1803-the children]690-each of the children a doughcake with a bit of brown sugar in it .

" [I]124-her mother had 'em all pipin ' hot when [they]1803-the children came in from playin ' on [th ' moor]1874-th ' moor . An ' [th ' cottage]2128-th ' cottage all smelt o ' nice , clean hot bakin ' an ' there was a good fire , an ' [they]1803-the children just shouted for joy . [[Our]689-they Dickon]1929-our dickon [he]1929-our dickon said [[our]689-they cottage]2017-our cottage was good enough for [a king]2131-a king . "[124-her mother]

In the evening [they]689-they had all sat round the fire , and [Martha]50-martha and [[her]50-martha mother]124-her mother had sewed patches on torn clothes and mended stockings and [Martha]50-martha had told [them]689-they about [the little girl who had come from [India]2-india and who had been waited on all [her]50-martha life by what [Martha]50-martha called " [blacks]2027-blacks]2132-the little girl who had come from india and who had been waited on all her life by what martha called " blacks "[50-martha] until [she]50-martha did n't know how to put on [her]50-martha own stockings .

" Eh ! [they]689-they did like to hear about [you]50-martha , "[50-martha] said [Martha]50-martha . " [They]689-they wanted to know all about [th ' blacks]1907-th ' blacks an ' about [th ' ship [you]50-martha came in]2135-th ' ship you came in . [I]50-martha could n't tell ['em]2136-'em enough . "[50-martha]

[Mary]38-mary reflected a little .

" [I]38-mary 'll tell [you]693-you a great deal more before [your]693-you next day out , "[38-mary] [she]38-mary said , ' so that [you]693-you will have more to talk about . [I]0-i dare say [they]694-they would like to hear about riding on elephants and camels , and about [the officers going to hunt tigers]695-the officers going to hunt tigers . "[695-the officers going to hunt tigers]

" [My]50-martha word ! "[50-martha] cried delighted [Martha]50-martha . " It would set 'em clean off [their]694-they heads . Would tha ' really do that , [Miss]2137-miss ? It would be same as a wild beast show like [we]2138-we heard [they]694-they had in [York]11-york once . "[50-martha]

" [India]2-india is quite different from [Yorkshire]50-martha , "[38-mary] [Mary]38-mary said slowly , as [she]38-mary thought the matter over . " [I]38-mary never thought of that . Did [Dickon]54-dickon and [[your]50-martha mother]2093-your mother like to hear [you]50-martha talk about [me]38-mary ? "[38-mary]

" Why , [[our]2138-we [Dickon]54-dickon]1929-our dickon 's eyes nearly started out o ' [his]54-dickon head , [they]694-they got that round , "[50-martha] answered [Martha]50-martha . " But [mother]224-mother , [she]224-mother was put out about [your]50-martha seemin ' to be all by [yourself]50-martha like . [She]224-mother said , ' Has n't [Mr. Craven]41-mr. craven got [no governess]2142-no governess for [her]224-mother , nor [no nurse]2143-no nurse ? ' and [I]50-martha said , ' No , [he]41-mr. craven has n't , though [Mrs. Medlock]45-mrs. medlock says [he]41-mr. craven will when [he]41-mr. craven thinks of it , but [she]224-mother says [he]41-mr. craven may n't think of it for two or three years . ' "[50-martha]

" [I]38-mary do n't want [a governess]2073-a governess , "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary sharply .

" But [mother]224-mother says [you]50-martha ought to be learnin ' [your]50-martha book by this time an ' [you]50-martha ought to have [a woman]2146-a woman to look after [you]50-martha , an ' [she]224-mother says : ' Now , [Martha]50-martha , [you]50-martha just think how [you]50-martha 'd feel [yourself]50-martha , in a big place like that , wanderin ' about all alone , an ' [no mother]2147-no mother . [You]50-martha do [your]50-martha best to cheer [her]2146-a woman up , ' [she]224-mother says , an ' [I]50-martha said [I]50-martha would . "[50-martha]

[Mary]38-mary gave [her]38-mary a long , steady look .

" [You]50-martha do cheer [me]38-mary up , "[38-mary] [she]38-mary said . " [I]38-mary like to hear [you]50-martha talk . "[38-mary]

[Presently Martha]50-martha went out of [the room]201-the room and came back with something held in [her]38-mary hands under [her]38-mary apron .

" What does tha ' think , "[38-mary] [she]38-mary said , with a cheerful grin . " [I]38-mary 've brought [thee]50-martha a present . "[38-mary]

" A present ! "[38-mary] exclaimed [Mistress Mary]38-mary . How could [a cottage full of [fourteen hungry people]698-fourteen hungry people]697-a cottage full of fourteen hungry people give [any one]189-any one a present !

" [A man]1910-a man was drivin ' across [the moor]1835-the moor peddlin ' , "[50-martha] [Martha]50-martha explained . " An ' [he]1910-a man stopped [[his]1910-a man cart]2150-his cart at [our]2151-our door . [He]1910-a man had pots an ' pans an ' odds an ' ends , but [mother]224-mother had no money to buy anythin ' . Just as [he]1910-a man was goin' away [our]2151-our ' [Lizabeth Ellen]66-lizabeth ellen called out , ' [Mother]224-mother , [he]1910-a man 's got skippin'-ropes with red an ' blue handles . ' An ' [mother]224-mother [she]66-lizabeth ellen calls out quite sudden , ' Here , stop , [mister]2155-mister ! How much are [they]2156-they ? ' An ' [he]1910-a man says ' Tuppence ' , an ' [mother]224-mother [she]66-lizabeth ellen began fumblin ' in [her]66-lizabeth ellen pocket an ' [she]700-she says to [me]50-martha , ' [Martha]50-martha , tha 's brought [me]50-martha [thy]50-martha wages like [a good lass]2158-a good lass , an ' [I]50-martha 've got four places to put every penny , but [I]50-martha 'm just goin' to take tuppence out of it to buy [that child]2159-that child a skippin'-rope , ' an ' [she]700-she bought one an ' here it is . "[50-martha]

[She]700-she brought it out from under [her]700-she apron and exhibited it quite proudly . It was a strong , slender rope with a striped red and blue handle at each end , but [Mary Lennox]38-mary had never seen a skipping - rope before . [She]38-mary gazed at it with a mystified expression .

" What is it for ? "[700-she] [she]700-she asked curiously .

" For ! "[50-martha] cried out [Martha]50-martha . " Does tha ' mean that [they]2160-they 've not got skippin'-ropes in [India]2-india , for all [they]2160-they 've got elephants and tigers and camels ! No wonder most of 'em 's black . This is what it 's for ; just watch [me]50-martha . "[50-martha]

And [she]700-she ran into the middle of [the room]201-the room and , taking a handle in each hand , began to skip , and skip , and skip , while [Mary]38-mary turned in [her]38-mary chair to stare at [her]700-she , and the queer faces in [the old portraits]702-the old portraits seemed to stare at [her]700-she , too , and wonder what on earth [this common little cottager]703-this common little cottager had the impudence to be doing under [their]703-this common little cottager very noses . But [Martha]50-martha did not even see [them]703-this common little cottager . The interest and curiosity in [Mistress Mary]38-mary 's face delighted [her]50-martha , and [she]38-mary went on skipping and counted as [she]38-mary skipped until [she]38-mary had reached a hundred .

" [I]38-mary could skip longer than that , "[38-mary] [she]38-mary said when [she]38-mary stopped . " [I]38-mary 've skipped as much as five hundred when [I]38-mary was twelve , but [I]38-mary was n't as fat then as [I]38-mary am now , an ' [I]38-mary was in practice . "[38-mary]

[Mary]38-mary got up from [her]38-mary chair beginning to feel excited [herself]38-mary .

" It looks nice , "[38-mary] [she]38-mary said . " [[Your]38-mary mother]2093-your mother is [a kind woman]2162-a kind woman . Do [you]38-mary think [I]38-mary could ever skip like that ? "[38-mary]

" [You]38-mary just try it , "[50-martha] urged [Martha]50-martha , handing [her]38-mary the skipping - rope . " [You]38-mary ca n't skip a hundred at first , but if [you]38-mary practice [you]38-mary 'll mount up . That 's what [mother]224-mother said . [She]224-mother says , ' Nothin' will do [her]224-mother more good than skippin ' rope . It 's [th]2164-tha ' sensiblest toy [a child]1768-a child can have . Let [her]224-mother play out in th ' fresh air skippin ' an ' it 'll stretch [her]224-mother legs an ' arms an ' give [her]224-mother some strength in 'em . ' "[50-martha]

It was plain that there was not a great deal of strength in [Mistress Mary]38-mary 's arms and legs when [she]38-mary first began to skip . [She]38-mary was not very clever at it , but [she]38-mary liked it so much that [she]38-mary did not want to stop .

" Put on [tha]2164-tha ' things and run an ' skip out o ' doors , "[50-martha] said [Martha]50-martha . " [Mother]53-mother said [I]50-martha must tell [you]50-martha to keep out o ' doors as much as [you]50-martha could , even when it rains a bit , so as [tha]2164-tha ' wrap up warm . "[50-martha]

[Mary]38-mary put on [her]38-mary coat and hat and took [her]38-mary skipping - rope over [her]38-mary arm . [She]38-mary opened the door to go out , and then suddenly thought of something and turned back rather slowly .

" [Martha]50-martha , "[38-mary] [she]38-mary said , " they were [your]50-martha wages . It was [your]50-martha two - pence really . Thank [you]50-martha . "[38-mary] [She]38-mary said it stiffly because [she]38-mary was not used to thanking [people]167-people or noticing that [they]167-people did things for [her]38-mary . " Thank [you]50-martha , "[38-mary] [she]38-mary said , and held out [her]38-mary hand because [she]38-mary did not know what else to do .

[Martha]50-martha gave [her]50-martha hand a clumsy little shake , as if [she]50-martha was not accustomed to this sort of thing either . Then [she]50-martha laughed .

" Eh ! th ' art a queer , old - womanish thing , "[50-martha] [she]50-martha said . " If tha'd been [our]2166-our ' [Lizabeth Ellen]66-lizabeth ellen tha'd have given [me]50-martha a kiss . "[50-martha]

[Mary]38-mary looked stiffer than ever .

" Do [you]50-martha want [me]50-martha to kiss [you]50-martha ? "[50-martha]

[Martha]50-martha laughed again .

" Nay , not [me]50-martha , "[50-martha] [she]50-martha answered . " If tha ' was different , p'raps tha'd want to thysel ' . But tha ' is n't . Run off outside an ' play with [thy]50-martha rope . "[50-martha]

[Mistress Mary]38-mary felt a little awkward as [she]38-mary went out of [the room]201-the room . [Yorkshire people]706-yorkshire people seemed strange , and [Martha]50-martha was always rather a puzzle to [her]38-mary . At first [she]38-mary had disliked [her]50-martha very much , but now [she]38-mary did not . The skipping - rope was a wonderful thing . [She]50-martha counted and skipped , and skipped and counted , until [her]50-martha cheeks were quite red , and [she]50-martha was more interested than [she]50-martha had ever been since [she]50-martha was born . The sun was shining and a little wind was blowing not a rough wind , but one which came in delightful little gusts and brought a fresh scent of newly turned earth with it . [She]50-martha skipped round [the fountain garden]707-the fountain garden , and up [one walk]708-one walk and down another . [She]50-martha skipped at last into [the kitchen - garden]709-the kitchen - garden and saw [Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff digging and talking to [his]57-ben weatherstaff robin , which was hopping about [him]57-ben weatherstaff . [She]50-martha skipped down [the walk]523-the walk toward [him]57-ben weatherstaff and [he]57-ben weatherstaff lifted [his]57-ben weatherstaff head and looked at [her]50-martha with a curious expression . [She]50-martha had wondered if [he]57-ben weatherstaff would notice [her]50-martha . [She]50-martha wanted [him]57-ben weatherstaff to see [her]50-martha skip .

" Well ! "[57-ben weatherstaff] [he]57-ben weatherstaff exclaimed . " Upon [my]57-ben weatherstaff word . P'raps [tha]2167-tha ' art [a young ' un]2168-a young ' un , after all , an ' p'raps tha 's got [child]2169-child 's blood in [thy]2167-tha veins instead of sour buttermilk . [Tha]2167-tha 's skipped red into [thy]2167-tha cheeks as sure as [my]57-ben weatherstaff name 's [Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff . [I]57-ben weatherstaff would n't have believed [tha]2167-tha ' could do it . "[57-ben weatherstaff]

" [I]38-mary never skipped before , "[38-mary] [Mary]38-mary said . " [I]38-mary 'm just beginning . [I]38-mary can only go up to twenty . "[38-mary]

" [Tha]2167-tha ' keep on , "[57-ben weatherstaff] said [Ben]57-ben weatherstaff . " [Tha]2167-tha ' shapes well enough at [it]2170-it for [a young ' un that 's lived with [heathen]2172-heathen]2171-a young ' un that 's lived with heathen . " [He]57-ben weatherstaff followed after [thee]2167-tha yesterday . [He]57-ben weatherstaff 'll be at it again today . [He]57-ben weatherstaff 'll be bound to find out what [th ' skippin'-rope]2173-th ' skippin'-rope is . [He]57-ben weatherstaff 's never seen one . Eh !
