"[57-ben weatherstaff]

[Mary]38-mary skipped round all [the gardens]439-the gardens and round [the orchard]466-the orchard , resting every few minutes . At length [she]38-mary went to [her]38-mary own special walk and made up [her]38-mary mind to try if [she]38-mary could skip the whole length of it . It was a good long skip and [she]38-mary began slowly , but before [she]38-mary had gone half - way down [the path]459-the path [she]38-mary was so hot and breathless that [she]38-mary was obliged to stop . [She]38-mary did not mind much , because [she]38-mary had already counted up to thirty . [She]38-mary stopped with a little laugh of pleasure , and there , lo and behold , was the robin swaying on a long branch of ivy . [He]57-ben weatherstaff had followed [her]38-mary and [he]57-ben weatherstaff greeted [her]38-mary with a chirp . As [Mary]38-mary had skipped toward [him]57-ben weatherstaff [she]38-mary felt something heavy in [her]38-mary pocket strike against [her]38-mary at each jump , and when [she]38-mary saw the robin [she]38-mary laughed again .

" [You]57-ben weatherstaff showed [me]38-mary where the key was yesterday , "[38-mary] [she]38-mary said . " [You]57-ben weatherstaff ought to show [me]38-mary the door today ; but [I]38-mary do n't believe [you]57-ben weatherstaff know ! "[38-mary]

[The robin]495-the robin flew from [his]495-the robin swinging spray of ivy on to the top of the wall and [he]495-the robin opened [his]495-the robin beak and sang a loud , lovely trill , merely to show off . Nothing in [the world]234-the world is quite as adorably lovely as a robin when [he]495-the robin shows off and [they]716-they are nearly always doing it .

[Mary Lennox]38-mary had heard a great deal about Magic in [her]38-mary Ayah 's stories , and [she]38-mary always said that what happened almost at that moment was Magic .

One of the nice little gusts of wind rushed down [the walk]523-the walk , and it was a stronger one than the rest . It was strong enough to wave the branches of the trees , and it was more than strong enough to sway the trailing sprays of untrimmed ivy hanging from the wall . [Mary]38-mary had stepped close to the robin , and suddenly the gust of wind swung aside some loose ivy trails , and more suddenly still [she]38-mary jumped toward it and caught it in [her]38-mary hand . This [she]38-mary did because [she]38-mary had seen something under it a round knob which had been covered by the leaves hanging over it . It was the knob of a door .

[She]38-mary put [her]38-mary hands under the leaves and began to pull and push them aside . Thick as the ivy hung , it nearly all was a loose and swinging curtain , though some had crept over wood and iron . [Mary]38-mary 's heart began to thump and [her]38-mary hands to shake a little in [her]38-mary delight and excitement . [The robin]495-the robin kept singing and twittering away and tilting [his]495-the robin head on one side , as if [he]495-the robin were as excited as [she]38-mary was . What was this under [her]38-mary hands which was square and made of iron and which [her]38-mary fingers found a hole in ?

It was the lock of the door which had been closed ten years and [she]38-mary put [her]38-mary hand in [her]38-mary pocket , drew out the key and found it fitted the keyhole . [She]38-mary put the key in and turned it . It took two hands to do it , but it did turn .

And then [she]38-mary took a long breath and looked behind [her]38-mary up [the long walk]719-the long walk to see if [any one]189-any one was coming . [No one]145-no one was coming . [No one]145-no one ever did come , it seemed , and [she]38-mary took another long breath , because [she]38-mary could not help it , and [she]38-mary held back the swinging curtain of ivy and pushed back the door which opened slowly slowly .

Then [she]38-mary slipped through it , and shut it behind [her]38-mary , and stood with [her]38-mary back against it , looking about [her]38-mary and breathing quite fast with excitement , and wonder , and delight .

[She]38-mary was standing inside [the secret garden]1969-the secret garden .

CHAPTER IX

[THE STRANGEST HOUSE ANY ONE EVER LIVED]724-the strangest house any one ever lived IN

It was [the sweetest , most mysterious - looking place any one could imagine]725-the sweetest , most mysterious - looking place any one could imagine . The high walls which shut [it]724-the strangest house any one ever lived in were covered with the leafless stems of climbing roses which were so thick that they were matted together . [Mary Lennox]38-mary knew [they]726-they were roses because [she]38-mary had seen a great many roses in [India]2-india . All the ground was covered with grass of a wintry brown and out of it grew clumps of bushes which were surely rosebushes if [they]726-they were alive . There were numbers of standard roses which had so spread their branches that they were like little trees . There were other trees in [the garden]146-the garden , and one of the things which made [the place]228-the place look strangest and loveliest was that climbing roses had run all over [them]726-they and swung down long tendrils which made light swaying curtains , and here and there [they]726-they had caught at each other or at a far - reaching branch and had crept from one tree to another and made lovely bridges of [themselves]726-they . There were neither leaves nor roses on them now and [Mary]38-mary did not know whether [they]726-they were dead or alive , but [their]726-they thin gray or brown branches and sprays looked like a sort of hazy mantle spreading over everything , walls , and trees , and even brown grass , where they had fallen from their fastenings and run along the ground . It was this hazy tangle from tree to tree which made it all look so mysterious . [Mary]38-mary had thought it must be different from [other gardens which had not been left all by]729-other gardens which had not been left all by [themselves]729-other gardens which had not been left all by so long ; and indeed it was different from [any other place [she]38-mary had ever seen in [her]38-mary life]730-any other place she had ever seen in her life .

" How still it is ! "[38-mary] [she]38-mary whispered . " How still ! "[38-mary]

Then [she]38-mary waited a moment and listened at the stillness . The robin , who had flown to [his]731-his treetop , was still as all the rest . [He]731-his did not even flutter [his]731-his wings ; [he]731-his sat without stirring , and looked at [Mary]38-mary .

" No wonder it is still , "[38-mary] [she]38-mary whispered again . " [I]38-mary am [the first person who has spoken in here for ten years]2174-the first person who has spoken in here for ten years . "[38-mary]

[She]38-mary moved away from the door , stepping as softly as if [she]38-mary were afraid of awakening some one . [She]38-mary was glad that there was grass under [her]38-mary feet and that [her]38-mary steps made no sounds . [She]38-mary walked under one of the fairy - like gray arches between the trees and looked up at the sprays and tendrils which formed them . " [I]38-mary wonder if [they]2175-they are all quite dead , "[38-mary] [she]38-mary said . " Is it all [a quite dead garden]2176-a quite dead garden ? [I]38-mary wish it was n't . "[38-mary]

If [she]38-mary had been [Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff [she]38-mary could have told whether the wood was alive by looking at it , but [she]38-mary could only see that there were only gray or brown sprays and branches and none showed any signs of even a tiny leaf - bud anywhere .

But [she]38-mary was inside [the wonderful garden]732-the wonderful garden and [she]38-mary could come through the door under the ivy any time and [she]38-mary felt as if [she]38-mary had found [a world]733-a world all [her]38-mary own .

The sun was shining inside the four walls and the high arch of blue sky over [this particular piece of [Misselthwaite]5-misselthwaite]734-this particular piece of misselthwaite seemed even more brilliant and soft than it was over [the moor]1835-the moor . [The robin]495-the robin flew down from [his]495-the robin tree - top and hopped about or flew after [her]38-mary from one bush to another . [He]495-the robin chirped a good deal and had a very busy air , as if [he]495-the robin were showing [her]38-mary things . Everything was strange and silent and [she]38-mary seemed to be hundreds of miles away from any one , but somehow [she]38-mary did not feel lonely at all . All that troubled [her]38-mary was [her]38-mary wish that [she]38-mary knew whether all the roses were dead , or if perhaps some of them had lived and might put out leaves and buds as the weather got warmer . [She]38-mary did not want it to be [a quite dead garden]2176-a quite dead garden . If [it]2176-a quite dead garden were [a quite alive garden]738-a quite alive garden , how wonderful [it]2176-a quite dead garden would be , and what thousands of roses would grow on every side !

[Her]38-mary skipping - rope had hung over [her]38-mary arm when [she]38-mary came in and after [she]38-mary had walked about for a while [she]38-mary thought [she]38-mary would skip round [the whole garden]739-the whole garden , stopping when [she]38-mary wanted to look at things . There seemed to have been grass paths here and there , and in one or two corners there were alcoves of evergreen with stone seats or tall moss - covered flower urns in them .

As [she]38-mary came near the second of [these alcoves]740-these alcoves [she]38-mary stopped skipping . There had once been a flowerbed in [it]739-the whole garden , and [she]38-mary thought [she]38-mary saw something sticking out of the black earth some sharp little pale green points . [She]38-mary remembered what [Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff had said and [she]38-mary knelt down to look at them .

" Yes , they are tiny growing things and they might be crocuses or snowdrops or daffodils , "[38-mary] [she]38-mary whispered .

[She]38-mary bent very close to [them]741-them and sniffed the fresh scent of the damp earth . [She]38-mary liked it very much .

" Perhaps there are some other ones coming up in other places , "[38-mary] [she]38-mary said . " [I]38-mary will go all over [the garden]146-the garden and look . "[38-mary]

[She]38-mary did not skip , but walked . [She]38-mary went slowly and kept [her]38-mary eyes on the ground . [She]38-mary looked in the old border beds and among the grass , and after [she]38-mary had gone round , trying to miss nothing , [she]38-mary had found ever so many more sharp , pale green points , and [she]38-mary had become quite excited again .

" It is n't [a quite dead garden]2176-a quite dead garden , "[38-mary] [she]38-mary cried out softly to [herself]38-mary . " Even if the roses are dead , there are other things alive . "[38-mary]

[She]38-mary did not know anything about gardening , but the grass seemed so thick in some of the places where the green points were pushing their way through that [she]38-mary thought they did not seem to have room enough to grow . [She]38-mary searched about until [she]38-mary found a rather sharp piece of wood and knelt down and dug and weeded out the weeds and grass until [she]38-mary made nice little clear places around them .

" Now they look as if they could breathe , "[38-mary] [she]38-mary said , after [she]38-mary had finished with the first ones . " [I]38-mary am going to do ever so many more . [I]38-mary 'll do all [I]38-mary can see . If [I]38-mary have n't time today [I]38-mary can come tomorrow . "[38-mary]

[She]38-mary went from place to place , and dug and weeded , and enjoyed [herself]38-mary so immensely that [she]38-mary was led on from bed to bed and into the grass under the trees . The exercise made [her]38-mary so warm that [she]38-mary first threw [her]38-mary coat off , and then [her]38-mary hat , and without knowing it [she]38-mary was smiling down on to the grass and the pale green points all the time .

The robin was tremendously busy . [He]742-he was very much pleased to see gardening begun on [[his]742-he own estate]743-his own estate . [He]742-he had often wondered at [Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff . Where gardening is done all sorts of delightful things to eat are turned up with the soil . Now here was this new kind of creature who was not half [Ben]57-ben weatherstaff 's size and yet had had the sense to come into [[his]57-ben weatherstaff garden]458-his garden and begin at once .

[Mistress Mary]38-mary worked in [[her]38-mary garden]1960-her garden until it was time to go to [her]38-mary midday dinner . In fact , [she]38-mary was rather late in remembering , and when [she]38-mary put on [her]38-mary coat and hat , and picked up [her]38-mary skipping - rope , [she]38-mary could not believe that [she]38-mary had been working two or three hours . [She]38-mary had been actually happy all the time ; and dozens and dozens of the tiny , pale green points were to be seen in cleared places , looking twice as cheerful as they had looked before when the grass and weeds had been smothering them .

" [I]38-mary shall come back this afternoon , "[38-mary] [she]38-mary said , looking all round at [[her]38-mary new kingdom]746-her new kingdom , and speaking to the trees and the rose - bushes as if [they]747-they heard [her]38-mary .

Then [she]38-mary ran lightly across the grass , pushed open the slow old door and slipped through it under the ivy . [She]38-mary had such red cheeks and such bright eyes and ate such a dinner that [Martha]50-martha was delighted .

" Two pieces o ' meat an ' two helps o ' rice puddin ' ! "[38-mary] [she]38-mary said . " Eh ! [mother]224-mother will be pleased when [I]38-mary tell [her]224-mother what [th]2180-th ' skippin'-rope 's done for [thee]50-martha . "[38-mary]

In the course of [her]38-mary digging with [her]38-mary pointed stick [Mistress Mary]38-mary had found [herself]38-mary digging up a sort of white root rather like an onion . [She]38-mary had put it back in its place and patted the earth carefully down on it and just now [she]38-mary wondered if [Martha]50-martha could tell [her]38-mary what it was .

" [Martha]50-martha , "[38-mary] [she]38-mary said , " what are those white roots that look like onions ? "[38-mary]

" They 're bulbs , "[50-martha] answered [Martha]50-martha . " Lots o ' spring flowers grow from 'em . [Th ' very little ones]2181-th ' very little ones are snowdrops an ' crocuses an ' th ' big ones are narcissuses an ' jonquils and daffydowndillys . Th ' biggest of all is lilies an ' purple flags . Eh ! they are nice . [Dickon]54-dickon 's got a whole lot of 'em planted in [[our]2182-our bit o ' garden]2183-our bit o ' garden . "[50-martha]

" Does [Dickon]54-dickon know all about [them]2184-them ? "[38-mary] asked [Mary]38-mary , a new idea taking possession of [her]38-mary .

" [Our]2182-our [Dickon]54-dickon can make a flower grow out of a brick walk . [Mother]53-mother says [he]54-dickon just whispers things out o ' [th ' ground]2185-th ' ground . "[50-martha]

" Do [bulbs]2186-they live a long time ? Would [they]2186-they live years and years if [no one]145-no one helped [them]2186-they ? "[38-mary] inquired [Mary]38-mary anxiously .

" [They]2186-they 're things as helps [themselves]2186-they , "[50-martha] said [Martha]50-martha . " That 's why [poor folk]2188-poor folk can afford to have 'em . " [I]38-mary wish the spring was [here]1771-here now , "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary . " [I]38-mary want to see all the things that grow in [England]3-england . "[38-mary]

[She]38-mary had finished [her]38-mary dinner and gone to [her]38-mary favorite seat on the hearth - rug .

" [I]38-mary wish [I]38-mary wish [I]38-mary had a little spade , "[38-mary] [she]38-mary said . " Whatever does [tha]2194-tha ' want a spade for ? "[50-martha] asked [Martha]50-martha , laughing . " Art [tha]2194-tha ' goin' to take to diggin ' ? [I]50-martha must tell [mother]224-mother that , too . "[50-martha]

[Mary]38-mary looked at the fire and pondered a little . [She]38-mary must be careful if [she]38-mary meant to keep [her]38-mary secret kingdom . [She]38-mary was n't doing any harm , but if [Mr. Craven]41-mr. craven found out about the open door [he]41-mr. craven would be fearfully angry and get a new key and lock it up forevermore . [She]38-mary really could not bear that .

" This is such [a big lonely place]2196-a big lonely place , "[38-mary] [she]38-mary said slowly , as if [she]38-mary were turning matters over in [her]38-mary mind . " [The house]166-the house is lonely , and [the park]369-the park is lonely , and [the gardens]439-the gardens are lonely . [So many places]2200-so many places seem shut up . [I]38-mary never did many things in [India]2-india , but there were [more people]2201-more people to look at [natives]1914-natives and [soldiers]2203-soldiers marching by and sometimes [bands]2204-bands playing , and [[my]38-mary Ayah]1757-my ayah told [me]38-mary stories . "[38-mary]

[Martha]50-martha 's face quite lighted up .

" [My]50-martha word ! that 's riches , "[50-martha] said [Martha]50-martha . " [Tha]2219-tha ' can buy anything in [th ' world]2220-th ' world [tha]2219-tha ' wants . " [[Our]2222-our [Dickon]54-dickon]1929-our dickon can only read printin ' . If [tha]2219-tha ' could print [we]2222-our could write a letter to [him]1929-our dickon an ' ask [him]1929-our dickon to go an ' buy [th ' garden]2035-th ' garden tools an ' th ' seeds at th ' same time . "[50-martha]

" Oh ! [you]38-mary 're [a good girl]2229-a good girl ! "[38-mary] [Mary]38-mary cried . " [You]38-mary are , really ! [I]38-mary did n't know [you]38-mary were so nice . " [I]50-martha 've got some of [my]50-martha own , "[50-martha] said [Martha]50-martha . " [I]50-martha bought 'em so [I]50-martha could print a bit of a letter to [mother of a Sunday]2230-mother of a sunday . [I]50-martha 'll go and get it . "[50-martha] [She]50-martha ran out of [the room]201-the room , and [Mary]38-mary stood by the fire and twisted [her]38-mary thin little hands together with sheer pleasure .

" If [I]38-mary have a spade , "[38-mary] [she]38-mary whispered , " [I]38-mary can make [the earth]490-the earth nice and soft and dig up weeds . If [I]38-mary have seeds and can make flowers grow [the garden]146-the garden wo n't be dead at all it will come alive . "[38-mary]

[She]50-martha did not go out again that afternoon because when [Martha]50-martha returned with [her]50-martha pen and ink and paper [she]50-martha was obliged to clear the table and carry the plates and dishes [downstairs]440-downstairs and when [she]50-martha got into [the kitchen]750-the kitchen [Mrs. Medlock]45-mrs. medlock was there and told [her]50-martha to do something , so [Mary]38-mary waited for what seemed to [her]38-mary a long time before [she]38-mary came back . Then it was a serious piece of work to write to [Dickon]54-dickon . [Mary]38-mary had been taught very little because [[her]38-mary governesses]751-her governesses had disliked [her]38-mary too much to stay with [her]38-mary . [She]38-mary could not spell particularly well but [she]38-mary found that [she]38-mary could print letters when [she]38-mary tried . This was the letter [Martha]50-martha dictated to [her]38-mary : " [My]50-martha Dear [Dickon]54-dickon :[50-martha]

This comes hoping to find [you]38-mary well as it leaves [me]0-i at present . [Miss Mary]38-mary has plenty of money and will [you]38-mary go to [Thwaite]13-thwaite and buy [her]38-mary some flower seeds and a set of garden tools to make a flower - bed . Pick the prettiest ones and easy to grow because [she]38-mary has never done it before and lived in [India]2-india which is different . Give [my]0-i love to [mother]224-mother and [every one of [you]38-mary]753-every one of you . [Miss Mary]38-mary is going to tell [me]0-i a lot more so that on [my]0-i next day out [you]38-mary can hear about elephants and camels and [gentlemen]754-gentlemen going hunting lions and tigers .

" [[Your]38-mary loving sister]2233-your loving sister , [Martha Phoebe Sowerby]50-martha . "[38-mary] " [We]2234-we 'll put the money in th ' envelope an ' [I]50-martha 'll get [th ' butcher boy]2235-th ' butcher boy to take it in [[his]2235-th ' butcher boy cart]2150-his cart . [He]2235-th ' butcher boy 's [a great friend o ' [Dickon]54-dickon 's]2237-a great friend o ' dickon 's , "[50-martha] said [Martha]50-martha .

" How shall [I]38-mary get the things when [Dickon]54-dickon buys them ? "[38-mary]

" [He]54-dickon 'll bring ['em]2238-'em to [you]50-martha [himself]54-dickon . [He]54-dickon 'll like to walk over this way . "[38-mary]

" Oh ! "[38-mary] exclaimed [Mary]38-mary , " then [I]38-mary shall see [him]54-dickon ! [I]38-mary never thought [I]38-mary should see [Dickon]54-dickon . "[38-mary]

" Does tha ' want to see [him]54-dickon ? "[50-martha] asked [Martha]50-martha suddenly , for [Mary]38-mary had looked so pleased .

" Yes , [I]38-mary do . [I]38-mary never saw [a boy foxes and crows loved]2239-a boy foxes and crows loved . [I]38-mary want to see [him]54-dickon very much . "[38-mary]

[Martha]50-martha gave a little start , as if [she]50-martha remembered something . " Now to think , "[38-mary] [she]38-mary broke out , " to think o ' [me]38-mary forgettin ' that there ; an ' [I]38-mary thought [I]38-mary was goin' to tell [you]38-mary first thing this mornin ' . [I]38-mary asked [mother]224-mother and [she]224-mother said [she]224-mother 'd ask [Mrs. Medlock]45-mrs. medlock [her]224-mother own self . "[38-mary]

" Do [you]38-mary mean "[38-mary] [Mary]38-mary began .

" What [I]38-mary said Tuesday . Ask [her]224-mother if [you]38-mary might be driven over to [[our]2241-our cottage]2017-our cottage some day and have a bit o ' [mother]224-mother 's hot oat cake , an ' butter , an ' a glass o ' milk . "[38-mary]

It seemed as if all the interesting things were happening in one day . To think of going over [the moor]1835-the moor in the daylight and when the sky was blue ! To think of going into [the cottage which held]756-the cottage which held [twelve children]2215-twelve children !

" Does [she]224-mother think [Mrs. Medlock]45-mrs. medlock would let [me]38-mary go ? "[38-mary] [she]38-mary asked , quite anxiously .

" Aye , [she]224-mother thinks [she]224-mother would . [She]224-mother knows what [a tidy woman mother]2244-a tidy woman mother is and how clean [she]224-mother keeps [the cottage]646-the cottage . "[38-mary]

" If [I]38-mary went [I]38-mary should see [[your]50-martha mother]2093-your mother as well as [Dickon]54-dickon , "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary , thinking it over and liking the idea very much . " [She]2093-your mother does n't seem to be like [the mothers in [India]2-india]2247-the mothers in india . "[38-mary]

[Her]38-mary work in [the garden]146-the garden and the excitement of the afternoon ended by making [her]38-mary feel quiet and thoughtful . [Martha]50-martha stayed with [her]38-mary until tea - time , but [they]759-they sat in comfortable quiet and talked very little . But just before [Martha]50-martha went [downstairs]440-downstairs for the tea - tray , [Mary]38-mary asked a question .

" [Martha]50-martha , "[38-mary] [she]38-mary said , " has [the scullery - maid]2248-the scullery - maid had the toothache again today ? "[38-mary]

[Martha]50-martha certainly started slightly .

" What makes [thee]50-martha ask that ? "[38-mary] [she]38-mary said .

" Because when [I]50-martha waited so long for [you]50-martha to come back [I]50-martha opened the door and walked down [the corridor]583-the corridor to see if [you]50-martha were coming . And [I]50-martha heard that far - off crying again , just as [we]759-they heard it the other night . There is n't a wind today , so [you]50-martha see it could n't have been the wind . "[50-martha]

" Eh ! "[50-martha] said [Martha]50-martha restlessly . " Tha ' must n't go walkin ' about in [corridors]2250-corridors an ' listenin ' . [Mr. Craven]41-mr. craven would be that there angry there 's no knowin ' what [he]41-mr. craven 'd do . "[50-martha]

" [I]38-mary was n't listening , "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary . " [I]38-mary was just waiting for [you]50-martha and [I]38-mary heard it . That 's three times . "[38-mary]

" [My]50-martha word ! There 's [Mrs. Medlock]45-mrs. medlock 's bell , "[50-martha] said [Martha]50-martha , and [she]50-martha almost ran out of [the room]201-the room .

" It 's [the strangest house [any one]189-any one ever lived in]2251-the strangest house any one ever lived in , "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary drowsily , as [she]38-mary dropped [her]38-mary head on the cushioned seat of the armchair near [her]38-mary . Fresh air , and digging , and skipping - rope had made [her]38-mary feel so comfortably tired that [she]38-mary fell asleep .

[CHAPTER X

DICKON]70-chapter x dickon

The sun shone down for nearly a week on [the secret garden]1969-the secret garden . [The Secret Garden]1969-the secret garden was what [Mary]38-mary called [it]1969-the secret garden when [she]38-mary was thinking of [it]1969-the secret garden . [She]38-mary liked the name , and [she]38-mary liked still more the feeling that when [its]1969-the secret garden beautiful old walls shut [her]38-mary in [no one]145-no one knew where [she]38-mary was . It seemed almost like being shut out of [the world]234-the world in some fairy place . The few books [she]38-mary had read and liked had been fairy - story books , and [she]38-mary had read of [secret gardens]766-secret gardens in some of the stories . Sometimes [people]167-people went to sleep in them for a hundred years , which [she]38-mary had thought must be rather stupid . [She]38-mary had no intention of going to sleep , and , in fact , [she]38-mary was becoming wider awake every day which passed at [Misselthwaite]5-misselthwaite . [She]38-mary was beginning to like to be out of doors ; [she]38-mary no longer hated the wind , but enjoyed it . [She]38-mary could run faster , and longer , and [she]38-mary could skip up to a hundred . The bulbs in [the secret garden]1969-the secret garden must have been much astonished . Such nice clear places were made round [them]769-they that [they]769-they had all the breathing space [they]769-they wanted , and really , if [Mistress Mary]38-mary had known it , [they]769-they began to cheer up under the dark earth and work tremendously . The sun could get at [them]769-they and warm [them]769-they , and when the rain came down it could reach [them]769-they at once , so [they]769-they began to feel very much alive .

[Mary]38-mary was [an odd , determined little person]770-an odd , determined little person , and now [she]38-mary had something interesting to be determined about , [she]38-mary was very much absorbed , indeed . [She]38-mary worked and dug and pulled up weeds steadily , only becoming more pleased with [her]38-mary work every hour instead of tiring of it . It seemed to [her]38-mary like a fascinating sort of play . [She]38-mary found many more of the sprouting pale green points than [she]38-mary had ever hoped to find . They seemed to be starting up everywhere and each day [she]38-mary was sure [she]38-mary found tiny new ones , some so tiny that they barely peeped above the earth . There were so many that [she]38-mary remembered what [Martha]50-martha had said about the ' snowdrops by the thousands , " and about bulbs spreading and making new ones . These had been left to [themselves]769-they for ten years and perhaps they had spread , like the snowdrops , into thousands . [She]38-mary wondered how long it would be before [they]769-they showed that they were flowers . Sometimes [she]38-mary stopped digging to look at [the garden]146-the garden and try to imagine what it would be like when it was covered with thousands of lovely things in bloom . During that week of sunshine , [she]38-mary became more intimate with [Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff . [She]38-mary surprised [him]57-ben weatherstaff several times by seeming to start up beside [him]57-ben weatherstaff as if [she]38-mary sprang out of [the earth]490-the earth . The truth was that [she]38-mary was afraid that [he]57-ben weatherstaff would pick up [his]57-ben weatherstaff tools and go away if [he]57-ben weatherstaff saw [her]38-mary coming , so [she]38-mary always walked toward [him]57-ben weatherstaff as silently as possible . But , in fact , [he]57-ben weatherstaff did not object to [her]38-mary as strongly as [he]57-ben weatherstaff had at first . Perhaps [he]57-ben weatherstaff was secretly rather flattered by [her]38-mary evident desire for [his]57-ben weatherstaff elderly company . Then , also , [she]38-mary was more civil than [she]38-mary had been . [He]57-ben weatherstaff did not know that when [she]38-mary first saw [him]57-ben weatherstaff [she]38-mary spoke to [him]57-ben weatherstaff as [she]38-mary would have spoken to [a native]1904-a native , and had not known that [a cross , sturdy old Yorkshire man]2256-a cross , sturdy old yorkshire man was not accustomed to salaam to [[his]2256-a cross , sturdy old yorkshire man masters]2257-his masters , and be merely commanded by [them]2257-his masters to do things .[50-martha]

" Tha'rt like [th ' robin]2258-th ' robin , "[771-he] [he]771-he said to [her]772-her one morning when [he]771-he lifted [his]771-he head and saw [her]772-her standing by [him]771-he . " [I]771-he never knows when [I]771-he shall see [thee]2258-th ' robin or which side tha'll come from . "[771-he]

" [He]57-ben weatherstaff 's friends with [me]38-mary now , "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary .

" That 's like [him]57-ben weatherstaff , "[57-ben weatherstaff] snapped [Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff . " Makin ' up to [th ' women folk]2259-th ' women folk just for vanity an ' flightiness . There 's nothin' [he]57-ben weatherstaff would n't do for th ' sake o ' showin ' off an ' flirtin ' [his]57-ben weatherstaff tail - feathers . [He]57-ben weatherstaff 's as full o ' pride as an egg 's full o ' meat . "[57-ben weatherstaff]

[He]771-he very seldom talked much and sometimes did not even answer [Mary]38-mary 's questions except by a grunt , but this morning [he]771-he said more than usual . [He]771-he stood up and rested one hobnailed boot on the top of [his]771-he spade while [he]771-he looked [her]38-mary over .

" How long has [tha]2258-th ' robin ' been [here]1771-here ? "[771-he] [he]771-he jerked out .

" [I]38-mary think it 's about a month , "[38-mary] [she]38-mary answered .

" [Tha]58-tha 's beginnin ' to do Misselthwaite credit , "[771-he] [he]771-he said . " [Tha]58-tha 's a bit fatter than [tha]58-tha ' was an ' [tha 's not quite so yeller]2261-tha 's not quite so yeller . [Mary]38-mary was not vain and as [she]38-mary had never thought much of [her]38-mary looks [she]38-mary was not greatly disturbed .

" [I]38-mary know [I]38-mary 'm fatter , "[38-mary] [she]38-mary said . " [My]38-mary stockings are getting tighter . They used to make wrinkles . There 's the robin , [Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff . "[38-mary]

There , indeed , was the robin , and [she]38-mary thought [he]773-he looked nicer than ever . [His]773-he red waistcoat was as glossy as satin and [he]773-he flirted [his]773-he wings and tail and tilted [his]773-he head and hopped about with all sorts of lively graces . " Aye , there tha ' art ! "[57-ben weatherstaff] [he]57-ben weatherstaff said . " [Tha]2264-tha ' can put up with [me]57-ben weatherstaff for a bit sometimes when tha 's got [no one]145-no one better . "[57-ben weatherstaff]

" Oh ! look at [him]495-the robin ! "[38-mary] exclaimed [Mary]38-mary .

[The robin]495-the robin was evidently in a fascinating , bold mood . [He]495-the robin hopped closer and closer and looked at [Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff more and more engagingly . " [Tha]2264-tha ' thinks tha'll get over [me]57-ben weatherstaff by doin' that , "[57-ben weatherstaff] said [Ben]57-ben weatherstaff , wrinkling [his]57-ben weatherstaff face up in such a way that [Mary]38-mary felt sure [he]57-ben weatherstaff was trying not to look pleased . [The robin]495-the robin spread [his]495-the robin wings [Mary]38-mary could scarcely believe [her]38-mary eyes . [He]495-the robin flew right up to the handle of [Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff 's spade and alighted on the top of it . Then [the old man]481-the old man 's face wrinkled itself slowly into a new expression . [He]481-the old man spoke quite in a whisper .

" Well , [I]481-the old man 'm danged ! "[481-the old man] [he]481-the old man said as softly as if [he]481-the old man were saying something quite different . " Tha ' does know how to get at a chap [tha]2269-tha ' does ! Tha 's fair unearthly , tha 's so knowin ' . "[481-the old man]

And [he]481-the old man stood without stirring almost without drawing [his]481-the old man breath until the robin gave another flirt to [his]495-the robin wings and flew away . Then [he]481-the old man stood looking at the handle of the spade as if there might be Magic in it , and then [he]481-the old man began to dig again and said nothing for several minutes .

But because [he]481-the old man kept breaking into a slow grin now and then , [Mary]38-mary was not afraid to talk to [him]481-the old man .

" Have [you]481-the old man [a garden of [your]481-the old man own]2270-a garden of your own ? "[38-mary] [she]38-mary asked .

" No . [I]481-the old man 'm bachelder an ' lodge with [Martin]72-martin at th ' gate . "[481-the old man]

" But if [you]481-the old man wanted to make a flower garden , "[38-mary] persisted [Mary]38-mary , " what would [you]481-the old man plant ? "[38-mary]

[Mary]38-mary 's face lighted up .

[Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff rooted up a weed and threw it aside before [he]57-ben weatherstaff answered .

" Well , yes , [I]57-ben weatherstaff do . [I]57-ben weatherstaff was learned that by [a young lady]1906-a young lady [I]57-ben weatherstaff was [gardener to]2272-gardener to . " That were as much as ten year ' ago . "[57-ben weatherstaff]

" Where is [she]1906-a young lady now ? "[38-mary] asked [Mary]38-mary , much interested .

" Heaven , "[57-ben weatherstaff] [he]57-ben weatherstaff answered , and drove [his]57-ben weatherstaff spade deep into the soil , " ' cording to what [parson]2277-parson says . "[57-ben weatherstaff]

" What happened to the roses ? "[38-mary] [Mary]38-mary asked again , more interested than ever .

" [They]2278-they was left to [themselves]2278-they . "[57-ben weatherstaff]

[Mary]38-mary was becoming quite excited .

" Did [they]2278-they quite die ? Do roses quite die when they are left to [themselves]2278-they ? "[38-mary] [she]38-mary ventured .

" Well , [I]57-ben weatherstaff 'd got to like ['em]2279-'em an ' [I]57-ben weatherstaff liked [her]1906-a young lady an ' [she]1906-a young lady liked 'em , "[57-ben weatherstaff] [Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff admitted reluctantly . " Once or twice a year [I]57-ben weatherstaff 'd go an ' work at 'em a bit prune 'em an ' dig about th ' roots . [They]2278-they run wild , but they was in rich soil , so some of 'em lived . "[57-ben weatherstaff]

" When they have no leaves and look gray and brown and dry , how can [you]57-ben weatherstaff tell whether [they]2278-they are dead or alive ? "[38-mary] inquired [Mary]38-mary .

" Wait till th ' spring gets at 'em wait till th ' sun shines on th ' rain and th ' rain falls on th ' sunshine an ' then [tha'll]2280-tha'll find out . "[57-ben weatherstaff]

" How how ? "[38-mary] cried [Mary]38-mary , forgetting to be careful . " Look along th ' twigs an ' branches an ' if tha ' see a bit of a brown lump swelling here an ' there , watch it after th ' warm rain an ' see what happens . "[57-ben weatherstaff] [He]57-ben weatherstaff stopped suddenly and looked curiously at [her]38-mary eager face . " Why does tha ' care so much about roses an ' such , all of a sudden ? "[57-ben weatherstaff] [he]57-ben weatherstaff demanded .

[Mistress Mary]38-mary felt [her]38-mary face grow red . [She]38-mary was almost afraid to answer .

" [I]38-mary [I]38-mary want to play that that [I]38-mary have [a garden of [my]38-mary own]2281-a garden of my own , "[38-mary] [she]38-mary stammered . " [I]38-mary there is nothing for [me]38-mary to do . [I]38-mary have nothing and [no one]145-no one . "[38-mary]

" Well , "[57-ben weatherstaff] said [Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff slowly , as [he]57-ben weatherstaff watched [her]38-mary , " that 's true . [Tha]2283-tha ' has n't . "[57-ben weatherstaff]

[He]57-ben weatherstaff said it in such an odd way that [Mary]38-mary wondered if [he]57-ben weatherstaff was actually a little sorry for [her]38-mary . [She]38-mary had never felt sorry for [herself]38-mary ; [she]38-mary had only felt tired and cross , because [she]38-mary disliked [people]167-people and things so much . But now [the world]234-the world seemed to be changing and getting nicer . If [no one]145-no one found out about [the secret garden]1969-the secret garden , [she]38-mary should enjoy [herself]38-mary always .

[She]38-mary stayed with [him]57-ben weatherstaff for ten or fifteen minutes longer and asked [him]57-ben weatherstaff as many questions as [she]38-mary dared . [He]57-ben weatherstaff answered every one of them in [his]57-ben weatherstaff queer grunting way and [he]57-ben weatherstaff did not seem really cross and did not pick up [his]57-ben weatherstaff spade and leave [her]38-mary . [He]57-ben weatherstaff said something about roses just as [she]38-mary was going away and it reminded [her]38-mary of the ones [he]57-ben weatherstaff had said [he]57-ben weatherstaff had been fond of .

" Do [you]57-ben weatherstaff go and see those other roses now ? "[38-mary] [she]38-mary asked .

" Not been this year . [My]57-ben weatherstaff rheumatics has made [me]57-ben weatherstaff too stiff in th ' joints . "[57-ben weatherstaff]

[He]57-ben weatherstaff said it in [his]57-ben weatherstaff grumbling voice , and then quite suddenly [he]57-ben weatherstaff seemed to get angry with [her]38-mary , though [she]38-mary did not see why [he]57-ben weatherstaff should .

" Now look here ! "[57-ben weatherstaff] [he]57-ben weatherstaff said sharply . " Do n't tha ' ask so many questions . Tha'rt th ' worst wench for askin ' questions [I]57-ben weatherstaff 've ever come a cross . Get [thee]2284-thee gone an ' play [thee]2284-thee . [I]57-ben weatherstaff 've done talkin ' for today . "[57-ben weatherstaff]

And [he]57-ben weatherstaff said it so crossly that [she]38-mary knew there was not the least use in staying another minute . [She]38-mary went skipping slowly down [the outside walk]782-the outside walk , thinking [him]57-ben weatherstaff over and saying to [herself]38-mary that , queer as it was , here was [another person whom [she]38-mary liked in spite of [his]57-ben weatherstaff crossness]783-another person whom she liked in spite of his crossness . [She]38-mary liked [old Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff . Yes , [she]38-mary did like [him]57-ben weatherstaff . [She]38-mary always wanted to try to make [him]57-ben weatherstaff talk to [her]38-mary . Also [she]38-mary began to believe that [he]57-ben weatherstaff knew everything in [the world]234-the world about flowers .

There was a laurel - hedged walk which curved round [the secret garden]1969-the secret garden and ended at a gate which opened into a wood , in [the park]369-the park . [She]38-mary thought [she]38-mary would slip round [this walk]787-this walk and look into the wood and see if there were any rabbits hopping about . [She]38-mary enjoyed the skipping very much and when [she]38-mary reached the little gate [she]38-mary opened it and went through because [she]38-mary heard a low , peculiar whistling sound and wanted to find out what it was .

It was a very strange thing indeed . [She]38-mary quite caught [her]38-mary breath as [she]38-mary stopped to look at it . [A boy]155-a boy was sitting under a tree , with [his]155-a boy back against it , playing on a rough wooden pipe . [He]155-a boy was [a funny looking boy about twelve]789-a funny looking boy about twelve . [He]155-a boy looked very clean and [his]155-a boy nose turned up and [his]155-a boy cheeks were as red as poppies and never had [Mistress Mary]38-mary seen such round and such blue eyes in [any boy]790-any boy 's face . And on the trunk of the tree [he]155-a boy leaned against , a brown squirrel was clinging and watching [him]155-a boy , and from behind a bush nearby a cock pheasant was delicately stretching [his]155-a boy neck to peep out , and quite near [him]155-a boy were two rabbits sitting up and sniffing with tremulous noses and actually it appeared as if [they]791-they were all drawing near to watch [him]155-a boy and listen to the strange low little call [his]155-a boy pipe seemed to make .

When [he]155-a boy saw [Mary]38-mary [he]155-a boy held up [his]155-a boy hand and spoke to [her]38-mary in a voice almost as low as and rather like [his]155-a boy piping .

" Do n't [tha]2285-tha ' move , "[155-a boy] [he]155-a boy said . " It 'd flight 'em . "[155-a boy] [Mary]38-mary remained motionless . [He]155-a boy stopped playing [his]155-a boy pipe and began to rise from the ground . [He]155-a boy moved so slowly that it scarcely seemed as though [he]155-a boy were moving at all , but at last [he]155-a boy stood on [his]155-a boy feet and then the squirrel scampered back up into the branches of [his]155-a boy tree , the pheasant withdrew [his]155-a boy head and the rabbits dropped on all fours and began to hop away , though not at all as if [they]791-they were frightened .

" [I]792-the boy 'm [Dickon]54-dickon , "[792-the boy] [the boy]792-the boy said . " [I]792-the boy know tha'rt [Miss Mary]38-mary . "[792-the boy]

Then [Mary]38-mary realized that somehow [she]38-mary had known at first that [he]155-a boy was [Dickon]54-dickon . Who else could have been charming rabbits and pheasants as [the natives]642-the natives charm snakes in [India]2-india ? [He]155-a boy had a wide , red , curving mouth and [his]155-a boy smile spread all over [his]155-a boy face .

" [I]155-a boy got up slow , "[155-a boy] [he]155-a boy explained , " because if tha ' makes a quick move it startles ['em]2286-'em . A body ' as to move gentle an ' speak low when wild things is about . "[155-a boy]

[He]155-a boy did not speak to [her]38-mary as if [they]794-they had never seen [each other]241-each other before but as if [he]155-a boy knew [her]38-mary quite well . [Mary]38-mary knew nothing about [boys]1783-boys and [she]38-mary spoke to [him]155-a boy a little stiffly because [she]38-mary felt rather shy .

" Did [you]155-a boy get [Martha]50-martha 's letter ? "[38-mary] [she]38-mary asked .

[He]155-a boy nodded [his]155-a boy curly , rust - colored head . " That 's why [I]155-a boy come . "[155-a boy]

[He]155-a boy stooped to pick up something which had been lying on the ground beside [him]155-a boy when [he]155-a boy piped .

" [I]155-a boy 've got [th]2287-th ' garden tools . There 's a little spade an ' rake an ' a fork an ' hoe . Eh ! they are good ' uns . There 's a trowel , too . An ' [th ' woman in [th ' shop]2289-th ' shop]2288-th ' woman in th ' shop threw in a packet o ' white poppy an ' one o ' blue larkspur when [I]155-a boy bought th ' other seeds . "[155-a boy]

" Will [you]155-a boy show the seeds to [me]38-mary ? "[38-mary] [Mary]38-mary said .

[She]38-mary wished [she]38-mary could talk as [he]155-a boy did . [His]155-a boy speech was so quick and easy . It sounded as if [he]155-a boy liked [her]38-mary and was not the least afraid [she]38-mary would not like [him]155-a boy , though [he]155-a boy was only [a common moor boy]797-a common moor boy , in patched clothes and with a funny face and a rough , rusty - red head . As [she]38-mary came closer to [him]155-a boy [she]38-mary noticed that there was a clean fresh scent of heather and grass and leaves about [him]155-a boy , almost as if [he]155-a boy were made of them . [She]38-mary liked it very much and when [she]38-mary looked into [his]155-a boy funny face with the red cheeks and round blue eyes [she]38-mary forgot that [she]38-mary had felt shy .

" Let [us]798-us sit down on this log and look at them , "[38-mary] [she]38-mary said .

[They]798-us sat down and [he]155-a boy took a clumsy little brown paper package out of [his]155-a boy coat pocket . [He]155-a boy untied the string and inside there were ever so many neater and smaller packages with a picture of a flower on each one .

" There 's a lot o ' mignonette an ' poppies , "[155-a boy] [he]155-a boy said . " [Mignonette]73-mignonette 's th ' sweetest smellin ' thing as grows , an ' it 'll grow wherever [you]2290-you cast it , same as poppies will . [Them]2291-them as'll come up an ' bloom if [you]2290-you just whistle to ['em]2292-'em , [them]2291-them 's th ' nicest of all . "[155-a boy] [He]155-a boy stopped and turned [his]155-a boy head quickly , [his]155-a boy poppy - cheeked face lighting up .

" Where 's that robin as is callin ' [us]798-us ? "[155-a boy] [he]155-a boy said .

The chirp came from a thick holly bush , bright with scarlet berries , and [Mary]38-mary thought [she]38-mary knew whose it was .

" Is it really calling [us]798-us ? "[38-mary] [she]38-mary asked .

" Aye , "[54-dickon] said [Dickon]54-dickon , as if it was the most natural thing in [the world]234-the world , " [he]155-a boy 's callin ' [some one [he]155-a boy 's friends with]2293-some one he 's friends with . That 's same as sayin ' ' Here [I]54-dickon am . Look at [me]54-dickon . [I]54-dickon wants a bit of a chat . ' There [he]155-a boy is in the bush . Whose is [he]155-a boy ? "[54-dickon]

" [He]155-a boy 's [Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff 's , but [I]38-mary think [he]155-a boy knows [me]38-mary a little , "[38-mary] answered [Mary]38-mary .

" Aye , [he]155-a boy knows [thee]2294-thee , "[54-dickon] said [Dickon]54-dickon in [his]54-dickon low voice again . " An ' [he]155-a boy likes [thee]2294-thee . [He]155-a boy 's took [thee]2294-thee on . [He]155-a boy 'll tell [me]54-dickon all about [thee]2294-thee in a minute . "[54-dickon]

[He]54-dickon moved quite close to the bush with the slow movement [Mary]38-mary had noticed before , and then [he]54-dickon made a sound almost like [the robin]495-the robin 's own twitter . [The robin]495-the robin listened a few seconds , intently , and then answered quite as if [he]495-the robin were replying to a question .

" Aye , [he]155-a boy 's [a friend o ' yours]2295-a friend o ' yours , "[54-dickon] chuckled [Dickon]54-dickon .

" Do [you]54-dickon think [he]155-a boy is ? "[38-mary] cried [Mary]38-mary eagerly . [She]38-mary did so want to know . " Do [you]54-dickon think [he]155-a boy really likes [me]38-mary ? "[38-mary]

" [He]155-a boy would n't come near [thee]2294-thee if [he]155-a boy did n't , "[54-dickon] answered [Dickon]54-dickon . " [Birds]74-birds is rare choosers an ' [a robin]544-a robin can flout a body worse than [a man]1910-a man . See , [he]155-a boy 's making up to [thee]2294-thee now . ' Can not tha ' see [a chap]2298-a chap ? ' [he]155-a boy 's sayin ' . "[54-dickon]

And it really seemed as if it must be true . [He]54-dickon so sidled and twittered and tilted as [he]54-dickon hopped on [his]54-dickon bush .

" Do [you]54-dickon understand everything birds say ? "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary .

[Dickon]54-dickon 's grin spread until [he]54-dickon seemed all wide , red , curving mouth , and [he]54-dickon rubbed [his]54-dickon rough head .

" [I]54-dickon think [I]54-dickon do , and [they]2299-they think [I]54-dickon do , "[54-dickon] [he]54-dickon said . " [I]54-dickon 've lived on [th ' moor]1874-th ' moor with ['em]2301-'em so long . [I]54-dickon 've watched ['em]2301-'em break shell an ' come out an ' fledge an ' learn to fly an ' begin to sing , till [I]54-dickon think [I]54-dickon 'm one of 'em . Sometimes [I]54-dickon think p'raps [I]54-dickon 'm a bird , or a fox , or a rabbit , or a squirrel , or even a beetle , an ' [I]54-dickon do n't know it . "[54-dickon]

[He]54-dickon laughed and came back to the log and began to talk about the flower seeds again . [He]54-dickon told [her]802-her what they looked like when they were flowers ; [he]54-dickon told [her]802-her how to plant them , and watch them , and feed and water them .

" See here , "[54-dickon] [he]54-dickon said suddenly , turning round to look at [her]802-her . " [I]54-dickon 'll plant them for [thee]802-her [myself]54-dickon . Where is [tha ' garden]2302-tha ' garden ? "[54-dickon]

[Mary]38-mary 's thin hands clutched each other as they lay on [her]38-mary lap . [She]38-mary did not know what to say , so for a whole minute [she]38-mary said nothing . [She]38-mary had never thought of this . [She]38-mary felt miserable . And [she]38-mary felt as if [she]38-mary went red and then pale .

" Tha 's got a bit o ' garden , has n't tha ' ? "[54-dickon] [Dickon]54-dickon said .

It was true that [she]38-mary had turned red and then pale . [Dickon]54-dickon saw [her]38-mary do it , and as [she]38-mary still said nothing , [he]54-dickon began to be puzzled .

" Would n't [they]2303-they give [thee]38-mary a bit ? "[54-dickon] [he]54-dickon asked . " Has n't tha ' got any yet ? "[54-dickon]

[She]38-mary held [her]38-mary hands tighter and turned [her]38-mary eyes toward [him]54-dickon .

" [I]38-mary do n't know anything about [boys]1783-boys , "[38-mary] [she]38-mary said slowly . " Could [you]54-dickon keep a secret , if [I]38-mary told [you]54-dickon one ? It 's a great secret . [I]38-mary do n't know what [I]38-mary should do if [any one]189-any one found it out . [I]38-mary believe [I]38-mary should die ! "[38-mary] [She]38-mary said the last sentence quite fiercely .

[Dickon]54-dickon looked more puzzled than ever and even rubbed [his]54-dickon hand over [his]54-dickon rough head again , but [he]54-dickon answered quite good - humoredly . " [I]54-dickon 'm keepin ' secrets all th ' time , "[54-dickon] [he]54-dickon said . " If [I]54-dickon could n't keep secrets from [th ' other lads]2306-th ' other lads , secrets about foxes ' cubs , an ' birds ' nests , an ' wild things ' holes , there 'd be naught safe on [th ' moor]1874-th ' moor . Aye , [I]54-dickon can keep secrets . "[54-dickon]

[Mistress Mary]38-mary did not mean to put out [her]38-mary hand and clutch [his]54-dickon sleeve but [she]38-mary did it .

" [I]38-mary 've stolen [a garden]245-a garden , "[38-mary] [she]38-mary said very fast . " It is n't [mine]38-mary . It is n't [anybody]2309-anybody 's . [Nobody]175-nobody wants it , [nobody]175-nobody cares for it , [nobody]175-nobody ever goes into it . Perhaps everything is dead in it already . [I]38-mary do n't know . "[38-mary]

[She]38-mary began to feel hot and as contrary as [she]38-mary had ever felt in [her]38-mary life .

" [I]38-mary do n't care , [I]38-mary do n't care ! [Nobody]175-nobody has any right to take it from [me]38-mary when [I]38-mary care about it and [they]175-nobody do n't . [They]175-nobody 're letting it die , all shut in by itself , "[38-mary] [she]38-mary ended passionately , and [she]38-mary threw [her]38-mary arms over [her]38-mary face and burst out crying - poor little Mistress [Mary]38-mary .

[Dickon]54-dickon 's curious blue eyes grew rounder and rounder . " Eh - h - h ! "[54-dickon] [he]54-dickon said , drawing [his]54-dickon exclamation out slowly , and the way [he]54-dickon did it meant both wonder and sympathy .

" [I]38-mary 've nothing to do , "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary . " Nothing belongs to [me]38-mary . [I]38-mary found it [myself]38-mary and [I]38-mary got into it [myself]38-mary . [I]38-mary was only just like the robin , and [they]2314-they would n't take it from the robin . "[38-mary] " Where is it ? "[54-dickon] asked [Dickon]54-dickon in a dropped voice .

[Mistress Mary]38-mary got up from the log at once . [She]38-mary knew [she]38-mary felt contrary again , and obstinate , and [she]38-mary did not care at all . [She]38-mary was imperious and [Indian]75-indian , and at the same time hot and sorrowful .

" Come with [me]38-mary and [I]38-mary 'll show [you]54-dickon , "[38-mary] [she]38-mary said .

[She]38-mary led [him]54-dickon round [the laurel path]803-the laurel path and to the walk where the ivy grew so thickly . [Dickon]54-dickon followed [her]38-mary with a queer , almost pitying , look on [his]54-dickon face . [He]54-dickon felt as if [he]54-dickon were being led to look at some strange bird 's nest and must move softly . When [she]38-mary stepped to the wall and lifted the hanging ivy [he]54-dickon started . There was a door and [Mary]38-mary pushed it slowly open and [they]804-they passed in together , and then [Mary]38-mary stood and waved [her]38-mary hand round defiantly .

" It 's this , "[38-mary] [she]38-mary said . " [It]805-it 's [a secret garden]2315-a secret garden , and [I]38-mary 'm [the only one in [the world]234-the world who wants it to be alive]2316-the only one in the world who wants it to be alive . "[38-mary]

[Dickon]54-dickon looked round and round about [it]805-it , and round and round again .

" Eh ! "[54-dickon] [he]54-dickon almost whispered , " it is [a queer , pretty place]2318-a queer , pretty place ! It 's like as if a body was in a dream . "[54-dickon]

CHAPTER XI

[THE NEST OF THE MISSEL THRUSH]806-the nest of the missel thrush

For two or three minutes [he]54-dickon stood looking round [him]54-dickon , while [Mary]38-mary watched [him]54-dickon , and then [he]54-dickon began to walk about softly , even more lightly than [Mary]38-mary had walked the first time [she]38-mary had found [herself]38-mary inside the four walls . [His]54-dickon eyes seemed to be taking in everything the gray trees with the gray creepers climbing over them and hanging from their branches , the tangle on the walls and among the grass , the evergreen alcoves with the stone seats and tall flower urns standing in them .

" [I]54-dickon never thought [I]54-dickon 'd see [this place]1962-this place , "[54-dickon] [he]54-dickon said at last , in a whisper .

" Did [you]54-dickon know about [it]1962-this place ? "[38-mary] asked [Mary]38-mary .

[She]38-mary had spoken aloud and [he]54-dickon made a sign to [her]38-mary .

" [We]2320-us must talk low , "[54-dickon] [he]54-dickon said , " or some one'll hear [us]2320-us an ' wonder what 's to do in [here]1771-here . "[54-dickon]

" Oh ! [I]38-mary forgot ! "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary , feeling frightened and putting [her]38-mary hand quickly against [her]38-mary mouth . " Did [you]54-dickon know about [the garden]146-the garden ? "[38-mary] [she]38-mary asked again when [she]38-mary had recovered [herself]38-mary . [Dickon]54-dickon nodded .

" [Martha]50-martha told [me]54-dickon there was one as [no one]145-no one ever went inside , "[54-dickon] [he]54-dickon answered . " [Us]2320-us used to wonder what it was like . "[54-dickon]

[He]54-dickon stopped and looked round at the lovely gray tangle about [him]54-dickon , and [his]54-dickon round eyes looked queerly happy .

" Eh ! the nests as'll be here come springtime , "[54-dickon] [he]54-dickon said . " It 'd be [th ' safest nestin ' place in [England]3-england]2324-th ' safest nestin ' place in england . [No one]145-no one never comin ' near an ' tangles o ' trees an ' roses to build in . [I]54-dickon wonder all th ' birds on [th ' moor]1874-th ' moor do n't build [here]1771-here . "[54-dickon]

[Mistress Mary]38-mary put [her]38-mary hand on [his]54-dickon arm again without knowing it .

" Will there be roses ? "[38-mary] [she]38-mary whispered . " Can [you]54-dickon tell ? [I]38-mary thought perhaps [they]2328-they were all dead . "[38-mary]

" Eh ! No ! Not them not all of 'em ! "[54-dickon] [he]54-dickon answered . " Look here ! "[54-dickon]

[He]54-dickon stepped over to the nearest tree an old , old one with gray lichen all over its bark , but upholding a curtain of tangled sprays and branches . [He]54-dickon took a thick knife out of [his]54-dickon Pocket and opened one of its blades .

" There 's lots o ' dead wood as ought to be cut out , "[54-dickon] [he]54-dickon said . " An ' there 's a lot o ' old wood , but it made some new last year . This here 's a new bit , "[54-dickon] and [he]54-dickon touched a shoot which looked brownish green instead of hard , dry gray . [Mary]38-mary touched it [herself]38-mary in an eager , reverent way .

" That one ? "[38-mary] [she]38-mary said . " Is that one quite alive quite ? "[38-mary]

[Dickon]54-dickon curved [his]54-dickon wide smiling mouth .

" It 's as wick as [you]38-mary or [me]54-dickon , "[54-dickon] [he]54-dickon said ; and [Mary]38-mary remembered that [Martha]50-martha had told [her]38-mary that " wick "[50-martha] meant " alive "[50-martha] or " lively . "[50-martha]

" [I]38-mary 'm glad it 's wick ! "[38-mary] [she]38-mary cried out in [her]38-mary whisper . " [I]38-mary want [them]807-they all to be wick . Let [us]807-they go round [the garden]146-the garden and count how many wick ones there are . "[38-mary]

[She]38-mary quite panted with eagerness , and [Dickon]54-dickon was as eager as [she]38-mary was . [They]807-they went from tree to tree and from bush to bush . [Dickon]54-dickon carried [his]54-dickon knife in [his]54-dickon hand and showed [her]38-mary things which [she]38-mary thought wonderful .

" [They]807-they 've run wild , "[54-dickon] [he]54-dickon said , " but [th ' strongest ones]2330-th ' strongest ones has fair thrived on it . [The delicatest ones]2331-the delicatest ones has died out , but [th ' others]2332-th ' others has growed an ' growed , an ' spread an ' spread , till they 's a wonder . See here ! "[54-dickon] and [he]54-dickon pulled down a thick gray , dry - looking branch . " [A body]2333-a body might think this was dead wood , but [I]54-dickon do n't believe it is down to th ' root . [I]54-dickon 'll cut it low down an ' see . "[54-dickon]

[He]54-dickon knelt and with [his]54-dickon knife cut the lifeless - looking branch through , not far above the earth .

" There ! "[54-dickon] [he]54-dickon said exultantly . " [I]54-dickon told [thee]38-mary so . There 's green in that wood yet . Look at it . "[54-dickon]

[Mary]38-mary was down on [her]38-mary knees before [he]54-dickon spoke , gazing with all [her]38-mary might .

" When it looks a bit greenish an ' juicy like that , it 's wick , "[54-dickon] [he]54-dickon explained . " When th ' inside is dry an ' breaks easy , like this here piece [I]54-dickon 've cut off , it 's done for . There 's a big root here as all this live wood sprung out of , an ' if th ' old wood 's cut off an ' it 's dug round , and took care of there 'll be "[54-dickon] [he]54-dickon stopped and lifted [his]54-dickon face to look up at the climbing and hanging sprays above [him]54-dickon " there 'll be a fountain o ' roses here this summer . "[54-dickon]

[They]808-they went from bush to bush and from tree to tree . [He]54-dickon was very strong and clever with [his]54-dickon knife and knew how to cut the dry and dead wood away , and could tell when an unpromising bough or twig had still green life in it . In the course of half an hour [Mary]38-mary thought [she]38-mary could tell too , and when [he]54-dickon cut through a lifeless - looking branch [she]38-mary would cry out joyfully under [her]38-mary breath when [she]38-mary caught sight of the least shade of moist green . The spade , and hoe , and fork were very useful . [He]54-dickon showed [her]38-mary how to use the fork while [he]54-dickon dug about roots with the spade and stirred the earth and let the air in .

[They]808-they were working industriously round one of the biggest standard roses when [he]54-dickon caught sight of something which made [him]54-dickon utter an exclamation of surprise .

" Why ! "[54-dickon] [he]54-dickon cried , pointing to the grass a few feet away . " Who did that there ? "[54-dickon]

It was [one of [[Mary]38-mary 's own little clearings round [the pale green points]811-the pale green points]810-mary 's own little clearings round the pale green points]809-one of mary 's own little clearings round the pale green points .

" [I]38-mary did it , "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary .

" Why , [I]54-dickon thought [tha]54-dickon ' did n't know nothin' about gardenin ' , "[54-dickon] [he]54-dickon exclaimed .

" [I]38-mary do n't , "[38-mary] [she]38-mary answered , " but they were so little , and the grass was so thick and strong , and they looked as if [they]808-they had no room to breathe . So [I]38-mary made a place for [them]808-they . [I]38-mary do n't even know what they are . "[38-mary]

[Dickon]54-dickon went and knelt down by [them]808-they , smiling [his]54-dickon wide smile .

" Tha ' was right , "[54-dickon] [he]54-dickon said . " [A gardener]2334-a gardener could n't have told [thee]38-mary better . [They]808-they 'll grow now like [Jack]76-jack 's bean - stalk . [They]808-they 're crocuses an ' snowdrops , an ' these here is narcissuses , "[54-dickon] turning to another patch , " an here 's daffydowndillys . Eh ! they will be a sight . "[54-dickon]

[He]54-dickon ran from [one clearing]812-one clearing to another .

" [Tha]58-tha ' has done a lot o ' work for [such a little wench]2335-such a little wench , "[54-dickon] [he]54-dickon said , looking [her]38-mary over .

" [I]38-mary 'm growing fatter , "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary , " and [I]38-mary 'm growing stronger . [I]38-mary used always to be tired . When [I]38-mary dig [I]38-mary 'm not tired at all . [I]38-mary like to smell the earth when it 's turned up . "[38-mary]

" It 's rare good for [thee]38-mary , "[54-dickon] [he]54-dickon said , nodding [his]54-dickon head wisely . " There 's naught as nice as th ' smell o ' good clean earth , except th ' smell o ' fresh growin ' things when th ' rain falls on ['em]2336-'em . [I]54-dickon get out on [th ' moor]1874-th ' moor many a day when it 's rainin ' an ' [I]54-dickon lie under a bush an ' listen to th ' soft swish o ' drops on th ' heather an ' [I]54-dickon just sniff an ' sniff . [My]54-dickon nose end fair quivers like a rabbit 's , [mother]224-mother says . "[54-dickon]

" Do [you]54-dickon never catch cold ? "[38-mary] inquired [Mary]38-mary , gazing at [him]54-dickon wonderingly . [She]38-mary had never seen [such a funny boy]813-such a funny boy , or such [a nice one]814-a nice one .

" Not [me]54-dickon , "[54-dickon] [he]54-dickon said , grinning . " [I]54-dickon never ketched cold since [I]54-dickon was born . [I]54-dickon was n't brought up nesh enough . [I]54-dickon 've chased about th ' moor in all weathers same as [th ' rabbits]2339-th ' rabbits does . [Mother]53-mother says [I]54-dickon 've sniffed up too much fresh air for twelve year ' to ever get to sniffin ' with cold . [I]54-dickon 'm as tough as a white - thorn knobstick . "[54-dickon]

[He]54-dickon was working all the time [he]54-dickon was talking and [Mary]38-mary was following [him]54-dickon and helping [him]54-dickon with [her]38-mary fork or the trowel .

" There 's a lot of work to do [here]1771-here ! "[54-dickon] [he]54-dickon said once , looking about quite exultantly .

" Will [you]54-dickon come again and help [me]38-mary to do it ? "[38-mary] [Mary]38-mary begged . " [I]38-mary 'm sure [I]38-mary can help , too . [I]38-mary can dig and pull up weeds , and do whatever [you]54-dickon tell [me]38-mary . Oh ! do come , [Dickon]54-dickon ! "[38-mary]

" [I]54-dickon 'll come every day if tha ' wants [me]54-dickon , rain or shine , "[54-dickon] [he]54-dickon answered stoutly . " It 's the best fun [I]54-dickon ever had in [my]54-dickon life shut in here an ' wakenin ' up [a garden]245-a garden . "[54-dickon]

" If [you]54-dickon will come , "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary , " if [you]54-dickon will help [me]38-mary to make it alive [I]38-mary 'll [I]38-mary do n't know what [I]38-mary 'll do , "[38-mary] [she]38-mary ended helplessly . What could [you]815-you do for [a boy like that]816-a boy like that ?

" [I]54-dickon 'll tell [thee]815-you what tha'll do , "[54-dickon] said [Dickon]54-dickon , with [his]54-dickon happy grin . " [Tha'll]2342-tha'll get fat an ' [tha'll]2342-tha'll get as hungry as [a young fox]2343-a young fox an ' [tha'll]2342-tha'll learn how to talk to [th ' robin]2258-th ' robin same as [I]54-dickon do . Eh ! [we]2345-we 'll have a lot o ' fun . "[54-dickon]

[He]54-dickon began to walk about , looking up in the trees and at the walls and bushes with a thoughtful expression .

" [I]54-dickon would n't want to make [it]2346-it look like [a [gardener]2348-gardener 's garden]2347-a gardener 's garden , all clipped an ' spick an ' span , would [you]38-mary ? "[54-dickon] [he]54-dickon said . " It 's nicer like this with things runnin ' wild , an ' swingin ' an ' catchin ' hold of each other . "[54-dickon]

" Do n't let [us]2345-we make it tidy , "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary anxiously . " It would n't seem like [a secret garden]2315-a secret garden if [it]2346-it was tidy . "[38-mary]

[Dickon]54-dickon stood rubbing [his]54-dickon rusty - red head with a rather puzzled look . " It 's [a secret garden]2315-a secret garden sure enough , "[54-dickon] [he]54-dickon said , " but seems like [some one besides th ' robin]2351-some one besides th ' robin must have been in [it]2346-it since [it]2346-it was shut up ten year ' ago . "[54-dickon]

" But the door was locked and the key was buried , "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary . " [No one]145-no one could get in . "[38-mary]

" That 's true , "[54-dickon] [he]54-dickon answered . " It 's [a queer place]1831-a queer place . Seems to [me]54-dickon as if there 'd been a bit o ' prunin ' done here an ' there , later than ten year ' ago . "[54-dickon]

" But how could it have been done ? "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary .

[He]54-dickon was examining a branch of a standard rose and [he]54-dickon shook [his]54-dickon head .

" Aye ! how could it ! "[54-dickon] [he]54-dickon murmured . " With [th]2354-th ' door locked an ' th ' key buried . "[54-dickon]

[Mistress Mary]38-mary always felt that however many years [she]38-mary lived [she]38-mary should never forget that first morning when [[her]38-mary garden]1960-her garden began to grow . Of course , it did seem to begin to grow for [her]38-mary that morning . When [Dickon]54-dickon began to clear places to plant seeds , [she]38-mary remembered what [Basil]39-basil had sung at [her]38-mary when [he]39-basil wanted to tease [her]38-mary .

" Are there any flowers that look like bells ? "[38-mary] [she]38-mary inquired .

" Lilies o ' [th ' valley]2355-th ' valley does , "[54-dickon] [he]54-dickon answered , digging away with the trowel , " an ' there 's Canterbury bells , an ' campanulas . "[54-dickon]

" Let 's plant some , "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary . " There 's lilies o ' th , valley here already ; [I]38-mary saw 'em . [They]2356-they 'll have growed too close an ' [we]2357-we 'll have to separate 'em , but there 's plenty . Th ' other ones takes two years to bloom from seed , but [I]38-mary can bring [you]54-dickon some bits o ' plants from [[our]2357-we cottage garden]2358-our cottage garden . Why does tha ' want 'em ? "[38-mary]

Then [Mary]38-mary told [him]54-dickon about [Basil]39-basil and [[his]39-basil brothers]818-his brothers and sisters in [India]2-india and of how [she]38-mary had hated [them]819-they and of [their]819-they calling [her]38-mary " Mistress [Mary]38-mary Quite Contrary . "[819-they]

" [They]819-they used to dance round and sing at [me]38-mary . [They]819-they sang[38-mary]

' [Mistress Mary]38-mary , quite contrary , How does [[your]38-mary garden]1784-your garden grow ? With silver bells , and cockle shells , And marigolds all in a row . ' [I]0-i just remembered it and it made [me]0-i wonder if there were really flowers like silver bells . "[0-i]

[She]38-mary frowned a little and gave [her]38-mary trowel a rather spiteful dig into [the earth]490-the earth .

" [I]38-mary was n't as contrary as [they]819-they were . "[38-mary]

But [Dickon]54-dickon laughed .

" Eh ! "[54-dickon] [he]54-dickon said , and as [he]54-dickon crumbled the rich black soil [she]38-mary saw [he]54-dickon was sniffing up the scent of it . " There does n't seem to be no need for [no one to be contrary]2359-no one to be contrary when there 's flowers an ' such like , an ' such lots o ' friendly wild things runnin ' about makin ' [homes]2360-homes for [themselves]819-they , or buildin ' nests an ' singin ' an ' whistlin ' , does there ? "[54-dickon]

[Mary]38-mary , kneeling by [him]54-dickon holding the seeds , looked at [him]54-dickon and stopped frowning .

" [Dickon]54-dickon , "[38-mary] [she]38-mary said , " [you]54-dickon are as nice as [Martha]50-martha said [you]54-dickon were . [I]38-mary like [you]54-dickon , and [you]54-dickon make [the fifth person]2361-the fifth person . [I]38-mary never thought [I]38-mary should like [five people]2362-five people . "[38-mary]

[Dickon]54-dickon sat up on [his]54-dickon heels as [Martha]50-martha did when [she]50-martha was polishing the grate . [He]54-dickon did look funny and delightful , [Mary]38-mary thought , with [his]54-dickon round blue eyes and red cheeks and happy looking turned - up nose .

" [Only five folk]2363-only five folk as [tha]2364-tha ' likes ? "[54-dickon] [he]54-dickon said . " Who is [th ' other four]2365-th ' other four ? "[54-dickon]

" [[Your]54-dickon mother]2093-your mother and [Martha]50-martha , "[38-mary] [Mary]38-mary checked them off on [her]38-mary fingers , " and the robin and [Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff . "[38-mary]

[Dickon]54-dickon laughed so that [he]54-dickon was obliged to stifle the sound by putting [his]54-dickon arm over [his]54-dickon mouth .

" [I]54-dickon know [tha]2364-tha ' thinks [I]54-dickon 'm [a queer lad]2367-a queer lad , "[54-dickon] [he]54-dickon said , " but [I]54-dickon think [tha]2364-tha ' art [th ' queerest little lass [I]54-dickon ever saw]2368-th ' queerest little lass i ever saw . "[54-dickon]

Then [Mary]38-mary did a strange thing . [She]38-mary leaned forward and asked [him]54-dickon a question [she]38-mary had never dreamed of asking [any one]189-any one before . And [she]38-mary tried to ask it in [Yorkshire]50-martha because that was [his]54-dickon language , and in [India]2-india [a native]1904-a native was always pleased if [you]824-you knew [his]54-dickon speech .

" Does tha ' like [me]38-mary ? "[38-mary] [she]38-mary said .

" Eh ! "[54-dickon] [he]54-dickon answered heartily , " that [I]54-dickon does . [I]54-dickon likes [thee]38-mary wonderful , an ' so does [th ' robin]2258-th ' robin , [I]54-dickon do believe ! "[54-dickon]

" That 's two , then , "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary . " That 's two for [me]38-mary . "[38-mary]

And then [they]825-they began to work harder than ever and more joyfully . [Mary]38-mary was startled and sorry when [she]38-mary heard the big clock in [the courtyard]826-the courtyard strike the hour of [her]38-mary midday dinner .

" [I]38-mary shall have to go , "[38-mary] [she]38-mary said mournfully . " And [you]54-dickon will have to go too , wo n't [you]54-dickon ? "[38-mary]

[Dickon]54-dickon grinned .

" [My]54-dickon dinner 's easy to carry about with [me]54-dickon , "[54-dickon] [he]54-dickon said . " [Mother]53-mother always lets [me]54-dickon put a bit o ' somethin' in [my]54-dickon pocket . "[54-dickon]

[He]54-dickon picked up [his]54-dickon coat from the grass and brought out of a pocket a lumpy little bundle tied up in a quite clean , coarse , blue and white handkerchief . It held two thick pieces of bread with a slice of something laid between them .

" It 's oftenest naught but bread , "[54-dickon] [he]54-dickon said , " but [I]54-dickon 've got a fine slice o ' fat bacon with it today . "[54-dickon]

[Mary]38-mary thought it looked a queer dinner , but [he]54-dickon seemed ready to enjoy it .

" Run on an ' get [thy]2370-thy victuals , "[54-dickon] [he]54-dickon said . " [I]54-dickon 'll be done with [mine]54-dickon first . [I]54-dickon 'll get some more work done before [I]54-dickon start back [home]1785-home . "[54-dickon]

[He]54-dickon sat down with [his]54-dickon back against a tree .

" [I]54-dickon 'll call th ' robin up , "[54-dickon] [he]54-dickon said , " and give [him]54-dickon th ' rind o ' th ' bacon to peck at . [They]2372-they likes a bit o ' fat wonderful . "[54-dickon]

[Mary]38-mary could scarcely bear to leave [him]54-dickon . Suddenly it seemed as if [he]54-dickon might be a sort of wood fairy who might be gone when [she]38-mary came into [the garden]146-the garden again . [He]54-dickon seemed too good to be true . [She]38-mary went slowly half - way to the door in the wall and then [she]38-mary stopped and went back .

" Whatever happens , [you]54-dickon [you]54-dickon never would tell ? "[38-mary] [she]38-mary said .

[His]54-dickon poppy - colored cheeks were distended with [his]54-dickon first big bite of bread and bacon , but [he]54-dickon managed to smile encouragingly .

" If tha ' was [a missel thrush]2373-a missel thrush an ' showed [me]54-dickon where [thy]54-dickon nest was , does [tha]54-dickon ' think [I]54-dickon 'd tell [any one]189-any one ? Not [me]54-dickon , "[54-dickon] [he]54-dickon said . " [Tha]54-dickon ' art as safe as [a missel thrush]2373-a missel thrush . "[54-dickon]

And [she]38-mary was quite sure [she]38-mary was .

[CHAPTER XII]77-chapter xii

" MIGHT [I]38-mary HAVE A BIT OF EARTH ? "[38-mary]

[Mary]38-mary ran so fast that [she]38-mary was rather out of breath when [she]38-mary reached [[her]38-mary room]1871-her room . [Her]38-mary hair was ruffled on [her]38-mary forehead and [her]38-mary cheeks were bright pink . [Her]38-mary dinner was waiting on the table , and [Martha]50-martha was waiting near [it]829-it .

" Tha 's a bit late , "[38-mary] [she]38-mary said . " Where has [tha]54-dickon ' been ? "[38-mary]

" [I]38-mary 've seen [Dickon]54-dickon ! "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary . " [I]38-mary 've seen [Dickon]54-dickon ! "[38-mary]

" [I]50-martha knew [he]54-dickon 'd come , "[50-martha] said [Martha]50-martha exultantly . " How does [tha]54-dickon ' like [him]54-dickon ? "[50-martha]

" [I]38-mary think [I]38-mary think [he]54-dickon 's beautiful ! "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary in a determined voice .

[Martha]50-martha looked rather taken aback but [she]50-martha looked pleased , too .

" Well , "[50-martha] [she]50-martha said , " [he]54-dickon 's [th ' best lad as ever]2376-th ' best lad as ever was born , but [us]54-dickon never thought [he]54-dickon was handsome . [His]54-dickon nose turns up too much . "[50-martha]

" [I]38-mary like it to turn up , "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary .

" An ' [his]54-dickon eyes is so round , "[50-martha] said [Martha]50-martha , a trifle doubtful . " Though they 're a nice color . "[50-martha] " [I]38-mary like them round , "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary . " And they are exactly the color of the sky over [the moor]1835-the moor . "[38-mary]

[Martha]50-martha beamed with satisfaction .

" [Mother]53-mother says [he]54-dickon made 'em that color with always lookin ' up at [th ' birds]2378-th ' birds an ' th ' clouds . But [he]54-dickon has got a big mouth , has n't [he]54-dickon , now ? "[50-martha]

" [I]38-mary love [his]54-dickon big mouth , "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary obstinately . " [I]38-mary wish [mine]38-mary were just like it . "[38-mary]

[Martha]50-martha chuckled delightedly .

" It 'd look rare an ' funny in [thy]50-martha bit of a face , "[50-martha] [she]50-martha said . " But [I]50-martha knowed it would be that way when [tha]50-martha ' saw [him]54-dickon . How did [tha]50-martha ' like th ' seeds an ' th ' garden tools ? "[50-martha]

" How did [you]50-martha know [he]54-dickon brought them ? "[38-mary] asked [Mary]38-mary .

" Eh ! [I]38-mary never thought of [him]54-dickon not bringin ' ['em]2379-'em . [He]54-dickon 'd be sure to bring ['em]2379-'em if [they]2379-'em was in [Yorkshire]50-martha . [He]54-dickon 's such [a trusty lad]2380-a trusty lad . "[38-mary]

[Mary]38-mary was afraid that [she]38-mary might begin to ask difficult questions , but [she]38-mary did not . [She]38-mary was very much interested in the seeds and gardening tools , and there was only one moment when [Mary]38-mary was frightened . This was when [she]38-mary began to ask where the flowers were to be planted .

" Who did [tha]2381-tha ' ask about it ? "[38-mary] [she]38-mary inquired .

" [I]38-mary have n't asked [anybody]2309-anybody yet , "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary , hesitating . " Well , [I]38-mary would n't ask [th ' head gardener]1987-th ' head gardener . [He]54-dickon 's too grand , [Mr. Roach]78-mr. roach is . "[38-mary]

" [I]38-mary 've never seen [him]54-dickon , "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary . " [I]38-mary 've only seen [undergardeners]2384-undergardeners and [Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff . "[38-mary]

" If [I]50-martha was [you]38-mary , [I]50-martha 'd ask [Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff , "[50-martha] advised [Martha]50-martha . " [He]57-ben weatherstaff 's not half as bad as [he]57-ben weatherstaff looks , for all [he]57-ben weatherstaff 's so crabbed . [Mr. Craven]41-mr. craven lets [him]57-ben weatherstaff do what [he]57-ben weatherstaff likes because [he]57-ben weatherstaff was here when [Mrs. Craven]59-mrs. craven was alive , an ' [he]57-ben weatherstaff used to make [her]59-mrs. craven laugh . [She]59-mrs. craven liked [him]57-ben weatherstaff . Perhaps [he]57-ben weatherstaff 'd find [you]38-mary a corner somewhere out o ' the way . "[50-martha]

" If it was out of the way and [no one]145-no one wanted it , [no one]145-no one could mind [my]38-mary having it , could [they]2387-they ? "[38-mary] [Mary]38-mary said anxiously .

" There would n't be no reason , "[50-martha] answered [Martha]50-martha . " [You]38-mary would n't do no harm . "[50-martha]

[Mary]38-mary ate [her]38-mary dinner as quickly as [she]38-mary could and when [she]38-mary rose from the table [she]38-mary was going to run to [[her]38-mary room]1871-her room to put on [her]38-mary hat again , but [Martha]50-martha stopped [her]38-mary .

" [I]50-martha 've got somethin' to tell [you]38-mary , "[50-martha] [she]50-martha said . " [I]50-martha thought [I]50-martha 'd let [you]38-mary eat [your]38-mary dinner first . [Mary]38-mary turned quite pale .

" Oh ! "[38-mary] [she]38-mary said . " Why ! Why ! [He]41-mr. craven did n't want to see [me]38-mary when [I]38-mary came . [I]38-mary heard [Pitcher]49-pitcher say [he]41-mr. craven did n't . "[38-mary] " Well , "[50-martha] explained [Martha]50-martha , " [Mrs. Medlock]45-mrs. medlock says it 's because o ' [mother]224-mother .
