" There are [snake - charmers]2880-snake - charmers in [India]2-india , "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary . " And [they]2880-snake - charmers can put [their]2880-snake - charmers snakes ' heads in [their]2880-snake - charmers mouths . "[38-mary]

" Goodness ! "[2532-the nurse] shuddered [the nurse]2532-the nurse .

[They]1179-they ate [their]1179-they breakfast with the morning air pouring in upon [them]1179-they . [Colin]81-colin 's breakfast was a very good one and [Mary]38-mary watched [him]81-colin with serious interest .

" [You]81-colin will begin to get fatter just as [I]38-mary did , "[38-mary] [she]38-mary said . " [I]38-mary never wanted [my]38-mary breakfast when [I]38-mary was in [India]2-india and now [I]38-mary always want it . "[38-mary]

" [I]81-colin wanted [mine]81-colin this morning , "[81-colin] said [Colin]81-colin . " Perhaps it was the fresh air . When do [you]81-colin think [Dickon]54-dickon will come ? "[81-colin]

[He]81-colin was not long in coming . In about ten minutes [Mary]38-mary held up [her]38-mary hand .

" Listen ! "[38-mary] [she]38-mary said . " Did [you]81-colin hear a caw ? "[38-mary]

[Colin]81-colin listened and heard it , the oddest sound in [the world]234-the world to hear inside [a house]1181-a house , a hoarse " caw - caw . "[38-mary]

" Yes , "[81-colin] [he]81-colin answered .

" That 's Soot , "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary . " Listen again . Do [you]81-colin hear a bleat a tiny one ? "[38-mary]

" Oh , yes ! "[81-colin] cried [Colin]81-colin , quite flushing .

" That 's [the new - born lamb]2881-the new - born lamb , "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary . " [He]54-dickon 's coming . "[38-mary]

[Dickon]54-dickon 's moorland boots were thick and clumsy and though [he]54-dickon tried to walk quietly they made a clumping sound as [he]54-dickon walked through [the long corridors]619-the long corridors . [Mary]38-mary and [Colin]81-colin heard [him]54-dickon marching marching , until [he]54-dickon passed through the tapestry door on to the soft carpet of [[Colin]81-colin 's own passage]1183-colin 's own passage .

" If [you]81-colin please , [sir]2395-sir , "[50-martha] announced [Martha]50-martha , opening the door , " if [you]81-colin please , [sir]2395-sir , here 's [Dickon]54-dickon an ' [[his]54-dickon creatures]2884-his creatures . "[50-martha]

[Dickon]54-dickon came in smiling [his]54-dickon nicest wide smile . [The new - born lamb]2881-the new - born lamb was in [his]81-colin arms and the little red fox trotted by [his]81-colin side . [Nut]61-soot sat on [his]81-colin left shoulder and Soot on [his]81-colin right and [Shell]61-soot 's head and paws peeped out of [his]81-colin coat pocket .

[Colin]81-colin slowly sat up and stared and stared as [he]81-colin had stared when [he]81-colin first saw [Mary]38-mary ; but this was a stare of wonder and delight . The truth was that in spite of all [he]81-colin had heard [he]81-colin had not in the least understood what [this boy]1185-this boy would be like and that [his]81-colin fox and [his]81-colin crow and [his]81-colin squirrels and [his]81-colin lamb were so near to [him]81-colin and [his]81-colin friendliness that [they]1186-they seemed almost to be part of [himself]81-colin . [Colin]81-colin had never talked to [a boy]155-a boy in [his]81-colin life and [he]81-colin was so overwhelmed by [his]81-colin own pleasure and curiosity that [he]81-colin did not even think of speaking .

But [Dickon]54-dickon did not feel the least shy or awkward . [He]54-dickon had not felt embarrassed because the crow had not known [his]54-dickon language and had only stared and had not spoken to [him]54-dickon the first time [they]1188-they met . [Creatures]1189-creatures were always like that until [they]1189-creatures found out about [you]1190-you . [He]54-dickon walked over to [Colin]81-colin 's sofa and put [the new - born lamb]2881-the new - born lamb quietly on [his]54-dickon lap , and immediately [the little creature]1192-the little creature turned to the warm velvet dressing - gown and began to nuzzle and nuzzle into its folds and butt [its]1192-the little creature tight - curled head with soft impatience against [his]54-dickon side . Of course [no boy]1193-no boy could have helped speaking then .

" What is it doing ? "[81-colin] cried [Colin]81-colin . " What does it want ? "[81-colin]

" [It]1192-the little creature wants [[its]1192-the little creature mother]1932-its mother , "[54-dickon] said [Dickon]54-dickon , smiling more and more . " [I]54-dickon brought it to [thee]81-colin a bit hungry because [I]54-dickon knowed tha'd like to see [it]1192-the little creature feed . "[54-dickon]

[He]54-dickon knelt down by the sofa and took a feeding - bottle from [his]54-dickon pocket .

" Come on , [little ' un]2886-little ' un , "[54-dickon] [he]54-dickon said , turning the small woolly white head with a gentle brown hand . " This is what tha 's after . [Tha'll]95-tha'll get more out o ' this than [tha]95-tha'll ' will out o ' silk velvet coats . There now , "[54-dickon] and [he]54-dickon pushed the rubber tip of the bottle into the nuzzling mouth and the lamb began to suck it with ravenous ecstasy .

After that there was no wondering what to say . By the time [the lamb]1194-the lamb fell asleep questions poured forth and [Dickon]54-dickon answered [them]1195-them all . [He]54-dickon told [them]1196-them how [he]54-dickon had found [the lamb]1194-the lamb just as the sun was rising three mornings ago . [He]54-dickon had been standing on [the moor]1835-the moor listening to a skylark and watching [him]1194-the lamb swing higher and higher into the sky until [he]1194-the lamb was only a speck in the heights of blue .

" [I]1199-i 'd almost lost [him]1194-the lamb but for [his]1194-the lamb song an ' [I]1199-i was wonderin ' how [a chap]2298-a chap could hear it when it seemed as if [he]2298-a chap 'd get out o ' [th ' world]2220-th ' world in a minute an ' just then [I]1199-i heard somethin' else far off among th ' gorse bushes . It was a weak bleatin ' an ' [I]1199-i knowed it was a new lamb as was hungry an ' [I]1199-i knowed it would n't be hungry if [it]1194-the lamb had n't lost [[its]1194-the lamb mother]1932-its mother somehow , so [I]1199-i set off searchin ' . Eh ! [I]1199-i did have a look for it . [I]1199-i went in an ' out among [th ' gorse bushes]2890-th ' gorse bushes an ' round an ' round an ' [I]1199-i always seemed to take th ' wrong turnin ' . But at last [I]1199-i seed a bit o ' white by a rock on top o ' [th ' moor]1874-th ' moor an ' [I]1199-i climbed up an ' found th ' little ' un half dead wi ' cold an ' clemmin ' . "[1199-i] While [he]1199-i talked , [Soot]61-soot flew solemnly in and out of the open window and cawed remarks about [the scenery]1200-the scenery while [Nut]61-soot and [Shell]61-soot made excursions into the big trees outside and ran up and down trunks and explored branches . [Captain]47-captain curled up near [Dickon]54-dickon , who sat on the hearth - rug from preference .

[They]1201-they looked at the pictures in the gardening books and [Dickon]54-dickon knew all the flowers by [their]1202-their country names and knew exactly which ones were already growing in [the secret garden]1969-the secret garden .

" [I]54-dickon couldna ' say that there name , "[54-dickon] [he]54-dickon said , pointing to one under which was written " Aquilegia , "[54-dickon] " but [us]1201-they calls that a columbine , an ' that there one it 's a snapdragon and [they]1201-they both grow wild in hedges , but these is garden ones an ' they 're bigger an ' grander . There 's some big clumps o ' columbine in [th ' garden]2035-th ' garden . They 'll look like a bed o ' blue an ' white butterflies flutterin ' when they 're out . "[54-dickon]

" [I]81-colin 'm going to see [them]1201-they , "[81-colin] cried [Colin]81-colin . " [I]81-colin am going to see [them]1201-they ! "[81-colin]

" Aye , [that tha ' mun]2893-that tha ' mun , "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary quite seriously . " An ' [tha ' munnot]2894-tha ' munnot lose no time about it . "[38-mary]

[CHAPTER XX]96-chapter xx

" [I]81-colin SHALL LIVE FOREVER AND EVER AND EVER ! "[81-colin]

But [they]1201-they were obliged to wait more than a week because first there came some very windy days and then [Colin]81-colin was threatened with a cold , which two things happening one after the other would no doubt have thrown [him]81-colin into a rage but that there was so much careful and mysterious planning to do and almost every day [Dickon]54-dickon came in , if only for a few minutes , to talk about what was happening on [the moor]1835-the moor and in [the lanes]2864-the lanes and hedges and on the borders of [streams]1206-streams . The things [he]54-dickon had to tell about [otters]1207-otters ' and [badgers]1208-badgers ' and [[water - rats]1209-water - rats ' houses]1210-water - rats ' houses , not to mention birds ' nests and field - mice and [[their]1211-their burrows]1212-their burrows , were enough to make [you]1213-you almost tremble with excitement when [you]1213-you heard all the intimate details from [an animal charmer]2877-an animal charmer and realized with what thrilling eagerness and anxiety the whole busy underworld was working .

" [They]2895-they 're same as [us]2896-us , "[54-dickon] said [Dickon]54-dickon , " only [they]2895-they have to build [[their]2895-they homes]2897-their homes every year . An ' it keeps ['em]2895-they so busy [they]2895-they fair scuffle to get 'em done . "[54-dickon]

The most absorbing thing , however , was the preparations to be made before [Colin]81-colin could be transported with sufficient secrecy to [the garden]146-the garden . [No one]145-no one must see [the chair - carriage]1217-the chair - carriage and [Dickon]54-dickon and [Mary]38-mary after [they]1218-they turned a certain corner of the shrubbery and entered upon the walk outside the ivied walls . As each day passed , [Colin]81-colin had become more and more fixed in [his]81-colin feeling that the mystery surrounding [the garden]146-the garden was one of its greatest charms . Nothing must spoil that . [No one]145-no one must ever suspect that [they]1218-they had a secret . [People]167-people must think that [he]81-colin was simply going out with [Mary]38-mary and [Dickon]54-dickon because [he]81-colin liked [them]1218-they and did not object to [their]1218-they looking at [him]81-colin . [They]1218-they had long and quite delightful talks about [their]1218-they route . [They]1218-they would go up [this path]1222-this path and down that one and cross the other and go round among the fountain flower - beds as if [they]1218-they were looking at the " bedding - out plants "[1223-the head gardener] [the head gardener]1223-the head gardener , [Mr. Roach]78-mr. roach , had been having arranged . That would seem such a rational thing to do that [no one]145-no one would think it at all mysterious . [They]1218-they would turn into [the shrubbery walks]1225-the shrubbery walks and lose [themselves]1218-they until [they]1218-they came to the long walls . It was almost as serious and elaborately thought out as the plans of march made by [great generals in time of war]1226-great generals in time of war .

Rumors of the new and curious things which were occurring in [[the invalid]1164-the invalid 's apartments]1228-the invalid 's apartments had of course filtered through [[the servants]162-the servants ' hall]1163-the servants ' hall into [the stable yards]1231-the stable yards and out among [the gardeners]902-the gardeners , but notwithstanding this , [Mr. Roach]78-mr. roach was startled one day when [he]78-mr. roach received orders from [[Master Colin]81-colin 's room]1233-master colin 's room to the effect that [he]78-mr. roach must report [himself]78-mr. roach in [the apartment]1234-the apartment [no outsider]1235-no outsider had ever seen , as [the invalid]1164-the invalid [himself]1164-the invalid desired to speak to [him]78-mr. roach .

" Well , well , "[78-mr. roach] [he]78-mr. roach said to [himself]78-mr. roach as [he]78-mr. roach hurriedly changed [his]78-mr. roach coat , " what 's to do now ? [[His]792-the boy Royal Highness that was n't to be looked at calling up [a man [he]792-the boy 's never set eyes on]2899-a man he 's never set eyes on]2898-his royal highness that was n't to be looked at calling up a man he 's never set eyes on . "[78-mr. roach]

[Mr. Roach]78-mr. roach was not without curiosity . [He]78-mr. roach had never caught even a glimpse of [the boy]792-the boy and had heard a dozen exaggerated stories about [his]792-the boy uncanny looks and ways and [his]792-the boy insane tempers . The thing [he]78-mr. roach had heard oftenest was that [he]792-the boy might die at any moment and there had been numerous fanciful descriptions of a humped back and helpless limbs , given by [people who had never seen [him]792-the boy]1238-people who had never seen him .

" Things are changing in [this house]2900-this house , [Mr. Roach]78-mr. roach , "[45-mrs. medlock] said [Mrs. Medlock]45-mrs. medlock , as [she]45-mrs. medlock led [him]78-mr. roach up the back staircase to [the corridor on to which opened [the hitherto mysterious chamber]1240-the hitherto mysterious chamber]1239-the corridor on to which opened the hitherto mysterious chamber .

" Let 's hope [they]2901-they 're changing for the better , [Mrs. Medlock]45-mrs. medlock , "[78-mr. roach] [he]78-mr. roach answered .

" [They]2901-they could n't well change for the worse , "[45-mrs. medlock] [she]45-mrs. medlock continued ; " and queer as it all is there 's [them]2901-they as finds [their]2901-they duties made a lot easier to stand up under . Do n't [you]78-mr. roach be surprised , [Mr. Roach]78-mr. roach , if [you]78-mr. roach find [yourself]78-mr. roach in the middle of a menagerie and [Martha Sowerby]50-martha 's [Dickon]54-dickon more at [home]1785-home than [you]78-mr. roach or [me]45-mrs. medlock could ever be . "[45-mrs. medlock]

There really was a sort of Magic about [Dickon]54-dickon , as [Mary]38-mary always privately believed . When [Mr. Roach]78-mr. roach heard [his]54-dickon name [he]78-mr. roach smiled quite leniently .

" [He]54-dickon 'd be at [home]1785-home in [Buckingham Palace]17-buckingham palace or at the bottom of [a coal mine]2904-a coal mine , "[78-mr. roach] [he]78-mr. roach said . " And yet it 's not impudence , either . [He]54-dickon 's just fine , is [that lad]2905-that lad . "[78-mr. roach]

It was perhaps well [he]78-mr. roach had been prepared or [he]78-mr. roach might have been startled . When the bedroom door was opened a large crow , which seemed quite at home perched on the high back of a carven chair , announced the entrance of [a visitor]1241-a visitor by saying " Caw Caw "[78-mr. roach] quite loudly . In spite of [Mrs. Medlock]45-mrs. medlock 's warning , [Mr. Roach]78-mr. roach only just escaped being sufficiently undignified to jump backward .

[The young Rajah]90-the rajah was neither in bed nor on [his]90-the rajah sofa . [He]90-the rajah was sitting in an armchair and a young lamb was standing by [him]90-the rajah shaking its tail in feeding - lamb fashion as [Dickon]54-dickon knelt giving [it]54-dickon milk from [its]54-dickon bottle . A squirrel was perched on [Dickon]54-dickon 's bent back attentively nibbling a nut . [The little girl from [India]2-india]1242-the little girl from india was sitting on a big footstool looking on .

" Here is [Mr. Roach]78-mr. roach , [Master Colin]81-colin , "[45-mrs. medlock] said [Mrs. Medlock]45-mrs. medlock .

[The young Rajah]90-the rajah turned and looked [his]90-the rajah servitor over at least that was what [the head gardener]1223-the head gardener felt happened .

" Oh , [you]78-mr. roach are [Roach]78-mr. roach , are [you]78-mr. roach ? "[1223-the head gardener] [he]1223-the head gardener said . " [I]1223-the head gardener sent for [you]78-mr. roach to give [you]78-mr. roach some very important orders . "[1223-the head gardener]

" Very good , [sir]2395-sir , "[78-mr. roach] answered [Roach]78-mr. roach , wondering if [he]78-mr. roach was to receive instructions to fell all the oaks in [the park]369-the park or to transform [the orchards]1245-the orchards into [water - gardens]1246-water - gardens .

" [I]81-colin am going out in [my]81-colin chair this afternoon , "[81-colin] said [Colin]81-colin . " If the fresh air agrees with [me]81-colin [I]81-colin may go out every day . " [Mary]38-mary , "[81-colin] said [Colin]81-colin , turning to [her]1248-you , " what is that thing [you]1248-you say in [India]2-india when [you]1248-you have finished talking and want [people]167-people to go ? " Caw Caw ! "[1249-the crow] remarked [the crow]1249-the crow hoarsely but not impolitely .

" [My]78-mr. roach word ! "[78-mr. roach] [he]78-mr. roach said , " [he]78-mr. roach 's got a fine lordly way with [him]78-mr. roach , has n't [he]78-mr. roach ? [Dickon]54-dickon went back to [the garden]146-the garden with [[his]54-dickon creatures]2884-his creatures and [Mary]38-mary stayed with [Colin]81-colin . " [The garden]146-the garden ? "[38-mary] asked [Mary]38-mary .

" [I]38-mary never saw it in [India]2-india because there was n't any , "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary .

Shut in and morbid as [his]81-colin life had been , [Colin]81-colin had more imagination than [she]38-mary had and at least [he]81-colin had spent a good deal of time looking at wonderful books and pictures .

" That morning when [you]81-colin ran in and said ' It 's come ! It 's come ! ' , [you]81-colin made [me]38-mary feel quite queer . It sounded as if things were coming with a great procession and big bursts and wafts of music . [I]38-mary 've a picture like it in one of [my]38-mary books crowds of [lovely people]2926-lovely people and [children]1816-children with garlands and branches with blossoms on [them]1816-children , [everyone laughing and dancing and crowding and playing on pipes]2928-everyone laughing and dancing and crowding and playing on pipes . " How funny ! "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary . " That 's really just what it feels like . And if all the flowers and leaves and green things and birds and wild creatures danced past at once , what [a crowd]2929-a crowd it would be ! [I]38-mary 'm sure [they]1257-they 'd dance and sing and flute and that would be the wafts of music . "[38-mary]

[They]1257-they both laughed but it was not because the idea was laughable but because [they]1257-they both so liked it .

A little later [the nurse]2532-the nurse made [Colin]81-colin ready . [She]38-mary noticed that instead of lying like a log while [his]81-colin clothes were put on [he]81-colin sat up and made some efforts to help [himself]81-colin , and [he]81-colin talked and laughed with [Mary]38-mary all the time .

" This is one of [his]81-colin good days , [sir]2395-sir , "[38-mary] [she]38-mary said to [Dr. Craven]86-dr. craven , who dropped in to inspect [him]81-colin . " [He]81-colin 's in such good spirits that it makes [him]81-colin stronger . "[38-mary]

" [I]86-dr. craven 'll call in again later in the afternoon , after [he]81-colin has come in , "[86-dr. craven] said [Dr. Craven]86-dr. craven . " [I]2532-the nurse 'd rather give up the case this moment , [sir]2395-sir , than even stay [here]1771-here while it 's suggested , "[2532-the nurse] answered [the nurse]2532-the nurse . With sudden firmness .

" [I]2517-the doctor had n't really decided to suggest it , "[2517-the doctor] said [the doctor]2517-the doctor , with [his]2517-the doctor slight nervousness . " [We]2933-we 'll try the experiment .
