[The strongest footman in [the house]166-the house]1261-the strongest footman in the house carried [Colin]81-colin down stairs and put [him]81-colin in [his]81-colin wheeled chair near which [Dickon]54-dickon waited outside . After [the manservant]1263-the manservant had arranged [his]1263-the manservant rugs and cushions [the Rajah]1264-the rajah waved [his]1264-the rajah hand to [him]81-colin and to [the nurse]2532-the nurse .

" [You]2532-the nurse have [my]1264-the rajah permission to go , "[1264-the rajah] [he]1264-the rajah said , and [they]1266-they both disappeared quickly and it must be confessed giggled when [they]1266-they were safely inside [the house]166-the house .

[Dickon]54-dickon began to push the wheeled chair slowly and steadily . [Mistress Mary]38-mary walked beside it and [Colin]81-colin leaned back and lifted [his]81-colin face to the sky . The arch of [it]1268-it looked very high and the small snowy clouds seemed like white birds floating on outspread wings below its crystal blueness . The wind swept in soft big breaths down from [the moor]1835-the moor and was strange with a wild clear scented sweetness . [Colin]81-colin kept lifting [his]81-colin thin chest to draw it in , and [his]81-colin big eyes looked as if it were [they]1270-they which were listening listening , instead of [his]81-colin ears .

" There are so many sounds of singing and humming and calling out , "[81-colin] [he]81-colin said . " What is that scent the puffs of wind bring ? "[81-colin]

" It 's gorse on [th ' moor]1874-th ' moor that 's openin ' out , "[54-dickon] answered [Dickon]54-dickon . " Eh ! th ' bees are at [it]1268-it wonderful today . "[54-dickon]

Not [a human creature]1271-a human creature was to be caught sight of in the paths [they]1266-they took . In fact [every gardener]1272-every gardener or [gardener 's lad]1273-gardener 's lad had been witched away . But [they]1266-they wound in and out among the shrubbery and out and round the fountain beds , following [their]1266-they carefully planned route for the mere mysterious pleasure of it . But when at last [they]1266-they turned into [the Long Walk by the ivied walls]1274-the long walk by the ivied walls the excited sense of an approaching thrill made [them]1266-they , for some curious reason [they]1266-they could not have explained , begin to speak in whispers .

" This is it , "[38-mary] breathed [Mary]38-mary . " This is where [I]38-mary used to walk up and down and wonder and wonder . "[38-mary] " Is it ? "[81-colin] cried [Colin]81-colin , and [his]81-colin eyes began to search the ivy with eager curiousness . " But [I]81-colin can see nothing , "[81-colin] [he]81-colin whispered . " There is no door . "[81-colin]

" That 's what [I]38-mary thought , "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary .

Then there was a lovely breathless silence and the chair wheeled on .

" That is [the garden where [Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff works]2937-the garden where ben weatherstaff works , "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary .

" Is it ? "[81-colin] said [Colin]81-colin .

A few yards more and [Mary]38-mary whispered again .

" This is where the robin flew over the wall , "[38-mary] [she]38-mary said .

" Is it ? "[81-colin] cried [Colin]81-colin . " Oh ! [I]81-colin wish [he]57-ben weatherstaff 'd come again ! "[81-colin]

" And that , "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary with solemn delight , pointing under a big lilac bush , " is where [he]57-ben weatherstaff perched on the little heap of earth and showed [me]38-mary the key . "[38-mary]

Then [Colin]81-colin sat up .

" Where ? Where ? There ? "[81-colin] [he]81-colin cried , and [his]81-colin eyes were as big as the wolf 's in [Red Riding - Hood]97-red riding - hood , when [Red Riding - Hood]97-red riding - hood felt called upon to remark on [them]1275-them . [Dickon]54-dickon stood still and the wheeled chair stopped .

" And this , "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary , stepping on to the bed close to the ivy , " is where [I]38-mary went to talk to [him]57-ben weatherstaff when [he]57-ben weatherstaff chirped at [me]38-mary from the top of the wall . And this is the ivy the wind blew back , "[38-mary] and [she]38-mary took hold of the hanging green curtain .

" Oh ! is it is it ! "[81-colin] gasped [Colin]81-colin .

" And here is the handle , and here is the door . [Dickon]54-dickon push [him]57-ben weatherstaff in push [him]57-ben weatherstaff in quickly ! "[81-colin]

And [Dickon]54-dickon did it with one strong , steady , splendid push .

But [Colin]81-colin had actually dropped back against [his]81-colin cushions , even though [he]81-colin gasped with delight , and [he]81-colin had covered [his]81-colin eyes with [his]81-colin hands and held them there shutting out everything until [they]1275-them were inside and the chair stopped as if by magic and the door was closed . Not till then did [he]81-colin take them away and look round and round and round as [Dickon]54-dickon and [Mary]38-mary had done . And over walls and earth and trees and swinging sprays and tendrils the fair green veil of tender little leaves had crept , and in the grass under the trees and the gray urns in [the alcoves]1276-the alcoves and here and there everywhere were touches or splashes of gold and purple and white and the trees were showing pink and snow above [his]81-colin head and there were fluttering of wings and faint sweet pipes and humming and scents and scents . And the sun fell warm upon [his]81-colin face like a hand with a lovely touch . And in wonder [Mary]38-mary and [Dickon]54-dickon stood and stared at [him]81-colin . [He]81-colin looked so strange and different because a pink glow of color had actually crept all over [him]81-colin ivory face and neck and hands and all .

" [I]81-colin shall get well ! [I]81-colin shall get well ! "[81-colin] [he]81-colin cried out . " [Mary]38-mary ! [Dickon]54-dickon ! [I]81-colin shall get well ! And [I]81-colin shall live forever and ever and ever ! "[81-colin]

CHAPTER XXI

[BEN WEATHERSTAFF]57-ben weatherstaff

One of the strange things about living in [the world]234-the world is that it is only now and then [one]406-one is quite sure [one]406-one is going to live forever and ever and ever . [One]406-one knows it sometimes when [one]406-one gets up at the tender solemn dawn - time and goes out and stands alone and throws [one]406-one 's head far back and looks up and up and watches the pale sky slowly changing and flushing and marvelous unknown things happening until [the East]18-the east almost makes [one]406-one cry out and [one]406-one 's heart stands still at the strange unchanging majesty of the rising of the sun which has been happening every morning for thousands and thousands and thousands of years . [One]406-one knows it then for a moment or so . And one knows it sometimes when [one]406-one stands by [oneself]406-one in a wood at sunset and the mysterious deep gold stillness slanting through and under the branches seems to be saying slowly again and again something [one]406-one can not quite hear , however much [one]406-one tries . Then sometimes the immense quiet of the dark blue at night with millions of stars waiting and watching makes [one]406-one sure ; and sometimes a sound of far - off music makes it true ; and sometimes a look in [some one]151-some one 's eyes .

And it was like that with [Colin]81-colin when [he]81-colin first saw and heard and felt the Springtime inside the four high walls of [a hidden garden]901-a hidden garden . That afternoon [the whole world]905-the whole world seemed to devote itself to being perfect and radiantly beautiful and kind to [one boy]2658-one boy . Perhaps out of pure heavenly goodness the spring came and crowned everything it possibly could into [that one place]1294-that one place . More than once [Dickon]54-dickon paused in what [he]54-dickon was doing and stood still with a sort of growing wonder in [his]54-dickon eyes , shaking [his]54-dickon head softly .

" Eh ! it is [graidely]98-graidely , "[54-dickon] [he]54-dickon said . " [I]54-dickon 'm twelve goin' on thirteen an ' there 's a lot o ' afternoons in thirteen years , but seems to [me]54-dickon like [I]54-dickon never seed one as graidely as this ' ere . "[54-dickon]

" Aye , it is [a graidely one]2938-a graidely one , "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary , and [she]38-mary sighed for mere joy . " [I]38-mary 'll warrant it 's the graidelest one as ever was in [this world]2939-this world . "[38-mary]

" Does tha ' think , "[81-colin] said [Colin]81-colin with dreamy carefulness , " as happen it was made loike this ' ere all o ' purpose for [me]81-colin ? "[81-colin]

" [My]38-mary word ! "[38-mary] cried [Mary]38-mary admiringly , " that there is a bit o ' good [Yorkshire]50-martha . Tha'rt shapin ' first - rate that tha ' art . "[38-mary]

And delight reigned . [They]1295-they drew the chair under the plum - tree , which was snow - white with blossoms and musical with bees . It was like a [king]1296-king 's canopy , [a fairy king]1297-a fairy king 's . There were flowering cherry - trees near and apple - trees whose buds were pink and white , and here and there one had burst open wide . Between the blossoming branches of the canopy bits of blue sky looked down like wonderful eyes .

[Mary]38-mary and [Dickon]54-dickon worked a little here and there and [Colin]81-colin watched [them]1295-they . [They]1295-they brought [him]81-colin things to look at buds which were opening , buds which were tight closed , bits of twig whose leaves were just showing green , the feather of a woodpecker which had dropped on the grass , the empty shell of some bird early hatched . [Dickon]54-dickon pushed the chair slowly round and round [the garden]146-the garden , stopping every other moment to let [him]81-colin look at wonders springing out of the earth or trailing down from trees . It was like being taken in state round [the country of [a magic king]1300-a magic king and [queen]1301-queen]1299-the country of a magic king and queen and shown all the mysterious riches it contained .

" [I]81-colin wonder if [we]1295-they shall see the robin ? "[81-colin] said [Colin]81-colin .

" [Tha'll]95-tha'll see [him]81-colin often enow after a bit , "[54-dickon] answered [Dickon]54-dickon . " When [th]95-tha'll ' eggs hatches out [th ' little chap]2940-th ' little chap [he]81-colin 'll be kep ' so busy it 'll make [his]81-colin head swim . [Tha'll]95-tha'll see [him]81-colin flyin ' backward an ' [for'ard]99-for'ard carryin ' worms nigh as big as [himsel]81-colin ' an ' that much noise goin' on in th ' nest when [he]81-colin gets there as fair flusters [him]81-colin so as [he]81-colin scarce knows which big mouth to drop [th]95-tha'll ' first piece in . An ' gapin ' beaks an ' squawks on every side . [Mother]53-mother says as when [she]53-mother sees th ' work [a robin]544-a robin has to keep them gapin ' beaks filled , [she]53-mother feels like [she]53-mother was [a lady with nothin' to do]2942-a lady with nothin' to do . [She]53-mother says [she]53-mother 's seen [th ' little chaps]2943-th ' little chaps when it seemed like th ' sweat must be droppin ' off ['em]2944-'em , though [folk]1939-folk ca n't see it . "[54-dickon]

This made [them]1302-they giggle so delightedly that [they]1302-they were obliged to cover [their]1302-they mouths with [their]1302-they hands , remembering that [they]1302-they must not be heard . [Colin]81-colin had been instructed as to the law of whispers and low voices several days before . [He]81-colin liked the mysteriousness of it and did [his]81-colin best , but in the midst of excited enjoyment it is rather difficult never to laugh above a whisper .

Every moment of the afternoon was full of new things and every hour the sunshine grew more golden . The wheeled chair had been drawn back under the canopy and [Dickon]54-dickon had sat down on the grass and had just drawn out [his]54-dickon pipe when [Colin]81-colin saw something [he]81-colin had not had time to notice before .

" That 's a very old tree over there , is n't it ? "[54-dickon] [he]54-dickon said . [Dickon]54-dickon looked across the grass at the tree and [Mary]38-mary looked and there was a brief moment of stillness .

" Yes , "[54-dickon] answered [Dickon]54-dickon , after it , and [his]54-dickon low voice had a very gentle sound .

[Mary]38-mary gazed at the tree and thought .

" The branches are quite gray and there 's not a single leaf anywhere , "[81-colin] [Colin]81-colin went on . " It 's quite dead , is n't it ? "[81-colin]

" Aye , "[54-dickon] admitted [Dickon]54-dickon . " But them roses as has climbed all over [it]2946-it will near hide every bit o ' th ' dead wood when they 're full o ' leaves an ' flowers . It wo n't look dead then . It 'll be [th]2947-th ' prettiest of all . "[54-dickon]

[Mary]38-mary still gazed at the tree and thought .

" It looks as if a big branch had been broken off , "[81-colin] said [Colin]81-colin . " [I]81-colin wonder how it was done . "[81-colin]

" It 's been done many a year , "[54-dickon] answered [Dickon]54-dickon . " Eh ! "[54-dickon] with a sudden relieved start and laying [his]54-dickon hand on [Colin]81-colin . " Look at that robin ! There [he]1303-he is ! [He]1303-he 's been foragin ' for [[his]1303-he mate]2733-his mate . "[54-dickon]

[Colin]81-colin was almost too late but [he]81-colin just caught sight of [him]1303-he , the flash of red - breasted bird with something in [his]1303-he beak . [He]1303-he darted through the greenness and into the close - grown corner and was out of sight . [Colin]81-colin leaned back on [his]81-colin cushion again , laughing a little . " [He]1303-he 's taking [her]2733-his mate tea to [her]2733-his mate . Perhaps it 's five o'clock . [I]81-colin think [I]81-colin 'd like some tea [myself]81-colin . "[81-colin]

And so [they]1304-we were safe .

" It was Magic which sent the robin , "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary secretly to [Dickon]54-dickon afterward . " [I]38-mary know it was Magic . "[38-mary] For both [she]38-mary and [Dickon]54-dickon had been afraid [Colin]81-colin might ask something about the tree whose branch had broken off ten years ago and [they]1304-we had talked it over together and [Dickon]54-dickon had stood and rubbed [his]54-dickon head in a troubled way .

" [We]1304-we mun look as if it was n't no different from th ' other trees , "[54-dickon] [he]54-dickon had said . " [We]1304-we could n't never tell [him]81-colin how it broke , [poor lad]2784-poor lad . If [he]81-colin says anything about it [we]1304-we mun [we]1304-we mun try to look cheerful . "[54-dickon]

" Aye , that [we]1304-we mun , "[38-mary] had answered [Mary]38-mary .

But [she]38-mary had not felt as if [she]38-mary looked cheerful when [she]38-mary gazed at the tree . [She]38-mary wondered and wondered in those few moments if there was any reality in that other thing [Dickon]54-dickon had said . [He]54-dickon had gone on rubbing [his]54-dickon rust - red hair in a puzzled way , but a nice comforted look had begun to grow in [his]54-dickon blue eyes .

" [Mrs. Craven]59-mrs. craven was [a very lovely young lady]2950-a very lovely young lady , "[54-dickon] [he]54-dickon had gone on rather hesitatingly . " An ' [mother]224-mother [she]59-mrs. craven thinks maybe [she]59-mrs. craven 's about [Misselthwaite]5-misselthwaite many a time lookin ' after [Mester Colin]81-colin , same as [all mothers]2952-all mothers do when [they]2952-all mothers 're took out o ' [th ' world]2220-th ' world . [They]2952-all mothers have to come back , tha ' sees . Happen [she]59-mrs. craven 's been in [the garden]146-the garden an ' happen it was [her]59-mrs. craven set [us]2955-us to work , an ' told [us]2955-us to bring [him]81-colin [here]1771-here . "[54-dickon]

[Mary]38-mary had thought [he]54-dickon meant something about Magic . [She]38-mary was a great believer in Magic . Secretly [she]38-mary quite believed that [Dickon]54-dickon worked Magic , of course good Magic , on everything near [him]54-dickon and that was why [people]167-people liked [him]54-dickon so much and [wild creatures]1306-wild creatures knew [he]54-dickon was [[their]167-people friend]1307-their friend . [She]38-mary wondered , indeed , if it were not possible that [his]54-dickon gift had brought [the robin]495-the robin just at the right moment when [Colin]81-colin asked that dangerous question . [She]38-mary felt that [his]54-dickon Magic was working all the afternoon and making [Colin]81-colin look like [an entirely different boy]1309-an entirely different boy . It did not seem possible that [he]81-colin could be [the crazy creature who had screamed and beaten and bitten [his]54-dickon pillow]1310-the crazy creature who had screamed and beaten and bitten his pillow . Even [his]54-dickon ivory whiteness seemed to change . The faint glow of color which had shown on [his]54-dickon face and neck and hands when [he]54-dickon first got inside [the garden]146-the garden really never quite died away . [He]54-dickon looked as if [he]54-dickon were made of flesh instead of ivory or wax .

[They]1312-they saw [the robin]495-the robin carry food to [[his]495-the robin mate]2733-his mate two or three times , and it was so suggestive of afternoon tea that [Colin]81-colin felt [they]1312-they must have some .

" Go and make one of [the men]206-the men [servants]282-servants bring some in a basket to the rhododendron walk , "[81-colin] [he]81-colin said . " And then [you]2733-his mate and [Dickon]54-dickon can bring it here . "[81-colin]

It was an agreeable idea , easily carried out , and when the white cloth was spread upon the grass , with hot tea and buttered toast and crumpets , a delightfully hungry meal was eaten , and [several birds on domestic errands]1315-several birds on domestic errands paused to inquire what was going on and were led into investigating crumbs with great activity . [Nut]61-soot and [Shell]61-soot whisked up trees with pieces of cake and Soot took the entire half of a buttered crumpet into a corner and pecked at and examined and turned it over and made hoarse remarks about it until [he]54-dickon decided to swallow it all joyfully in one gulp .

The afternoon was dragging towards its mellow hour . The sun was deepening the gold of its lances , the bees were going [home]1785-home and the birds were flying past less often . [Dickon]54-dickon and [Mary]38-mary were sitting on the grass , the tea - basket was repacked ready to be taken back to [the house]166-the house , and [Colin]81-colin was lying against [his]81-colin cushions with [his]81-colin heavy locks pushed back from [his]81-colin forehead and [his]81-colin face looking quite a natural color .

" [I]81-colin do n't want this afternoon to go , "[81-colin] [he]81-colin said ; " but [I]81-colin shall come back tomorrow , and the day after , and the day after , and the day after . "[81-colin]

" [You]81-colin 'll get plenty of fresh air , wo n't [you]81-colin ? "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary . " [I]81-colin 'm going to get nothing else , "[81-colin] [he]81-colin answered . " [I]38-mary 've seen the spring now and [I]38-mary 'm going to see the summer . [I]38-mary 'm going to see everything grow here . [I]38-mary 'm going to grow [here]1771-here [myself]38-mary . "[38-mary]

" That tha ' will , "[54-dickon] said [Dickon]54-dickon . " [Us'll]2960-us'll have [thee]81-colin walkin ' about here an ' diggin ' same as other folk afore long . "[54-dickon]

[Colin]81-colin flushed tremendously .

" Walk ! "[81-colin] [he]81-colin said . " Dig ! Shall [I]81-colin ? "[81-colin]

[Dickon]54-dickon 's glance at [him]81-colin was delicately cautious . Neither [he]81-colin nor [Mary]38-mary had ever asked if anything was the matter with [his]81-colin legs .

" For sure [tha]81-colin ' will , "[81-colin] [he]81-colin said stoutly . " [Tha]81-colin tha 's got legs o ' thine own , same as [other folks]2961-other folks ! "[81-colin]

[Mary]38-mary was rather frightened until [she]38-mary heard [Colin]81-colin 's answer .

" Nothing really ails [them]2962-them , "[81-colin] [he]81-colin said , " but [they]2962-them are so thin and weak . [They]2962-them shake so that [I]81-colin 'm afraid to try to stand on [them]2962-them . "[81-colin]

Both [Mary]38-mary and [Dickon]54-dickon drew a relieved breath .

" When [tha]81-colin ' stops bein ' afraid [tha'lt]81-colin stand on ['em]81-colin , "[54-dickon] [Dickon]54-dickon said with renewed cheer . " An ' tha'lt stop bein ' afraid in a bit . "[54-dickon]

" [I]81-colin shall ? "[81-colin] said [Colin]81-colin , and [he]81-colin lay still as if [he]81-colin were wondering about things .

[They]1318-they were really very quiet for a little while . The sun was dropping lower . It was that hour when everything stills itself , and [they]1318-they really had had a busy and exciting afternoon . [Colin]81-colin looked as if [he]81-colin were resting luxuriously . Even the creatures had ceased moving about and had drawn together and were resting near [them]1318-they . [Soot]61-soot had perched on a low branch and drawn up one leg and dropped the gray film drowsily over [his]81-colin eyes . [Mary]38-mary privately thought [he]81-colin looked as if [he]81-colin might snore in a minute .

In the midst of this stillness it was rather startling when [Colin]81-colin half lifted [his]81-colin head and exclaimed in a loud suddenly alarmed whisper :

" Who is [that man]2963-that man ? "[81-colin] [Dickon]54-dickon and [Mary]38-mary scrambled to [their]1318-they feet .

" [Man]2964-man ! "[1318-they] [they]1318-they both cried in low quick voices .

[Colin]81-colin pointed to the high wall . " Look ! "[81-colin] [he]81-colin whispered excitedly . " Just look ! "[81-colin]

[Mary]38-mary and [Dickon]54-dickon wheeled about and looked . There was [Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff 's indignant face glaring at [them]1318-they over the wall from the top of a ladder ! [He]81-colin actually shook [his]81-colin fist at [Mary]38-mary .

" If [I]81-colin was n't [a bachelder]2965-a bachelder , an ' tha ' was [a wench o ' mine]2966-a wench o ' mine , "[81-colin] [he]81-colin cried , " [I]81-colin 'd give [thee]38-mary a hidin ' ! "[81-colin]

[He]81-colin mounted another step threateningly as if it were [his]81-colin energetic intention to jump down and deal with [her]38-mary ; but as [she]38-mary came toward [him]81-colin [he]81-colin evidently thought better of it and stood on the top step of [his]81-colin ladder shaking [his]81-colin fist down at [her]38-mary .

" [I]81-colin never thowt much o ' [thee]38-mary ! "[81-colin] [he]81-colin harangued . " [I]81-colin couldna ' abide [thee]38-mary th ' first time [I]81-colin set eyes on [thee]38-mary . [A scrawny buttermilk - faced young besom]2967-a scrawny buttermilk - faced young besom , allus askin ' questions an ' pokin ' [tha]2968-tha ' nose where it wasna , wanted . [I]81-colin never knowed how [tha]2968-tha ' got so thick wi ' [me]81-colin . If it hadna ' been for [th]2968-tha ' [robin Drat]100-robin drat [him]81-colin "[81-colin]

" [Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff , "[38-mary] called out [Mary]38-mary , finding [her]38-mary breath . [She]38-mary stood below [him]81-colin and called up to [him]81-colin with a sort of gasp . " [Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff , it was the robin who showed [me]38-mary the way ! "[38-mary]

Then it did seem as if [Ben]57-ben weatherstaff really would scramble down on [her]38-mary side of the wall , [he]57-ben weatherstaff was so outraged .

" [Tha ' young bad ' un]2969-tha ' young bad ' un ! "[81-colin] [he]81-colin called down at [her]38-mary . " Layin ' [tha]2968-tha ' badness on [a robin]544-a robin not but what [he]544-a robin 's impidint enow for anythin ' . [Him]544-a robin showin ' [thee]2971-thee th ' way ! [Him]544-a robin ! Eh ! tha ' young nowt "[81-colin] [she]38-mary could see [his]81-colin next words burst out because [he]81-colin was overpowered by curiosity " however [i]81-colin ' [this world]2939-this world did [tha]2968-tha ' get in ? "[81-colin]

" It was the robin who showed [me]38-mary the way , "[38-mary] [she]38-mary protested obstinately . " [He]544-a robin did n't know [he]544-a robin was doing it but [he]544-a robin did . And [I]38-mary ca n't tell [you]38-mary from here while [you]38-mary 're shaking [your]38-mary fist at [me]38-mary . "[38-mary]

[He]81-colin stopped shaking [his]81-colin fist very suddenly at that very moment and [his]81-colin jaw actually dropped as [he]81-colin stared over [her]38-mary head at something [he]81-colin saw coming over the grass toward [him]81-colin .

At the first sound of [his]81-colin torrent of words [Colin]81-colin had been so surprised that [he]81-colin had only sat up and listened as if [he]81-colin were spellbound . But in the midst of it [he]81-colin had recovered [himself]81-colin and beckoned imperiously to [Dickon]54-dickon .

" Wheel [me]81-colin over there ! "[81-colin] [he]81-colin commanded . " Wheel [me]81-colin quite close and stop right in front of [him]81-colin ! "[81-colin]

And this , if [you]1319-you please , this is what [Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff beheld and which made [his]81-colin jaw drop . A wheeled chair with luxurious cushions and robes which came toward [him]81-colin looking rather like some sort of State Coach because [a young Rajah]1320-a young rajah leaned back in [it]1321-it with royal command in [his]1320-a young rajah great black - rimmed eyes and a thin white hand extended haughtily toward [him]1320-a young rajah . And it stopped right under [Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff 's nose . It was really no wonder [his]81-colin mouth dropped open .

" Do [you]1319-you know who [I]90-the rajah am ? "[90-the rajah] demanded [the Rajah]90-the rajah .

How [Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff stared ! [His]57-ben weatherstaff red old eyes fixed themselves on what was before [him]57-ben weatherstaff as if [he]57-ben weatherstaff were seeing a ghost . [He]57-ben weatherstaff gazed and gazed and gulped a lump down [his]57-ben weatherstaff throat and did not say a word . " Do [you]1319-you know who [I]81-colin am ? "[81-colin] demanded [Colin]81-colin still more imperiously . " Answer ! "[81-colin]

[Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff put [his]57-ben weatherstaff gnarled hand up and passed it over [his]57-ben weatherstaff eyes and over [his]57-ben weatherstaff forehead and then [he]57-ben weatherstaff did answer in a queer shaky voice .

" Who [tha]2973-tha ' art ? "[57-ben weatherstaff] [he]57-ben weatherstaff said . " Aye , that [I]57-ben weatherstaff do wi ' [[tha]2973-tha ' mother]2974-tha ' mother 's eyes starin ' at [me]57-ben weatherstaff out o ' tha ' face . [Lord]2975-lord knows how [tha]2973-tha ' come here . But tha'rt th ' poor cripple . "[57-ben weatherstaff]

[Colin]81-colin forgot that [he]81-colin had ever had a back . [His]81-colin face flushed scarlet and [he]81-colin sat bolt upright .

" [I]81-colin 'm not [a cripple]2976-a cripple ! "[81-colin] [he]81-colin cried out furiously . " [I]81-colin 'm not ! "[81-colin]

" [He]57-ben weatherstaff 's not ! "[38-mary] cried [Mary]38-mary , almost shouting up the wall in [her]38-mary fierce indignation . " [He]57-ben weatherstaff 's not got a lump as big as a pin ! [I]38-mary looked and there was none there not one ! "[38-mary]

[Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff passed [his]57-ben weatherstaff hand over [his]57-ben weatherstaff forehead again and gazed as if [he]57-ben weatherstaff could never gaze enough . [His]57-ben weatherstaff hand shook and [his]57-ben weatherstaff mouth shook and [his]57-ben weatherstaff voice shook . [He]57-ben weatherstaff was [an ignorant old man]1322-an ignorant old man and [a tactless old man]1323-a tactless old man and [he]57-ben weatherstaff could only remember the things [he]57-ben weatherstaff had heard .

" Tha ' tha ' has n't got a crooked back ? "[57-ben weatherstaff] [he]57-ben weatherstaff said hoarsely .

" No ! "[81-colin] shouted [Colin]81-colin .

" [Tha ' tha ']2977-tha ' tha ' has n't got crooked legs ? "[57-ben weatherstaff] quavered [Ben]57-ben weatherstaff more hoarsely yet . It was too much . The strength which [Colin]81-colin usually threw into [his]81-colin tantrums rushed through [him]81-colin now in a new way . Never yet had [he]57-ben weatherstaff been accused of crooked legs even in whispers and the perfectly simple belief in [their]1324-their existence which was revealed by [Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff 's voice was more than [Rajah]90-the rajah flesh and blood could endure . [His]57-ben weatherstaff anger and insulted pride made [him]57-ben weatherstaff forget everything but this one moment and filled [him]57-ben weatherstaff with a power [he]57-ben weatherstaff had never known before , an almost unnatural strength .

" Come here ! "[57-ben weatherstaff] [he]57-ben weatherstaff shouted to [Dickon]54-dickon , and [he]57-ben weatherstaff actually began to tear the coverings off [his]57-ben weatherstaff lower limbs and disentangle [himself]57-ben weatherstaff . " Come here ! Come here ! This minute ! "[57-ben weatherstaff]

[Dickon]54-dickon was by [his]57-ben weatherstaff side in a second . [Mary]38-mary caught [her]38-mary breath in a short gasp and felt [herself]38-mary turn pale .

" [He]81-colin can do it ! [He]81-colin can do it ! [He]81-colin can do it ! [He]81-colin can ! "[38-mary] [she]38-mary gabbled over to [herself]38-mary under [her]38-mary breath as fast as ever [she]38-mary could .

There was a brief fierce scramble , the rugs were tossed on the ground , [Dickon]54-dickon held [Colin]81-colin 's arm , the thin legs were out , the thin feet were on the grass . [Colin]81-colin was standing upright upright as straight as an arrow and looking strangely tall [his]81-colin head thrown back and [his]81-colin strange eyes flashing lightning . " Look at [me]54-dickon ! "[54-dickon] [he]54-dickon flung up at [Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff . " Just look at [me]54-dickon [you]57-ben weatherstaff ! Just look at [me]54-dickon ! "[54-dickon]

" [He]81-colin 's as straight as [I]54-dickon am ! "[54-dickon] cried [Dickon]54-dickon . " [He]81-colin 's as straight as [any lad [i]54-dickon ' [Yorkshire]50-martha]2978-any lad i ' yorkshire ! "[54-dickon]

What [Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff did [Mary]38-mary thought queer beyond measure . [He]57-ben weatherstaff choked and gulped and suddenly tears ran down [his]57-ben weatherstaff weather - wrinkled cheeks as [he]57-ben weatherstaff struck [his]57-ben weatherstaff old hands together .

" Eh ! "[57-ben weatherstaff] [he]57-ben weatherstaff burst forth , " [th ' lies folk]2979-th ' lies folk tells ! Tha'rt as thin as a lath an ' as white as a wraith , but there 's not a knob on [thee]792-the boy . Tha'lt make a mon yet . God bless [thee]792-the boy ! "[57-ben weatherstaff]

[Dickon]54-dickon held [Colin]81-colin 's arm strongly but [the boy]792-the boy had not begun to falter . [He]54-dickon stood straighter and straighter and looked [Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff in the face .

" [I]57-ben weatherstaff 'm [[your]792-the boy master]2980-your master , "[57-ben weatherstaff] [he]57-ben weatherstaff said , " when [[my]57-ben weatherstaff father]1923-my father is away . And [you]792-the boy are to obey [me]57-ben weatherstaff . This is [[my]57-ben weatherstaff garden]2434-my garden . Do n't dare to say a word about it ! [You]792-the boy get down from that ladder and go out to [the Long Walk]719-the long walk and [Miss Mary]38-mary will meet [you]792-the boy and bring [you]792-the boy here . [I]57-ben weatherstaff want to talk to [you]792-the boy . [We]2984-we did not want [you]792-the boy , but now [you]792-the boy will have to be in the secret . Be quick ! "[57-ben weatherstaff]

[Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff 's crabbed old face was still wet with that one queer rush of tears . It seemed as if [he]57-ben weatherstaff could not take [his]57-ben weatherstaff eyes from thin straight [Colin]81-colin standing on [his]81-colin feet with [his]81-colin head thrown back .

" Eh ! [lad]2693-lad , "[81-colin] [he]81-colin almost whispered . " Eh ! [[my]81-colin lad]2986-my lad ! "[81-colin] And then remembering [himself]81-colin [he]81-colin suddenly touched [his]81-colin hat [gardener]101-gardener fashion and said , " Yes , [sir]2395-sir ! Yes , [sir]2395-sir ! "[81-colin] and obediently disappeared as [he]81-colin descended [the ladder]1326-the ladder .

CHAPTER XXII

WHEN THE SUN WENT DOWN

When [his]81-colin head was out of sight [Colin]81-colin turned to [Mary]38-mary .

" Go and meet [him]54-dickon , "[81-colin] [he]81-colin said ; and [Mary]38-mary flew across the grass to the door under the ivy .

[Dickon]54-dickon was watching [him]81-colin with sharp eyes . There were scarlet spots on [his]54-dickon cheeks and [he]54-dickon looked amazing , but [he]54-dickon showed no signs of falling .

" [I]54-dickon can stand , "[54-dickon] [he]54-dickon said , and [his]54-dickon head was still held up and [he]54-dickon said it quite grandly .

" [I]54-dickon told [thee]81-colin tha ' could as soon as [tha]81-colin ' stopped bein ' afraid , "[54-dickon] answered [Dickon]54-dickon . " An ' tha 's stopped . "[54-dickon]

" Yes , [I]81-colin 've stopped , "[81-colin] said [Colin]81-colin .

Then suddenly [he]81-colin remembered something [Mary]38-mary had said .

" Are [you]54-dickon making Magic ? "[81-colin] [he]81-colin asked sharply .

[Dickon]54-dickon 's curly mouth spread in a cheerful grin .

" [Tha]81-colin 's doin' Magic thysel ' , "[54-dickon] [he]54-dickon said . " It 's same Magic as made these ' ere work out o ' th ' earth , "[54-dickon] and [he]54-dickon touched with [his]54-dickon thick boot a clump of crocuses in the grass . [Colin]81-colin looked down at [them]1327-them .

" Aye , "[81-colin] [he]81-colin said slowly , " there couldna ' be bigger Magic than that there there couldna ' be . "[81-colin]

[He]54-dickon drew [himself]54-dickon up straighter than ever .

" [I]54-dickon 'm going to walk to that tree , "[54-dickon] [he]54-dickon said , pointing to one a few feet away from [him]54-dickon . " [I]54-dickon 'm going to be standing when [Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff comes here . [I]54-dickon can rest against the tree if [I]54-dickon like . When [I]54-dickon want to sit down [I]54-dickon will sit down , but not before . Bring a rug from the chair . "[54-dickon]

[He]54-dickon walked to the tree and though [Dickon]54-dickon held [his]54-dickon arm [he]54-dickon was wonderfully steady . When [he]54-dickon stood against the tree trunk it was not too plain that [he]54-dickon supported [himself]54-dickon against it , and [he]54-dickon still held [himself]54-dickon so straight that [he]54-dickon looked tall .

When [Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff came through the door in the wall [he]57-ben weatherstaff saw [him]57-ben weatherstaff standing there and [he]57-ben weatherstaff heard [Mary]38-mary muttering something under [her]38-mary breath .

" What art sayin ' ? "[57-ben weatherstaff] [he]57-ben weatherstaff asked rather testily because [he]57-ben weatherstaff did not want [his]57-ben weatherstaff attention distracted from [the long thin straight boy figure and proud face]1328-the long thin straight boy figure and proud face .

But [she]38-mary did not tell [him]57-ben weatherstaff . What [she]38-mary was saying was this :

" [You]57-ben weatherstaff can do it ! [You]57-ben weatherstaff can do it ! [I]38-mary told [you]57-ben weatherstaff [you]57-ben weatherstaff could ! [You]57-ben weatherstaff can do it ! [You]57-ben weatherstaff can do it ! [You]57-ben weatherstaff can ! "[38-mary] [She]38-mary was saying it to [Colin]81-colin because [she]38-mary wanted to make Magic and keep [him]81-colin on [his]81-colin feet looking like that . [She]38-mary could not bear that [he]81-colin should give in before [Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff . [He]81-colin did not give in . [She]38-mary was uplifted by a sudden feeling that [he]81-colin looked quite beautiful in spite of [his]81-colin thinness . [He]81-colin fixed [his]81-colin eyes on [Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff in [his]81-colin funny imperious way .

" Look at [me]81-colin ! "[81-colin] [he]81-colin commanded . " Look at [me]81-colin all over ! Am [I]81-colin a hunchback ? Have [I]81-colin got crooked legs ? "[81-colin]

[Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff had not quite got over [his]57-ben weatherstaff emotion , but [he]57-ben weatherstaff had recovered a little and answered almost in [his]57-ben weatherstaff usual way .

" Not tha ' , "[57-ben weatherstaff] [he]57-ben weatherstaff said . " Nowt o ' th ' sort . What 's [tha]2989-tha ' been doin' with [thysel]2989-tha ' hidin ' out o ' sight an ' lettin ' [folk]1939-folk think [tha]2989-tha ' was cripple an ' half - witted ? "[57-ben weatherstaff]

" Half - witted ! "[81-colin] said [Colin]81-colin angrily . " Who thought that ? "[81-colin]

" [Lots o ' fools]2991-lots o ' fools , "[57-ben weatherstaff] said [Ben]57-ben weatherstaff . " [Th]2989-tha ' world 's full o ' jackasses brayin ' an ' [they]1939-folk never bray nowt but lies . What did [tha]2989-tha ' shut [thysel]2989-tha ' up for ? "[57-ben weatherstaff]

" [Everyone]174-everyone thought [I]81-colin was going to die , "[81-colin] said [Colin]81-colin shortly . " [I]81-colin 'm not ! "[81-colin]

And [he]81-colin said it with such decision [Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff looked [him]81-colin over , up and down , down and up .

" Tha ' die ! "[57-ben weatherstaff] [he]57-ben weatherstaff said with dry exultation . " Nowt o ' th ' sort ! [Tha]58-tha 's got too much pluck in [thee]58-tha . When [I]57-ben weatherstaff seed [thee]58-tha put [tha]2989-tha ' legs on th ' ground in such a hurry [I]57-ben weatherstaff knowed [tha]2989-tha ' was all right . Sit [thee]58-tha down on [th ' rug]2993-th ' rug a bit young [Mester]57-ben weatherstaff an ' give [me]57-ben weatherstaff [thy]2989-tha orders . "[57-ben weatherstaff]

There was a queer mixture of crabbed tenderness and shrewd understanding in [his]57-ben weatherstaff manner . [Mary]38-mary had poured out speech as rapidly as [she]38-mary could as [they]1329-they had come down [the Long Walk]719-the long walk . The chief thing to be remembered , [she]38-mary had told [him]57-ben weatherstaff , was that [Colin]81-colin was getting well getting well . [The garden]146-the garden was doing it . [No one]145-no one must let [him]57-ben weatherstaff remember about having humps and dying .

[The Rajah]90-the rajah condescended to seat [himself]90-the rajah on a rug under the tree .

" What work do [you]81-colin do in [the gardens]439-the gardens , [Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff ? "[90-the rajah] [he]90-the rajah inquired .

" Anythin ' [I]57-ben weatherstaff 'm told to do , "[57-ben weatherstaff] answered [old Ben]57-ben weatherstaff . " [I]57-ben weatherstaff 'm kep ' on by favor because [she]38-mary liked [me]57-ben weatherstaff . "[57-ben weatherstaff]

" [She]38-mary ? "[81-colin] said [Colin]81-colin .

" [Tha ' mother]2974-tha ' mother , "[57-ben weatherstaff] answered [Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff .

" [[My]81-colin mother]1897-my mother ? "[81-colin] said [Colin]81-colin , and [he]81-colin looked about [him]81-colin quietly . " This was [[her]38-mary garden]1960-her garden , was n't it ? "[81-colin]

" Aye , it was that ! "[57-ben weatherstaff] and [Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff looked about [him]81-colin too . " [She]38-mary were main fond of it . "[81-colin]

" It is [[my]81-colin garden]2434-my garden now . [I]81-colin am fond of [it]2434-my garden . [I]81-colin shall come [here]1771-here every day , "[81-colin] announced [Colin]81-colin . " But it is to be a secret . [My]81-colin orders are that [no one]145-no one is to know that [we]3001-we come here . [Dickon]54-dickon and [[my]81-colin cousin]2627-my cousin have worked and made it come alive . [I]81-colin shall send for [you]57-ben weatherstaff sometimes to help but [you]57-ben weatherstaff must come when [no one]145-no one can see [you]57-ben weatherstaff . "[81-colin]

[Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff 's face twisted itself in a dry old smile .

" [I]57-ben weatherstaff 've come here before when [no one]145-no one saw [me]57-ben weatherstaff , "[57-ben weatherstaff] [he]57-ben weatherstaff said .

" What ! "[81-colin] exclaimed [Colin]81-colin .

" When ? "[81-colin]

" [Th]3005-th ' last time [I]57-ben weatherstaff was [here]1771-here , "[57-ben weatherstaff] rubbing [his]57-ben weatherstaff chin and looking round , " was about two year ' ago . "[57-ben weatherstaff]

" But [no one]145-no one has been in [it]1771-here for ten years ! "[81-colin] cried [Colin]81-colin .

" There was no door ! "[81-colin]

" [I]57-ben weatherstaff 'm [no one]145-no one , "[57-ben weatherstaff] said [old Ben]57-ben weatherstaff dryly . " An ' [I]57-ben weatherstaff did n't come through th ' door . [I]57-ben weatherstaff come over th ' wall . [Th ' rheumatics]3009-th ' rheumatics held [me]57-ben weatherstaff back th ' last two year ' . "[57-ben weatherstaff]

" [Tha]3010-tha ' come an ' did a bit o ' prunin ' ! "[54-dickon] cried [Dickon]54-dickon . " [I]54-dickon could n't make out how it had been done . "[54-dickon]

" [She]3011-she was so fond of it [she]3011-she was ! "[57-ben weatherstaff] said [Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff slowly . " An ' [she]3011-she was such [a pretty young thing]3012-a pretty young thing . [She]3011-she says to [me]57-ben weatherstaff once , ' [Ben]57-ben weatherstaff , ' says [she]3011-she laughin ' , ' if ever [I]57-ben weatherstaff 'm ill or if [I]57-ben weatherstaff go away [you]57-ben weatherstaff must take care of [my]57-ben weatherstaff roses . ' When [she]3011-she did go away th ' orders was [no one]145-no one was ever to come nigh . But [I]57-ben weatherstaff come , "[57-ben weatherstaff] with grumpy obstinacy . " Over th ' wall [I]57-ben weatherstaff come until [th ' rheumatics]3009-th ' rheumatics stopped [me]57-ben weatherstaff an ' [I]57-ben weatherstaff did a bit o ' work once a year . [She]3011-she 'd gave [her]3011-she order first . "[57-ben weatherstaff]

" It would n't have been as wick as it is if [tha]3011-she ' had n't done it , "[54-dickon] said [Dickon]54-dickon . " [I]54-dickon did wonder . "[54-dickon]

" [I]81-colin 'm glad [you]57-ben weatherstaff did it , [Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff , "[81-colin] said [Colin]81-colin . " [You]57-ben weatherstaff 'll know how to keep the secret . "[81-colin]

" Aye , [I]57-ben weatherstaff 'll know , [sir]2395-sir , "[57-ben weatherstaff] answered [Ben]57-ben weatherstaff . " An ' it 'll be easier for [a man wi ' rheumatics]3016-a man wi ' rheumatics to come in at th ' door . "[57-ben weatherstaff]

On the grass near [the tree]1333-the tree [Mary]38-mary had dropped [her]38-mary trowel . [Colin]81-colin stretched out [his]81-colin hand and took it up . An odd expression came into [his]81-colin face and [he]81-colin began to scratch at the earth . [His]81-colin thin hand was weak enough but presently as [they]1334-they watched [him]81-colin [Mary]38-mary with quite breathless interest [he]81-colin drove the end of the trowel into the soil and turned some over .

" [You]81-colin can do it ! [You]81-colin can do it ! "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary to [herself]38-mary . " [I]38-mary tell [you]81-colin , [you]81-colin can ! "[38-mary]

[Dickon]54-dickon 's round eyes were full of eager curiousness but [he]54-dickon said not a word . [Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff looked on with interested face .

[Colin]81-colin persevered . After [he]81-colin had turned a few trowelfuls of soil [he]81-colin spoke exultantly to [Dickon]54-dickon in [his]54-dickon best [Yorkshire]50-martha .

" Tha ' said as tha'd have [me]81-colin walkin ' about here same as [other folk]3017-other folk an ' [tha]3018-tha ' said [tha'd]3018-tha have [me]81-colin diggin ' . [I]81-colin thowt [tha]3018-tha ' was just leein ' to please [me]81-colin . This is only th ' first day an ' [I]81-colin 've walked an ' here [I]81-colin am diggin ' . "[81-colin]

[Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff 's mouth fell open again when [he]57-ben weatherstaff heard [him]81-colin , but [he]57-ben weatherstaff ended by chuckling .

" Eh ! "[57-ben weatherstaff] [he]57-ben weatherstaff said , " that sounds as if tha'd got wits enow . Tha'rt [a Yorkshire lad]2801-a yorkshire lad for sure . An ' tha'rt diggin ' , too . How 'd [tha]3018-tha ' like to plant a bit o ' somethin' ? [I]57-ben weatherstaff can get [thee]3018-tha a rose in a pot . "[57-ben weatherstaff]

" Go and get it ! "[81-colin] said [Colin]81-colin , digging excitedly . " Quick ! Quick ! "[81-colin]

It was done quickly enough indeed . [Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff went [his]57-ben weatherstaff way forgetting rheumatics . [Dickon]54-dickon took [his]54-dickon spade and dug the hole deeper and wider than [a new digger with thin white hands]1335-a new digger with thin white hands could make it . [Mary]38-mary slipped out to run and bring back a watering - can . When [Dickon]54-dickon had deepened [the hole]1336-the hole [Colin]81-colin went on turning [the soft earth]1337-the soft earth over and over . [He]81-colin looked up at the sky , flushed and glowing with the strangely new exercise , slight as it was .

" [I]81-colin want to do it before the sun goes quite quite down , "[81-colin] [he]81-colin said .

[Mary]38-mary thought that perhaps the sun held back a few minutes just on purpose . [Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff brought the rose in its pot from [the greenhouse]1338-the greenhouse . [He]57-ben weatherstaff hobbled over the grass as fast as [he]57-ben weatherstaff could . [He]57-ben weatherstaff had begun to be excited , too . [He]57-ben weatherstaff knelt down by the hole and broke the pot from the mould .

" Here , [lad]2693-lad , "[57-ben weatherstaff] [he]57-ben weatherstaff said , handing the plant to [Colin]81-colin . " Set it in the earth thysel ' same as [th ' king]3021-th ' king does when [he]3021-th ' king goes to [a new place]3022-a new place . "[57-ben weatherstaff]

[The thin white hands]1339-the thin white hands shook a little and [Colin]81-colin 's flush grew deeper as [he]81-colin set the rose in the mould and held it while [old Ben]57-ben weatherstaff made firm the earth . It was filled in and pressed down and made steady . [Mary]38-mary was leaning forward on [her]38-mary hands and knees . Soot had flown down and marched forward to see what was being done . [Nut]61-soot and [Shell]61-soot chattered about it from a cherry - tree .

" It 's planted ! "[81-colin] said [Colin]81-colin at last . " And the sun is only slipping over the edge . Help [me]81-colin up , [Dickon]54-dickon . [I]81-colin want to be standing when it goes . That 's part of the Magic . "[81-colin]

And [Dickon]54-dickon helped [him]81-colin , and the Magic or whatever it was so gave [him]81-colin strength that when the sun did slip over the edge and end the strange lovely afternoon for [them]1340-them there [he]81-colin actually stood on [his]81-colin two feet laughing .

CHAPTER XXIII

MAGIC

[Dr. Craven]86-dr. craven had been waiting some time at [the house]166-the house when [they]1340-them returned to [it]166-the house . [He]86-dr. craven had indeed begun to wonder if it might not be wise to send [some one]151-some one out to explore [the garden paths]1343-the garden paths . When [Colin]81-colin was brought back to [[his]81-colin room]2556-his room [the poor man]1345-the poor man looked [him]81-colin over seriously .

" [You]81-colin should not have stayed so long , "[1345-the poor man] [he]1345-the poor man said . " [You]81-colin must not overexert [yourself]81-colin . "[1345-the poor man]

" [I]81-colin am not tired at all , "[81-colin] said [Colin]81-colin . " It has made [me]81-colin well . Tomorrow [I]81-colin am going out in the morning as well as in the afternoon . "[81-colin]

" [I]86-dr. craven am not sure that [I]86-dr. craven can allow it , "[86-dr. craven] answered [Dr. Craven]86-dr. craven . " [I]86-dr. craven am afraid it would not be wise . "[86-dr. craven]

" It would not be wise to try to stop [me]81-colin , "[81-colin] said [Colin]81-colin quite seriously . " [I]81-colin am going . "[81-colin]

Even [Mary]38-mary had found out that one of [Colin]81-colin 's chief peculiarities was that [he]81-colin did not know in the least what [a rude little brute]1346-a rude little brute [he]81-colin was with [his]81-colin way of ordering [people]167-people about . [He]81-colin had lived on [a sort of desert island]1348-a sort of desert island all [his]81-colin life and as [he]81-colin had been [the king of it]1349-the king of it [he]81-colin had made [his]81-colin own manners and had had [no one]145-no one to compare [himself]81-colin with . [Mary]38-mary had indeed been rather like [him]81-colin [herself]38-mary and since [she]38-mary had been at [Misselthwaite]5-misselthwaite had gradually discovered that [her]38-mary own manners had not been of the kind which is usual or popular . Having made this discovery [she]38-mary naturally thought it of enough interest to communicate to [Colin]81-colin . So [she]38-mary sat and looked at [him]81-colin curiously for a few minutes after [Dr. Craven]86-dr. craven had gone . [She]38-mary wanted to make [him]81-colin ask [her]38-mary why [she]38-mary was doing it and of course [she]38-mary did .

" What are [you]38-mary looking at [me]81-colin for ? "[81-colin] [he]81-colin said .

" [I]38-mary 'm thinking that [I]38-mary am rather sorry for [Dr. Craven]86-dr. craven . "[38-mary]

" So am [I]81-colin , "[81-colin] said [Colin]81-colin calmly , but not without an air of some satisfaction . " [He]81-colin wo n't get [Misselthwaite]5-misselthwaite at all now [I]81-colin 'm not going to die . "[81-colin]

" [I]38-mary 'm sorry for [him]81-colin because of that , of course , "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary , " but [I]38-mary was thinking just then that it must have been very horrid to have had to be polite for ten years to [a boy who was always rude]3023-a boy who was always rude . [I]38-mary would never have done it . "[38-mary]

" Am [I]81-colin rude ? "[81-colin] [Colin]81-colin inquired undisturbedly .

" If [you]81-colin had been [[his]81-colin own boy]3024-his own boy and [he]81-colin had been [a slapping sort of man]3025-a slapping sort of man , "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary , " [he]81-colin would have slapped [you]81-colin . "[38-mary]

" But [he]81-colin dare n't , "[81-colin] said [Colin]81-colin .

" No , [he]81-colin dare n't , "[38-mary] answered [Mistress Mary]38-mary , thinking the thing out quite without prejudice . " [Nobody]175-nobody ever dared to do anything [you]81-colin did n't like because [you]81-colin were going to die and things like that . [You]81-colin were such a poor thing . "[38-mary]

" But , "[81-colin] announced [Colin]81-colin stubbornly , " [I]81-colin am not going to be a poor thing . [I]81-colin wo n't let [people]167-people think [I]81-colin 'm one . [I]81-colin stood on [my]81-colin feet this afternoon . "[81-colin]

" It is always having [your]81-colin own way that has made [you]81-colin so queer , "[38-mary] [Mary]38-mary went on , thinking aloud .

[Colin]81-colin turned [his]81-colin head , frowning .

" Am [I]81-colin queer ? "[81-colin] [he]81-colin demanded .

" Yes , "[38-mary] answered [Mary]38-mary , " very . But [you]81-colin need n't be cross , "[38-mary] [she]38-mary added impartially , " because so am [I]38-mary queer and so is [Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff . But [I]38-mary am not as queer as [I]38-mary was before [I]38-mary began to like [people]167-people and before [I]38-mary found [the garden]146-the garden . "[38-mary]

" [I]81-colin do n't want to be queer , "[81-colin] said [Colin]81-colin . " [I]81-colin am not going to be , "[81-colin] and [he]81-colin frowned again with determination .

[He]81-colin was [a very proud boy]1351-a very proud boy . [He]81-colin lay thinking for a while and then [Mary]38-mary saw [his]81-colin beautiful smile begin and gradually change [his]81-colin whole face .

" [I]81-colin shall stop being queer , "[81-colin] [he]81-colin said , " if [I]81-colin go every day to [the garden]146-the garden . There is Magic in there good Magic , [you]38-mary know , [Mary]38-mary . [I]81-colin am sure there is . "[81-colin] " So am [I]38-mary , "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary .

" Even if it is n't real Magic , "[81-colin] [Colin]81-colin said , " [we]1352-them can pretend it is . Something is there something ! "[81-colin]

" It 's Magic , "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary , " but not black . It 's as white as snow . "[38-mary]

[They]1352-them always called it Magic and indeed it seemed like it in the months that followed the wonderful months the radiant months the amazing ones . Oh ! the things which happened in [that garden]2028-that garden ! If [you]1354-you have never had [a garden]245-a garden [you]1354-you can not understand , and if [you]1354-you have had [a garden]245-a garden [you]1354-you will know that it would take a whole book to describe all that came to pass [there]2007-there . At first it seemed that green things would never cease pushing their way through [the earth]490-the earth , in the grass , in the beds , even in the crevices of the walls . Then the green things began to show buds and the buds began to unfurl and show color , every shade of blue , every shade of purple , every tint and hue of crimson . In [its]2028-that garden happy days flowers had been tucked away into every inch and hole and corner . [Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff had seen it done and had [himself]57-ben weatherstaff scraped out mortar from between the bricks of the wall and made pockets of earth for lovely clinging things to grow on . [Iris]102-iris and white lilies rose out of the grass in sheaves , and the green alcoves filled themselves with amazing armies of the blue and white flower lances of tall delphiniums or columbines or campanulas .

" [She]3031-she was main fond o ' [them]1352-them [she]3031-she was , "[57-ben weatherstaff] [Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff said . " [She]3031-she liked them things as was allus pointin ' up to th ' blue sky , [she]3031-she used to tell . Not as [she]3031-she was one o ' [them]1352-them as looked down on th ' earth not [her]3031-she . [She]3031-she just loved it but [she]3031-she said as th ' blue sky allus looked so joyful . "[57-ben weatherstaff]

The seeds [Dickon]54-dickon and [Mary]38-mary had planted grew as if [fairies]1359-fairies had tended them . Satiny poppies of all tints danced in the breeze by the score , gaily defying flowers which had lived in [the garden]146-the garden for years and which it might be confessed seemed rather to wonder how [such new people]1361-such new people had got [there]2007-there . And the roses the roses ! Rising out of the grass , tangled round the sun - dial , wreathing the tree trunks and hanging from [their]1363-their branches , climbing up the walls and spreading over [them]1363-their with long garlands falling in cascades [they]1363-their came alive day by day , hour by hour . Fair fresh leaves , and buds and buds tiny at first but swelling and working Magic until they burst and uncurled into cups of scent delicately spilling themselves over [their]1363-their brims and filling the garden air .

[Colin]81-colin saw it all , watching each change as it took place . Every morning [he]81-colin was brought out and every hour of each day when it did n't rain [he]81-colin spent in [the garden]146-the garden . Even gray days pleased [him]81-colin . [He]81-colin would lie on the grass " watching things growing , "[81-colin] [he]81-colin said . If [you]1365-you watched long enough , [he]81-colin declared , [you]1365-you could see buds unsheath themselves . Also [you]1365-you could make the acquaintance of strange busy insect things running about on various unknown but evidently serious errands , sometimes carrying tiny scraps of straw or feather or food , or climbing blades of grass as if they were trees from whose tops one could look out to explore [the country]1796-the country . A mole throwing up its mound at the end of its burrow and making its way out at last with the long - nailed paws which looked so like elfish hands , had absorbed [him]81-colin one whole morning . [Ants]103-ants ' ways , beetles ' ways , bees ' ways , frogs ' ways , birds ' ways , plants ' ways , gave [him]81-colin a new world to explore and when [Dickon]54-dickon revealed them all and added foxes ' ways , otters ' ways , ferrets ' ways , squirrels ' ways , and trout ' and water - rats ' and badgers ' ways , there was no end to the things to talk about and think over .

And this was not the half of the Magic . The fact that [he]81-colin had really once stood on [his]81-colin feet had set [Colin]81-colin thinking tremendously and when [Mary]38-mary told [him]81-colin of the spell [she]38-mary had worked [he]81-colin was excited and approved of it greatly . [He]81-colin talked of it constantly .

" Of course there must be lots of Magic in [the world]234-the world , "[81-colin] [he]81-colin said wisely one day , " but [people]167-people do n't know what it is like or how to make it . Perhaps the beginning is just to say nice things are going to happen until [you]3034-you make them happen . [I]81-colin am going to try and experiment . "[81-colin]

The next morning when [they]1367-they went to [the secret garden]1969-the secret garden [he]81-colin sent at once for [Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff . [Ben]57-ben weatherstaff came as quickly as [he]57-ben weatherstaff could and found [the Rajah]1264-the rajah standing on [his]1264-the rajah feet under a tree and looking very grand but also very beautifully smiling .

" Good morning , [Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff , "[81-colin] [he]81-colin said . " [I]81-colin want [you]57-ben weatherstaff and [Dickon]54-dickon and [Miss Mary]38-mary to stand in a row and listen to [me]81-colin because [I]81-colin am going to tell [you]57-ben weatherstaff something very important . "[81-colin]

" Aye , aye , [sir]2395-sir ! "[57-ben weatherstaff] answered [Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff , touching [his]57-ben weatherstaff forehead . One of the long concealed charms of [Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff was that in [his]57-ben weatherstaff boyhood [he]57-ben weatherstaff had once run away to [sea]1370-sea and had made voyages . So [he]57-ben weatherstaff could reply like [a sailor]1371-a sailor .

" [I]90-the rajah am going to try a scientific experiment , "[90-the rajah] explained [the Rajah]90-the rajah . " When [I]90-the rajah grow up [I]90-the rajah am going to make great scientific discoveries and [I]90-the rajah am going to begin now with this experiment . "[90-the rajah]

" Aye , aye , [sir]2395-sir ! "[57-ben weatherstaff] said [Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff promptly , though this was the first time [he]57-ben weatherstaff had heard of great scientific discoveries .

It was the first time [Mary]38-mary had heard of them , either , but even at this stage [she]38-mary had begun to realize that , queer as [he]57-ben weatherstaff was , [Colin]81-colin had read about a great many singular things and was somehow [a very convincing sort of boy]1372-a very convincing sort of boy . When [he]57-ben weatherstaff held up [his]57-ben weatherstaff head and fixed [his]57-ben weatherstaff strange eyes on [you]1373-you it seemed as if [you]1373-you believed [him]57-ben weatherstaff almost in spite of [yourself]1373-you though [he]57-ben weatherstaff was only ten years old going on eleven . At this moment [he]57-ben weatherstaff was especially convincing because [he]57-ben weatherstaff suddenly felt the fascination of actually making a sort of speech like [a grown - up person]435-a grown - up person .

" The great scientific discoveries [I]57-ben weatherstaff am going to make , "[57-ben weatherstaff] [he]57-ben weatherstaff went on , " will be about Magic . Magic is a great thing and scarcely [any one]189-any one knows anything about it except [a few people in old books]3038-a few people in old books and [Mary]38-mary a little , because [she]38-mary was born in [India]2-india where there are fakirs . [I]57-ben weatherstaff believe [Dickon]54-dickon knows some Magic , but perhaps [he]54-dickon does n't know [he]54-dickon knows it . [He]54-dickon charms animals and [people]167-people . [I]57-ben weatherstaff would never have let [him]54-dickon come to see [me]57-ben weatherstaff if [he]54-dickon had not been [an animal charmer]2877-an animal charmer which is [a boy charmer]3041-a boy charmer , too , because [a boy]155-a boy is an animal . [I]57-ben weatherstaff am sure there is Magic in everything , only [we]3043-we have not sense enough to get hold of it and make it do things for [us]3043-we like electricity and horses and steam . "[57-ben weatherstaff]

This sounded so imposing that [Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff became quite excited and really could not keep still . " Aye , aye , [sir]2395-sir , "[57-ben weatherstaff] [he]57-ben weatherstaff said and [he]57-ben weatherstaff began to stand up quite straight .

" When [Mary]38-mary found [this garden]2262-this garden it looked quite dead , "[1375-the orator] [the orator]1375-the orator proceeded . " Then something began pushing things up out of the soil and making things out of nothing . One day things were n't [there]2007-there and another they were . [I]1375-the orator had never watched things before and it made [me]1375-the orator feel very curious . [Scientific people]3047-scientific people are always curious and [I]1375-the orator am going to be scientific . [I]1375-the orator keep saying to [myself]1375-the orator , ' What is it ? What is it ? ' It 's something . It ca n't be nothing ! [I]1375-the orator do n't know its name so [I]1375-the orator call it Magic . [I]1375-the orator have never seen the sun rise but [Mary]38-mary and [Dickon]54-dickon have and from what [they]3047-scientific people tell [me]1375-the orator [I]1375-the orator am sure that is Magic too . Something pushes it up and draws it . Sometimes since [I]1375-the orator 've been in [the garden]146-the garden [I]1375-the orator 've looked up through the trees at the sky and [I]1375-the orator have had a strange feeling of being happy as if something were pushing and drawing in [my]1375-the orator chest and making [me]1375-the orator breathe fast . Magic is always pushing and drawing and making things out of nothing . Everything is made out of Magic , leaves and trees , flowers and birds , badgers and foxes and squirrels and [people]167-people . So it must be all around [us]3050-us . In [this garden]2262-this garden in [all the places]3052-all the places . The Magic in [this garden]2262-this garden has made [me]1375-the orator stand up and know [I]1375-the orator am going to live to be [a man]1910-a man . CHAPTER XXIV

" LET [THEM]3102-them LAUGH "[81-colin]

[The secret garden]1969-the secret garden was not [the only one [Dickon]54-dickon worked in]1398-the only one dickon worked in . Round [the cottage on [the moor]1835-the moor]956-the cottage on the moor there was a piece of ground enclosed by a low wall of rough stones . Early in the morning and late in the fading twilight and on all the days [Colin]81-colin and [Mary]38-mary did not see [him]54-dickon , [Dickon]54-dickon worked [there]2007-there planting or tending potatoes and cabbages , turnips and carrots and herbs for [[his]54-dickon mother]2546-his mother . In the company of [[his]54-dickon " creatures]3103-his " creatures "[54-dickon] [he]54-dickon did wonders there and was never tired of doing them , it seemed . While [he]54-dickon dug or weeded [he]54-dickon whistled or sang bits of [Yorkshire]50-martha moor songs or talked to [Soot]61-soot or [Captain]47-captain or [the brothers]1403-the brothers and sisters [he]54-dickon had taught to help [him]54-dickon .

" [We]3104-we 'd never get on as comfortable as [we]3104-we do , "[80-mrs. sowerby] [Mrs. Sowerby]80-mrs. sowerby said , " if it was n't for [[Dickon]54-dickon 's garden]3105-dickon 's garden . Anything'll grow for [him]54-dickon . [His]54-dickon ' taters and cabbages is twice th ' size of [any one else]1034-any one else 's an ' [they]3107-they 've got a flavor with ['em]3108-'em as [nobody]175-nobody 's has . "[80-mrs. sowerby]

When [she]80-mrs. sowerby found a moment to spare [she]80-mrs. sowerby liked to go out and talk to [him]54-dickon . After supper there was still a long clear twilight to work in and that was [her]80-mrs. sowerby quiet time . [She]80-mrs. sowerby could sit upon the low rough wall and look on and hear stories of the day . [She]80-mrs. sowerby loved this time . There were not only vegetables in [this garden]2262-this garden . [Dickon]54-dickon had bought penny packages of flower seeds now and then and sown bright sweet - scented things among gooseberry bushes and even cabbages and [he]54-dickon grew borders of mignonette and pinks and pansies and things whose seeds [he]54-dickon could save year after year or whose [roots would bloom each spring and spread in time into fine clumps]1405-roots would bloom each spring and spread in time into fine clumps . The low wall was one of the prettiest things in [Yorkshire]50-martha because [he]54-dickon had tucked moorland foxglove and ferns and rock - cress and hedgerow flowers into every crevice until only here and there glimpses of the stones were to be seen .

" All [a chap 's]3110-a chap 's got to do to make ['em]3108-'em thrive , [mother]224-mother , "[54-dickon] [he]54-dickon would say , " is to be friends with ['em]3108-'em for sure . [They]3108-'em 're just like [th ' ' creatures]3112-th ' ' creatures . ' If [they]3108-'em 're thirsty give ['em]3108-'em drink and if [they]3108-'em 're hungry give ['em]3108-'em a bit o ' food . [They]3108-'em want to live same as [we]3113-we do . If [they]3108-'em died [I]54-dickon should feel as if [I]54-dickon 'd been [a bad lad]3114-a bad lad and somehow treated [them]3108-'em heartless . "[54-dickon]

It was in these twilight hours that [Mrs. Sowerby]80-mrs. sowerby heard of all that happened at [Misselthwaite Manor]1-misselthwaite manor . At first [she]80-mrs. sowerby was only told that " [Mester Colin]81-colin "[54-dickon] had taken a fancy to going out into [the grounds]1406-the grounds with [Miss Mary]38-mary and that it was doing [him]1407-him good . But it was not long before it was agreed between [the two children]1408-the two children that [[Dickon]54-dickon 's mother]934-dickon 's mother might " come into the secret . "[54-dickon] Somehow it was not doubted that [she]934-dickon 's mother was ' safe for sure . "[934-dickon 's mother]

So one beautiful still evening [Dickon]54-dickon told the whole story , with all the thrilling details of the buried key and the robin and the gray haze which had seemed like deadness and the secret [Mistress Mary]38-mary had planned never to reveal . The coming of [Dickon]54-dickon and how it had been told to [him]54-dickon , the doubt of [Mester Colin]81-colin and the final drama of [his]54-dickon introduction to [the hidden domain]1410-the hidden domain , combined with the incident of [Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff 's angry face peering over the wall and [Mester Colin]81-colin 's sudden indignant strength , made [Mrs. Sowerby]80-mrs. sowerby 's nice - looking face quite change color several times .

" [My]80-mrs. sowerby word ! "[80-mrs. sowerby] [she]80-mrs. sowerby said . " It was a good thing [that little lass]3115-that little lass came to [th ' Manor]3116-th ' manor . It 's been [th]3117-th ' makin ' o ' [her]3115-that little lass an ' th ' savin , [o]3118-o ' [him]81-colin . Standin ' on [his]81-colin feet ! An ' [us]3119-us all thinkin ' [he]81-colin was [a poor half - witted lad with not a straight bone in [him]81-colin]3120-a poor half - witted lad with not a straight bone in him . "[80-mrs. sowerby]

[She]80-mrs. sowerby asked a great many questions and [her]80-mrs. sowerby blue eyes were full of deep thinking .

" What do [they]3121-they make of it at th ' [Manor]19-manor [him]81-colin being so well an ' cheerful an ' never complainin ' ? "[80-mrs. sowerby] [she]80-mrs. sowerby inquired . " [They]3121-they do n't know what to make of it , "[54-dickon] answered [Dickon]54-dickon . " Every day as comes round [his]81-colin face looks different . It 's fillin ' out and does n't look so sharp an ' th ' waxy color is goin' . But [he]81-colin has to do [his]81-colin bit o ' complainin ' , "[54-dickon] with a highly entertained grin .

" What for , [i]80-mrs. sowerby ' [Mercy]107-mercy 's name ? "[80-mrs. sowerby] asked [Mrs. Sowerby]80-mrs. sowerby .

[Dickon]54-dickon chuckled .

" [He]81-colin does it to keep [them]3121-they from guessin ' what 's happened . If [the doctor]2517-the doctor knew [he]81-colin 'd found out [he]81-colin could stand on [his]81-colin feet [he]81-colin 'd likely write and tell [Mester Craven]89-mester craven . [Mester Colin]81-colin 's savin ' th ' secret to tell [himself]81-colin . [He]81-colin 's goin' to practise [his]81-colin Magic on [his]81-colin legs every day till [[his]81-colin father]900-his father comes back an ' then [he]81-colin 's goin' to march into [[his]81-colin room]2556-his room an ' show [him]81-colin [he]81-colin 's as straight as [other lads]3125-other lads . But [him]81-colin an ' [Miss Mary]38-mary thinks it 's best plan to do a bit o ' groanin ' an ' frettin ' now an ' then to throw [folk]1939-folk off th ' scent . "[54-dickon]

[Mrs. Sowerby]80-mrs. sowerby was laughing a low comfortable laugh long before [he]1411-he had finished [his]1411-he last sentence .

" Eh ! "[80-mrs. sowerby] [she]80-mrs. sowerby said , " [that pair]3127-that pair 's enjoyin ' [their]3127-that pair - selves [I]80-mrs. sowerby 'll warrant . " [Mester Colin]81-colin is carried down to [his]81-colin chair every time [he]81-colin goes out , "[54-dickon] [he]54-dickon explained . " An ' [he]81-colin flies out at [John]108-john , [th ' footman]3129-th ' footman , for not carryin ' [him]81-colin careful enough . [Mrs. Sowerby]80-mrs. sowerby laughed so heartily at the revelation of this difficulty that [she]80-mrs. sowerby quite rocked backward and forward in [her]80-mrs. sowerby blue cloak , and [Dickon]54-dickon laughed with [her]80-mrs. sowerby .

" Eh ! [mother]224-mother ! "[54-dickon] said [Dickon]54-dickon admiringly , " what a wonder tha ' art ! Tha ' always sees a way out o ' things . [They]3132-they was quite in a pother yesterday . [She]80-mrs. sowerby was quite right , [the comfortable wonderful mother creature]1412-the comfortable wonderful mother creature and [she]80-mrs. sowerby had never been more so than when [she]80-mrs. sowerby said [their]1413-their " play actin ' "[80-mrs. sowerby] would be [their]1413-their joy . " [Your]81-colin appetite . Is improving very much , [Master Colin]81-colin , "[2532-the nurse] [the nurse]2532-the nurse had said one day . " [You]81-colin used to eat nothing , and so many things disagreed with [you]81-colin . "[2532-the nurse]

" [People who are not going to live]3153-people who are not going to live are often different . "[81-colin] [Dr. Craven]86-dr. craven shook [his]86-dr. craven head . " [I]81-colin wo n't have [him]1829-your father told ! "[81-colin] [Colin]81-colin broke forth fiercely . " Hush - h ! [[my]86-dr. craven boy]2632-my boy , "[86-dr. craven] [Dr. Craven]86-dr. craven soothed [him]1418-he . " Nothing shall be written without [your]1418-he permission . [You]1418-he are too sensitive about things . [You]1418-he must not undo the good which has been done . "[86-dr. craven]

[He]1418-he said no more about writing to [Mr. Craven]41-mr. craven and when [he]1418-he saw [the nurse]2532-the nurse [he]1418-he privately warned [her]2532-the nurse that such a possibility must not be mentioned to [the patient]1420-the patient .

" [The boy]792-the boy is extraordinarily better , "[1418-he] [he]1418-he said . " [His]792-the boy advance seems almost abnormal . "[1418-he] [Mary]38-mary and [Colin]81-colin were much alarmed and talked together anxiously . From this time dated [their]1421-they plan of " play actin ' . "[1418-he]

" [I]81-colin may be obliged to have a tantrum , "[81-colin] said [Colin]81-colin regretfully . " [I]81-colin do n't want to have one and [I]81-colin 'm not miserable enough now to work [myself]81-colin into a big one . Perhaps [I]81-colin could n't have one at all . [He]81-colin made up [his]81-colin mind to eat less , but unfortunately it was not possible to carry out this brilliant idea when [he]81-colin wakened each morning with an amazing appetite and the table near [his]81-colin sofa was set with a breakfast of home - made bread and fresh butter , snow - white eggs , raspberry jam and clotted cream . [Mary]38-mary always breakfasted with [him]81-colin and when [they]1421-they found [themselves]1421-they at the table particularly if there were delicate slices of sizzling ham sending forth tempting odors from under a hot silver cover [they]1421-they would look into [each other]241-each other 's eyes in desperation .

" [I]81-colin think [we]1421-they shall have to eat it all this morning , [Mary]38-mary , "[81-colin] [Colin]81-colin always ended by saying . " [We]1421-they can send away some of the lunch and a great deal of the dinner . "[81-colin]

But [they]1421-they never found [they]1421-they could send away anything and the highly polished condition of the empty plates returned to [the pantry]1423-the pantry awakened much comment .

" [I]81-colin do wish , "[81-colin] [Colin]81-colin would say also , " [I]81-colin do wish the slices of ham were thicker , and one muffin each is not enough for any one . "[81-colin]

" It 's enough for [a person who is going to die]3162-a person who is going to die , "[38-mary] answered [Mary]38-mary when first [she]38-mary heard this , " but it 's not enough for [a person who is going to live]3163-a person who is going to live . [I]38-mary sometimes feel as if [I]38-mary could eat three when those nice fresh heather and gorse smells from [the moor]1835-the moor come pouring in at the open window . "[38-mary]

The morning that [Dickon]54-dickon after [they]1421-they had been enjoying [themselves]1421-they in [the garden]146-the garden for about two hours went behind a big rosebush and brought forth two tin pails and revealed that one was full of rich new milk with cream on the top of it , and that the other held cottage - made currant buns folded in a clean blue and white napkin , buns so carefully tucked in that they were still hot , there was a riot of surprised joyfulness . What a wonderful thing for [Mrs. Sowerby]80-mrs. sowerby to think of ! What [a kind , clever woman]1425-a kind , clever woman [she]80-mrs. sowerby must be ! How good the buns were ! And what delicious fresh milk !

" Magic is in [her]80-mrs. sowerby just as it is in [Dickon]54-dickon , "[81-colin] said [Colin]81-colin . " It makes [her]80-mrs. sowerby think of ways to do things nice things . [She]80-mrs. sowerby is [a Magic person]3165-a magic person . Tell [her]80-mrs. sowerby [we]1421-they are grateful , [Dickon]54-dickon extremely grateful . "[81-colin] [He]81-colin was given to using rather grown - up phrases at times . [He]81-colin enjoyed them . [He]81-colin liked this so much that [he]81-colin improved upon it .

" Tell [her]80-mrs. sowerby [she]80-mrs. sowerby has been most bounteous and [our]1421-they gratitude is extreme . "[81-colin]

And then forgetting [his]81-colin grandeur [he]81-colin fell to and stuffed [himself]81-colin with buns and drank milk out of the pail in copious draughts in the manner of [any hungry little boy who had been taking unusual exercise and breathing in moorland air and whose breakfast]1426-any hungry little boy who had been taking unusual exercise and breathing in moorland air and whose breakfast was more than two hours behind [him]81-colin .

This was the beginning of many agreeable incidents of the same kind . [They]1427-they actually awoke to the fact that as [Mrs. Sowerby]80-mrs. sowerby had [fourteen people]1428-fourteen people to provide food for [she]80-mrs. sowerby might not have enough to satisfy two extra appetites every day . So [they]1427-they asked [her]80-mrs. sowerby to let [them]1427-they send some of [their]1427-they shillings to buy things .

[Dickon]54-dickon made the stimulating discovery that in the wood in [the park]369-the park outside [the garden where [Mary]38-mary had first found [him]54-dickon piping to the wild creatures]1430-the garden where mary had first found him piping to the wild creatures there was [a deep little hollow where [you]1432-you could build a sort of tiny oven with stones and roast potatoes and eggs in [it]1431-a deep little hollow where you could build a sort of tiny oven with stones and roast potatoes and eggs in it]1431-a deep little hollow where you could build a sort of tiny oven with stones and roast potatoes and eggs in it . Roasted eggs were a previously unknown luxury and very hot potatoes with salt and fresh butter in them were fit for [a woodland king]1433-a woodland king besides being deliciously satisfying . [You]1432-you could buy both potatoes and eggs and eat as many as [you]1432-you liked without feeling as if [you]1432-you were taking food out of the mouths of [fourteen people]1428-fourteen people .

Every beautiful morning the Magic was worked by the mystic circle under the plum - tree which provided a canopy of thickening green leaves after its brief blossom - time was ended . After the ceremony [Colin]81-colin always took [his]81-colin walking exercise and throughout the day [he]81-colin exercised [his]81-colin newly found power at intervals . Each day [he]81-colin grew stronger and could walk more steadily and cover more ground . And each day [his]81-colin belief in the Magic grew stronger as well it might . [He]81-colin tried one experiment after another as [he]81-colin felt [himself]81-colin gaining strength and it was [Dickon]54-dickon who showed [him]81-colin the best things of all .

" Yesterday , "[54-dickon] [he]54-dickon said one morning after an absence , " [I]54-dickon went to [Thwaite]13-thwaite for [mother]224-mother an ' near [th ' Blue Cow Inn]3167-th ' blue cow inn [I]54-dickon seed [Bob Haworth]109-bob haworth . [He]109-bob haworth 's [the strongest chap on [th ' moor]1874-th ' moor]3168-the strongest chap on th ' moor . [He]109-bob haworth 's knowed [me]54-dickon ever since [I]54-dickon was a little ' un an ' [he]109-bob haworth 's [a friendly sort]3173-a friendly sort an ' [I]54-dickon axed [him]109-bob haworth some questions . "[54-dickon]

[Colin]81-colin had been listening excitedly .

" Can [you]54-dickon show [me]81-colin ? "[81-colin] [he]81-colin cried . " Will [you]54-dickon ? "[81-colin]

" Aye , to be sure , "[54-dickon] [Dickon]54-dickon answered , getting up .
