Rest in between times an ' take deep breaths an ' do n't overdo . "[54-dickon]

" [I]81-colin 'll be careful , "[81-colin] said [Colin]81-colin . " Show [me]81-colin ! Show [me]81-colin ! [Dickon]54-dickon , [you]54-dickon are [the most Magic boy in [the world]234-the world]3185-the most magic boy in the world ! "[81-colin]

[Dickon]54-dickon stood up on the grass and slowly went through a carefully practical but simple series of muscle exercises . [Colin]81-colin watched [them]1435-they with widening eyes . [He]81-colin could do a few while [he]81-colin was sitting down . Presently [he]81-colin did a few gently while [he]81-colin stood upon [his]81-colin already steadied feet . [Mary]38-mary began to do them also . [Soot]61-soot , who was watching the performance , became much disturbed and left [his]61-soot branch and hopped about restlessly because [he]61-soot could not do them too .

From that time the exercises were part of the day 's duties as much as the Magic was . It became possible for both [Colin]81-colin and [Mary]38-mary to do more of [them]1435-they each time [they]1436-they tried , and such appetites were the results that but for the basket [Dickon]54-dickon put down behind the bush each morning when [he]54-dickon arrived [they]1435-they would have been lost . But the little oven in [the hollow]1437-the hollow and [Mrs. Sowerby]80-mrs. sowerby 's bounties were so satisfying that [Mrs. Medlock]45-mrs. medlock and [the nurse]2532-the nurse and [Dr. Craven]86-dr. craven became mystified again . [You]1439-you can trifle with [your]1439-you breakfast and seem to disdain [your]1439-you dinner if [you]1439-you are full to the brim with roasted eggs and potatoes and richly frothed new milk and oatcakes and buns and heather honey and clotted cream .

" [They]1435-they are eating next to nothing , "[2532-the nurse] said [the nurse]2532-the nurse . " [They]1435-they 'll die of starvation if [they]1435-they ca n't be persuaded to take some nourishment . And yet see how [they]1435-they look . "[2532-the nurse]

" Look ! "[45-mrs. medlock] exclaimed [Mrs. Medlock]45-mrs. medlock indignantly . " Eh ! [I]45-mrs. medlock 'm moithered to death with [them]1435-they . [They]1435-they 're [a pair of [young Satans]3188-young satans]3187-a pair of young satans . Bursting [their]1435-they jackets one day and the next turning up [their]1435-they noses at the best meals [Cook]3189-cook can tempt [them]1435-they with . Not a mouthful of that lovely young fowl and bread sauce did [they]1435-they set a fork into yesterday and [the poor woman fair]3190-the poor woman fair invented a pudding for [them]1435-they and back it 's sent . [She]3190-the poor woman fair almost cried . [She]3190-the poor woman fair 's afraid [she]3190-the poor woman fair 'll be blamed if [they]1435-they starve [themselves]1435-they into [their]1435-they graves . "[45-mrs. medlock]

[Dr. Craven]86-dr. craven came and looked at [Colin]81-colin long and carefully , [He]86-dr. craven wore an extremely worried expression when [the nurse]2532-the nurse talked with [him]86-dr. craven and showed [him]86-dr. craven the almost untouched tray of breakfast [she]2532-the nurse had saved for [him]86-dr. craven to look at but it was even more worried when [he]86-dr. craven sat down by [Colin]81-colin 's sofa and examined [him]86-dr. craven . [He]86-dr. craven had been called to [London]4-london on business and had not seen [the boy]792-the boy for nearly two weeks . When young things begin to gain health [they]1443-they gain it rapidly . The waxen tinge had left , [Colins]110-colins skin and a warm rose showed through it ; [his]110-colins beautiful eyes were clear and the hollows under them and in [his]110-colins cheeks and temples had filled out . [His]110-colins once dark , heavy locks had begun to look as if they sprang healthily from [his]110-colins forehead and were soft and warm with life . [His]110-colins lips were fuller and of a normal color . In fact as an imitation of [a boy who was a confirmed invalid]1444-a boy who was a confirmed invalid [he]110-colins was a disgraceful sight . [Dr. Craven]86-dr. craven held [his]110-colins chin in [his]86-dr. craven hand and thought [him]110-colins over .

" [I]86-dr. craven am sorry to hear that [you]110-colins do not eat anything , "[86-dr. craven] [he]86-dr. craven said . " That will not do . [You]110-colins will lose all [you]110-colins have gained and [you]110-colins have gained amazingly . [You]110-colins ate so well a short time ago . "[86-dr. craven]

" [I]81-colin told [you]110-colins it was an unnatural appetite , "[81-colin] answered [Colin]81-colin .

[Mary]38-mary was sitting on [her]38-mary stool nearby and [she]38-mary suddenly made a very queer sound which [she]38-mary tried so violently to repress that [she]38-mary ended by almost choking .

" What is the matter ? "[86-dr. craven] said [Dr. Craven]86-dr. craven , turning to look at [her]38-mary .

[Mary]38-mary became quite severe in [her]38-mary manner .

" It was something between a sneeze and a cough , "[38-mary] [she]38-mary replied with reproachful dignity , " and it got into [my]38-mary throat . "[38-mary]

" But , "[38-mary] [she]38-mary said afterward to [Colin]81-colin , " [I]38-mary could n't stop [myself]38-mary . It just burst out because all at once [I]38-mary could n't help remembering that last big potato [you]81-colin ate and the way [your]81-colin mouth stretched when [you]81-colin bit through that thick lovely crust with jam and clotted cream on it . "[38-mary]

" Is there any way in which [those children]3191-those children can get food secretly ? "[86-dr. craven] [Dr. Craven]86-dr. craven inquired of [Mrs. Medlock]45-mrs. medlock .

" There 's no way unless [they]3191-those children dig it out of [the earth]490-the earth or pick it off the trees , "[45-mrs. medlock] [Mrs. Medlock]45-mrs. medlock answered . " [They]3191-those children stay out in [the grounds]1406-the grounds all day and see [no one]145-no one but [each other]241-each other . And if [they]3191-those children want anything different to eat from what 's sent up to [them]3191-those children [they]3191-those children need only ask for it . "[45-mrs. medlock]

" Well , "[86-dr. craven] said [Dr. Craven]86-dr. craven , ' so long as going without food agrees with [them]1445-them [we]1446-we need not disturb [ourselves]1446-we . [The boy]792-the boy is [a new creature]1448-a new creature . "[1448-a new creature]

" So is [the girl]409-the girl , "[45-mrs. medlock] said [Mrs. Medlock]45-mrs. medlock . " [She]409-the girl 's begun to be downright pretty since [she]409-the girl 's filled out and lost [her]409-the girl ugly little sour look . [Her]409-the girl hair 's grown thick and healthy looking and [she]409-the girl 's got a bright color . The glummest , ill - natured little thing [she]409-the girl used to be and now [her]409-the girl and [Master Colin]81-colin laugh together like [a pair of crazy young ones]3197-a pair of crazy young ones . Perhaps [they]3197-a pair of crazy young ones 're growing fat on that . "[45-mrs. medlock]

" Perhaps [they]3197-a pair of crazy young ones are , "[86-dr. craven] said [Dr. Craven]86-dr. craven . " Let [them]3197-a pair of crazy young ones laugh . "[86-dr. craven]

CHAPTER XXV

THE CURTAIN

And [the secret garden]1969-the secret garden bloomed and bloomed and every morning revealed new miracles . In the robin 's nest there were [Eggs]111-the eggs and [[the robin]495-the robin 's mate]1451-the robin 's mate sat upon [them]1452-them keeping them warm with [her]1451-the robin 's mate feathery little breast and careful wings . At first [she]1451-the robin 's mate was very nervous and [the robin]495-the robin [himself]495-the robin was indignantly watchful . Even [Dickon]54-dickon did not go near the close - grown corner in those days , but waited until by the quiet working of some mysterious spell [he]54-dickon seemed to have conveyed to the soul of [the little pair]1454-the little pair that in [the garden]146-the garden there was nothing which was not quite like [themselves]1454-the little pair nothing which did not understand the wonderfulness of what was happening to [them]1454-the little pair the immense , tender , terrible , heart - breaking beauty and solemnity of [Eggs]111-the eggs . If there had been [one person in [that garden]2028-that garden who had not known through all [his]1458-his or [her]1459-her innermost being that if an Egg were taken away or hurt [the whole world]905-the whole world]1456-one person in that garden who had not known through all his or her innermost being that if an egg were taken away or hurt the whole world would whirl round and crash through space and come to an end if there had been [even one who did not feel it and act accordingly there could have been no happiness even in that golden springtime air]1461-even one who did not feel it and act accordingly there could have been no happiness even in that golden springtime air . But [they]1454-the little pair all knew it and felt it and [the robin]495-the robin and [[his]495-the robin mate]2733-his mate knew [they]1454-the little pair knew it .

At first [the robin]495-the robin watched [Mary]38-mary and [Colin]81-colin with sharp anxiety . For some mysterious reason [he]495-the robin knew [he]495-the robin need not watch [Dickon]54-dickon . The first moment [he]495-the robin set [his]495-the robin dew - bright black eye on [Dickon]54-dickon [he]495-the robin knew [he]54-dickon was not [a stranger]987-a stranger but [a sort of robin without beak or feathers]1466-a sort of robin without beak or feathers . [He]54-dickon could speak robin which is a quite distinct language not to be mistaken for any other . To speak robin to [a robin]544-a robin is like speaking French to [a Frenchman]1468-a frenchman . [Dickon]54-dickon always spoke it to [the robin]495-the robin [himself]54-dickon , so the queer gibberish [he]54-dickon used when [he]54-dickon spoke to [humans]1470-humans did not matter in the least . [The robin]495-the robin thought [he]495-the robin spoke this gibberish to [them]1470-humans because [they]1470-humans were not intelligent enough to understand feathered speech . [His]54-dickon movements also were robin . [They]1472-they never startled [one]406-one by being sudden enough to seem dangerous or threatening . [Any robin]1474-any robin could understand [Dickon]54-dickon , so [his]54-dickon presence was not even disturbing .

But at the outset it seemed necessary to be on guard against the other two . In the first place [the boy creature]1475-the boy creature did not come into [the garden]146-the garden on [his]1475-the boy creature legs . [He]1475-the boy creature was pushed in on a thing with wheels and the skins of wild animals were thrown over [him]1475-the boy creature . That in itself was doubtful . Then when [he]1475-the boy creature began to stand up and move about [he]1475-the boy creature did it in a queer unaccustomed way and [the others]1477-the others seemed to have to help [him]1475-the boy creature . [The robin]495-the robin used to secrete [himself]495-the robin in a bush and watch this anxiously , [his]495-the robin head tilted first on one side and then on the other . [He]495-the robin thought that the slow movements might mean that [he]495-the robin was preparing to pounce , as cats do . When cats are preparing to pounce they creep over the ground very slowly . [The robin]495-the robin talked this over with [[his]495-the robin mate]2733-his mate a great deal for a few days but after that [he]495-the robin decided not to speak of the subject because [her]2733-his mate terror was so great that [he]495-the robin was afraid it might be injurious to [the Eggs]111-the eggs .

When [the boy]792-the boy began to walk by [himself]792-the boy and even to move more quickly it was an immense relief . But for a long time or it seemed a long time to [the robin]495-the robin [he]1475-the boy creature was a source of some anxiety . [He]1475-the boy creature did not act as [the other humans]1483-the other humans did . [He]1475-the boy creature seemed very fond of walking but [he]1475-the boy creature had a way of sitting or lying down for a while and then getting up in a disconcerting manner to begin again .

One day [the robin]495-the robin remembered that when [he]495-the robin [himself]495-the robin had been made to learn to fly by [[his]495-the robin parents]1485-his parents [he]495-the robin had done much the same sort of thing . [He]495-the robin had taken short flights of a few yards and then had been obliged to rest . So it occurred to [him]495-the robin that [this boy]1185-this boy was learning to fly or rather to walk . [He]495-the robin mentioned this to [[his]495-the robin mate]2733-his mate and when [he]495-the robin told [her]2733-his mate that [the Eggs]111-the eggs would probably conduct [themselves]111-the eggs in the same way after [they]1488-they were fledged [she]2733-his mate was quite comforted and even became eagerly interested and derived great pleasure from watching [the boy]792-the boy over the edge of [[her]2733-his mate nest]1490-her nest though [she]2733-his mate always thought that [the Eggs]111-the eggs would be much cleverer and learn more quickly . But then [she]2733-his mate said indulgently that [humans]1470-humans were always more clumsy and slow than [Eggs]111-the eggs and most of [them]1470-humans never seemed really to learn to fly at all . [You]1492-you never met [them]1470-humans in the air or on [tree - tops]1493-tree - tops .

After a while [the boy]792-the boy began to move about as [the others]1477-the others did , but [all three of [the children]1803-the children]1496-all three of the children at times did unusual things . [They]1496-all three of the children would stand under the trees and move [their]1496-all three of the children arms and legs and heads about in a way which was neither walking nor running nor sitting down . [They]1496-all three of the children went through these movements at intervals every day and [the robin]495-the robin was never able to explain to [[his]495-the robin mate]2733-his mate what [they]1496-all three of the children were doing or tying to do . [He]495-the robin could only say that [he]495-the robin was sure that [the Eggs]111-the eggs would never flap about in such a manner ; but as the boy who could speak robin so fluently was doing the thing with [them]1496-all three of the children , [birds]1500-birds could be quite sure that the actions were not of a dangerous nature . Of course neither [the robin]495-the robin nor [[his]495-the robin mate]2733-his mate had ever heard of [the champion wrestler]3170-the champion wrestler , [Bob Haworth]109-bob haworth , and [his]109-bob haworth exercises for making the muscles stand out like lumps . [Robins]112-robins are not like [human beings]1504-human beings ; [their]112-robins muscles are always exercised from the first and so [they]112-robins develop [themselves]112-robins in a natural manner . If [you]1505-you have to fly about to find every meal [you]1505-you eat , [your]1505-you muscles do not become atrophied atrophied means wasted away through want of use .

When [the boy]792-the boy was walking and running about and digging and weeding like [the others]1477-the others , the nest in the corner was brooded over by a great peace and content . Fears for [the Eggs]111-the eggs became things of the past . Knowing that [your]1505-you Eggs were as safe as if they were locked in [a bank vault]1508-a bank vault and the fact that [you]1505-you could watch so many curious things going on made setting a most entertaining occupation . On wet days [[the Eggs]1509-the eggs ' mother]1510-the eggs ' mother sometimes felt even a little dull because [the children]1803-the children did not come into [the garden]146-the garden .

But even on wet days it could not be said that [Mary]38-mary and [Colin]81-colin were dull . One morning when the rain streamed down unceasingly and [Colin]81-colin was beginning to feel a little restive , as [he]81-colin was obliged to remain on [his]81-colin sofa because it was not safe to get up and walk about , [Mary]38-mary had an inspiration .

" Now that [I]81-colin am [a real boy]3198-a real boy , "[81-colin] [Colin]81-colin had said , " [my]81-colin legs and arms and all [my]81-colin body are so full of Magic that [I]81-colin ca n't keep them still . [They]1803-the children want to be doing things all the time . Do [you]38-mary know that when [I]81-colin waken in the morning , [Mary]38-mary , when it 's quite early and the birds are just shouting outside and everything seems just shouting for joy even the trees and things [we]3199-we ca n't really hear [I]81-colin feel as if [I]81-colin must jump out of bed and shout [myself]81-colin . If [I]81-colin did it , just think what would happen ! "[81-colin]

[Mary]38-mary giggled inordinately .

" [The nurse]2532-the nurse would come running and [Mrs. Medlock]45-mrs. medlock would come running and [they]1513-they would be sure [you]81-colin had gone crazy and [they]1513-they 'd send for [the doctor]2517-the doctor , "[38-mary] [she]38-mary said .

[Colin]81-colin giggled [himself]81-colin . [He]81-colin could see how [they]1513-they would all look how horrified by [his]81-colin outbreak and how amazed to see [him]81-colin standing upright .

" [I]81-colin wish [[my]81-colin father]1923-my father would come [home]1785-home , "[81-colin] [he]81-colin said . " [I]81-colin want to tell [him]1923-my father [myself]81-colin . [I]81-colin 'm always thinking about it but [we]3204-we could n't go on like this much longer . [I]81-colin ca n't stand lying still and pretending , and besides [I]81-colin look too different . [I]81-colin wish it was n't raining today . "[81-colin]

It was then [Mistress Mary]38-mary had [her]38-mary inspiration .

" [Colin]81-colin , "[38-mary] [she]38-mary began mysteriously , " do [you]81-colin know how many rooms there are in [this house]2900-this house ? "[38-mary]

Suppose [we]3213-we go and look at [them]3207-them . Wheel [me]81-colin in [my]81-colin chair and [nobody]175-nobody would know [we]3213-we went . "[81-colin]

" That 's what [I]38-mary was thinking , "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary . " [No one]145-no one would dare to follow [us]3213-we . There are galleries where [you]2532-the nurse could run . " Ring the bell , "[81-colin] said [Colin]81-colin .

When [the nurse]2532-the nurse came in [he]81-colin gave [his]81-colin orders .

" [I]81-colin want [my]81-colin chair , "[81-colin] [he]81-colin said . " [Miss Mary]38-mary and [I]81-colin are going to look at [the part of [the house]166-the house which is not used]3218-the part of the house which is not used . Rainy days lost [their]1515-their terrors that morning . When [the footman]535-the footman had wheeled the chair into [the picture - gallery]3220-the picture - gallery and left [the two]1032-the two together in obedience to orders , [Colin]81-colin and [Mary]38-mary looked at [each other]241-each other delighted . As soon as [Mary]38-mary had made sure that [John]108-john was really on [his]108-john way back to [[his]108-john own quarters]1520-his own quarters below stairs , [Colin]81-colin got out of [his]81-colin chair .

" [I]81-colin am going to run from one end of [the gallery]3222-the gallery to the other , "[81-colin] [he]81-colin said , " and then [I]81-colin am going to jump and then [we]1032-the two will do [Bob Haworth]109-bob haworth 's exercises . "[81-colin]

And [they]1032-the two did all these things and many others . [They]1032-the two looked at the portraits and found [the plain little girl]1521-the plain little girl dressed in green brocade and holding the parrot on [her]1521-the plain little girl finger .

" All these , "[81-colin] said [Colin]81-colin , " must be [[my]81-colin relations]3223-my relations . [They]3223-my relations lived a long time ago . [That parrot one]3224-that parrot one , [I]81-colin believe , is one of [my]81-colin great , [great , great , great aunts]3225-great , great , great aunts . [She]3224-that parrot one looks rather like [you]38-mary , [Mary]38-mary not as [you]38-mary look now but as [you]38-mary looked when [you]38-mary came [here]1771-here . Now [you]38-mary are a great deal fatter and better looking . "[81-colin]

" So are [you]38-mary , "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary , and [they]1522-they both laughed .

[They]1522-they went to [the Indian room]1523-the indian room and amused [themselves]1522-they with the ivory elephants . [They]1522-they found the rose - colored brocade boudoir and the hole in the cushion the mouse had left , but the mice had grown up and run away and the hole was empty . [They]1522-they saw [more rooms]1524-more rooms and made more discoveries than [Mary]38-mary had made on [her]38-mary first pilgrimage . [They]1522-they found [new corridors]1525-new corridors and corners and [flights of steps]1526-flights of steps and new old pictures [they]1522-they liked and weird old things [they]1522-they did not know the use of . It was a curiously entertaining morning and the feeling of wandering about in [the same house]1527-the same house with [other people]273-other people but at the same time feeling as if one were miles away from [them]1522-they was a fascinating thing .

" [I]81-colin 'm glad [we]1522-they came , "[81-colin] [Colin]81-colin said . " [I]81-colin never knew [I]81-colin lived in such [a big queer old place]3227-a big queer old place . [I]81-colin like it . [We]1522-they will ramble about every rainy day . [We]1522-they shall always be finding new queer corners and things . "[81-colin]

That morning [they]1522-they had found among other things such good appetites that when [they]1522-they returned to [[Colin]81-colin 's room]1097-colin 's room it was not possible to send the luncheon away untouched .

When [the nurse]2532-the nurse carried the tray down - [stairs]1531-stairs [she]2532-the nurse slapped it down on the [kitchen dresser]1532-kitchen dresser so that [Mrs. Loomis]113-mrs. loomis , [the cook]1169-the cook , could see the highly polished dishes and plates .

" Look at that ! "[2532-the nurse] [she]2532-the nurse said . " This is [a house of mystery]3228-a house of mystery , and [those two children]3229-those two children are the greatest mysteries in it . "[2532-the nurse]

" If [they]1522-they keep that up every day , "[1534-the strong young footman] said [the strong young footman]1534-the strong young footman [John]108-john , " there 'd be small wonder that [he]81-colin weighs twice as much to - day as [he]81-colin did a month ago . [I]108-john should have to give up [my]108-john place in time , for fear of doing [my]108-john muscles an injury . "[108-john]

That afternoon [Mary]38-mary noticed that something new had happened in [[Colin]81-colin 's room]1097-colin 's room . [She]38-mary had noticed it the day before but had said nothing because [she]38-mary thought the change might have been made by chance . [She]38-mary said nothing today but [she]38-mary sat and looked fixedly at the picture over the mantel . [She]38-mary could look at it because the curtain had been drawn aside . That was the change [she]38-mary noticed .

" [I]81-colin know what [you]38-mary want [me]81-colin to tell [you]38-mary , "[81-colin] said [Colin]81-colin , after [she]38-mary had stared a few minutes . " [I]81-colin always know when [you]38-mary want [me]81-colin to tell [you]38-mary something . [You]38-mary are wondering why the curtain is drawn back . [I]81-colin am going to keep it like that . "[81-colin]

" Why ? "[38-mary] asked [Mary]38-mary .

" Because it does n't make [me]81-colin angry any more to see [her]38-mary laughing . [I]81-colin wakened when it was bright moonlight two nights ago and felt as if the Magic was filling [the room]201-the room and making everything so splendid that [I]81-colin could n't lie still . [I]81-colin got up and looked out of the window . [The room]201-the room was quite light and there was a patch of moonlight on the curtain and somehow that made [me]81-colin go and pull the cord . [She]38-mary looked right down at [me]81-colin as if [she]38-mary were laughing because [she]38-mary was glad [I]81-colin was standing there . It made [me]81-colin like to look at [her]38-mary . [I]81-colin want to see [her]38-mary laughing like that all the time . [I]81-colin think [she]38-mary must have been a sort of [Magic person perhaps]3232-magic person perhaps . "[81-colin]

" [You]81-colin are so like [her]38-mary now , "[38-mary] said [Mary]38-mary , " that sometimes [I]38-mary think perhaps [you]81-colin are [her]38-mary ghost made into [a boy]155-a boy . "[38-mary]

That idea seemed to impress [Colin]81-colin . [He]81-colin thought it over and then answered [her]38-mary slowly .

" If [I]81-colin were [her]38-mary ghost [[my]81-colin father]1923-my father would be fond of [me]81-colin . "[81-colin]

" Do [you]81-colin want [him]1923-my father to be fond of [you]81-colin ? "[38-mary] inquired [Mary]38-mary .

" [I]81-colin used to hate it because [he]1923-my father was not fond of [me]81-colin . If [he]1923-my father grew fond of [me]81-colin [I]81-colin think [I]81-colin should tell [him]1923-my father about the Magic . It might make [him]1923-my father more cheerful . "[81-colin]

CHAPTER XXVI

" IT 'S [MOTHER]53-mother ! "[1536-their]

[Their]1536-their belief in the Magic was an abiding thing . After the morning 's incantations [Colin]81-colin sometimes gave [them]1536-their Magic lectures .

" [I]81-colin like to do it , "[81-colin] [he]81-colin explained , " because when [I]81-colin grow up and make great scientific discoveries [I]81-colin shall be obliged to lecture about them and so this is practise . [I]81-colin can only give short lectures now because [I]81-colin am very young , and besides [Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff would feel as if [he]57-ben weatherstaff were in [church]3082-church and [he]57-ben weatherstaff would go to sleep . "[81-colin]

" Th ' best thing about lecturin ' , "[57-ben weatherstaff] said [Ben]57-ben weatherstaff , " is that [a chap]2298-a chap can get up an ' say aught [he]2298-a chap pleases an ' [no other chap]3237-no other chap can answer [him]2298-a chap back . [I]57-ben weatherstaff would n't be agen ' lecturin ' a bit [mysel]3238-mysel ' sometimes . "[57-ben weatherstaff]

But when [Colin]81-colin held forth under [his]81-colin tree [old Ben]57-ben weatherstaff fixed devouring eyes on [him]81-colin and kept them there . [He]57-ben weatherstaff looked [him]81-colin over with critical affection . It was not so much the lecture which interested [him]57-ben weatherstaff as the legs which looked straighter and stronger each day , the boyish head which held itself up so well , the once sharp chin and hollow cheeks which had filled and rounded out and the eyes which had begun to hold the light [he]57-ben weatherstaff remembered in another pair . Sometimes when [Colin]81-colin felt [Ben]57-ben weatherstaff 's earnest gaze meant that [he]81-colin was much impressed [he]81-colin wondered what [he]57-ben weatherstaff was reflecting on and once when [he]57-ben weatherstaff had seemed quite entranced [he]81-colin questioned [him]57-ben weatherstaff .

" What are [you]57-ben weatherstaff thinking about , [Ben Weatherstaff]57-ben weatherstaff ? "[81-colin] [he]81-colin asked .

" [I]57-ben weatherstaff was thinkin ' "[57-ben weatherstaff] answered [Ben]57-ben weatherstaff , " as [I]57-ben weatherstaff 'd warrant tha 's , gone up three or four pound this week . "[57-ben weatherstaff]

That morning [Dickon]54-dickon was too late to hear the lecture . When [he]54-dickon came [he]54-dickon was ruddy with running and [his]54-dickon funny face looked more twinkling than usual . As [they]1537-they had a good deal of weeding to do after the rains [they]1537-they fell to work . [They]1537-they always had plenty to do after a warm deep sinking rain . [Colin]81-colin was as good at weeding as [any one in these days]1538-any one in these days and [he]81-colin could lecture while [he]81-colin was doing it . One of the things [they]1565-they talked of was the visit [they]1565-they were to make to [[her]1566-her cottage]2842-her cottage . [They]1565-they planned it all . [They]1565-they were to drive over [the moor]1835-the moor and lunch out of doors among the heather . [They]1565-they would see [all the twelve children]1569-all the twelve children and [[Dickon]54-dickon 's garden]3105-dickon 's garden and would not come back until [they]1565-they were tired .

[Susan Sowerby]54-dickon got up at last to return to [the house]166-the house and [Mrs. Medlock]45-mrs. medlock . It was time for [Colin]81-colin to be wheeled back also . But before [he]81-colin got into [his]81-colin chair [he]81-colin stood quite close to [Susan]54-dickon and fixed [his]81-colin eyes on [her]1566-her with a kind of bewildered adoration and [he]81-colin suddenly caught hold of the fold of [her]1566-her blue cloak and held it fast .

" [You]54-dickon are just what [I]81-colin what [I]81-colin wanted , "[81-colin] [he]81-colin said . " [I]81-colin wish [you]54-dickon were [[my]81-colin mother]1897-my mother as well as [Dickon]54-dickon 's ! "[81-colin]

All at once [Susan Sowerby]54-dickon bent down and drew [him]81-colin with [her]1566-her warm arms close against the bosom under the blue cloak as if [he]81-colin had been [[Dickon]54-dickon 's brother]1572-dickon 's brother . The quick mist swept over [her]1566-her eyes .

" Eh ! [dear lad]3254-dear lad ! "[1566-her] [she]1566-her said . " [[Thy]3254-dear lad own mother]3302-thy own mother 's in [this ' ere very garden]3303-this ' ere very garden , [I]1566-her do believe . [She]1566-her couldna ' keep out of it . [[Thy]3254-dear lad father]3304-thy father mun come back to [thee]3254-dear lad [he]3304-thy father mun ! "[1566-her]

CHAPTER XXVII

IN THE GARDEN

In each century since the beginning of [the world]234-the world wonderful things have been discovered . In the last century more amazing things were found out than in any century before . In this new century hundreds of things still more astounding will be brought to light . At first [people]167-people refuse to believe that a strange new thing can be done , then [they]167-people begin to hope it can be done , then [they]167-people see it can be done then it is done and all [the world]234-the world wonders why it was not done centuries ago . One of the new things [people]167-people began to find out in the last century was that thoughts just mere thoughts are as powerful as electric batteries as good for one as sunlight is , or as bad for one as poison . To let a sad thought or a bad one get into [your]1577-you mind is as dangerous as letting a scarlet fever germ get into [your]1577-you body . If [you]1577-you let it stay there after it has got in [you]1577-you may never get over it as long as [you]1577-you live .

So long as [Mistress Mary]38-mary 's mind was full of disagreeable thoughts about [her]38-mary dislikes and sour opinions of [people]167-people and [her]38-mary determination not to be pleased by or interested in anything , [she]38-mary was [a yellow - faced , sickly , bored and wretched child]1579-a yellow - faced , sickly , bored and wretched child . Circumstances , however , were very kind to [her]38-mary , though [she]38-mary was not at all aware of it . [They]1580-they began to push [her]38-mary about for [her]38-mary own good . When [her]38-mary mind gradually filled itself with robins , and [moorland cottages]1581-moorland cottages crowded with [children]1816-children , with [queer crabbed old gardeners]1583-queer crabbed old gardeners and [common little Yorkshire housemaids]1584-common little yorkshire housemaids , with springtime and with [secret gardens]766-secret gardens coming alive day by day , and also with [a moor boy]1586-a moor boy and [his]1586-a moor boy " creatures , "[1586-a moor boy] there was no room left for the disagreeable thoughts which affected [her]38-mary liver and [her]38-mary digestion and made [her]38-mary yellow and tired .

So long as [Colin]81-colin shut [himself]81-colin up in [[his]81-colin room]2556-his room and thought only of [his]81-colin fears and weakness and [his]81-colin detestation of [[people]167-people who looked at [him]81-colin and reflected hourly on humps and early death]1589-people who looked at him and reflected hourly on humps and early death , [he]81-colin was [a hysterical half - crazy little hypochondriac who knew nothing of the sunshine and the spring and also did not know that [he]81-colin could get well and could stand upon [his]81-colin feet if [he]81-colin tried to do it]1590-a hysterical half - crazy little hypochondriac who knew nothing of the sunshine and the spring and also did not know that he could get well and could stand upon his feet if he tried to do it . When new beautiful thoughts began to push out the old hideous ones , life began to come back to [him]81-colin , [his]81-colin blood ran healthily through [his]81-colin veins and strength poured into [him]81-colin like a flood . [His]81-colin scientific experiment was quite practical and simple and there was nothing weird about it at all . Much more surprising things can happen to [any one who , when a disagreeable or discouraged thought comes into [his]81-colin mind]1591-any one who , when a disagreeable or discouraged thought comes into his mind , just has the sense to remember in time and push it out by putting in [an agreeable determinedly courageous one]1592-an agreeable determinedly courageous one . Two things can not be in one place .

" Where , [you]3305-you tend a rose , [[my]1910-a man lad]2986-my lad , A thistle can not grow . "[1910-a man] While [the secret garden]1969-the secret garden was coming alive and [two children]2724-two children were coming alive with it , there was [a man]1910-a man wandering about [certain far - away beautiful places in [the Norwegian fiords]24-the norwegian fiords]1596-certain far - away beautiful places in the norwegian fiords and [the valleys and mountains of [Switzerland]25-switzerland]1597-the valleys and mountains of switzerland and [he]1910-a man was [a man who for ten years had kept [his]1910-a man mind filled with dark and heart - broken thinking]1598-a man who for ten years had kept his mind filled with dark and heart - broken thinking . [He]1910-a man had not been courageous ; [he]1910-a man had never tried to put any other thoughts in the place of [the dark ones]1599-the dark ones . [He]1910-a man had wandered by [blue lakes]1600-blue lakes and thought them ; [he]1910-a man had lain on mountain - sides with sheets of deep blue gentians blooming all about [him]1910-a man and flower breaths filling all the air and [he]1910-a man had thought them . A terrible sorrow had fallen upon [him]1910-a man when [he]1910-a man had been happy and [he]1910-a man had let [his]1910-a man soul fill itself with blackness and had refused obstinately to allow any rift of light to pierce through . [He]1910-a man had forgotten and deserted [[his]1910-a man home]1601-his home and [his]1910-a man duties . When [he]1910-a man traveled about , darkness so brooded over [him]1910-a man that the sight of [him]1910-a man was a wrong done to [other people]273-other people because it was as if [he]1910-a man poisoned the air about [him]1910-a man with gloom . [Most strangers]1603-most strangers thought [he]1910-a man must be either half mad or [a man with some hidden crime on [his]1910-a man soul]1604-a man with some hidden crime on his soul . [He]1910-a man , was [a tall man with a drawn face and crooked shoulders]1605-a tall man with a drawn face and crooked shoulders and the name [he]1910-a man always entered on [hotel registers]1606-hotel registers was , " [Archibald Craven]41-mr. craven , [Misselthwaite Manor]1-misselthwaite manor , [Yorkshire]50-martha , [England]3-england . "[1910-a man]

[He]1910-a man had traveled far and wide since the day [he]1910-a man saw [Mistress Mary]38-mary in [[his]1910-a man study]2394-his study and told [her]38-mary [she]38-mary might have [her]38-mary " bit of earth . "[1910-a man] [He]1910-a man had been in [the most beautiful places in [Europe]27-europe]1608-the most beautiful places in europe , though [he]1910-a man had remained nowhere more than a few days . [He]1910-a man had chosen [the quietest and remotest spots]1609-the quietest and remotest spots . [He]1910-a man had been on the tops of mountains whose heads were in the clouds and had looked down on [other mountains]1610-other mountains when the sun rose and touched them with such light as made it seem as if [the world]234-the world were just being born .

But the light had never seemed to touch [himself]1910-a man until one day when [he]1910-a man realized that for the first time in ten years a strange thing had happened . [He]1910-a man was in [a wonderful valley in [the Austrian Tyrol]28-the austrian tyrol]1612-a wonderful valley in the austrian tyrol and [he]1910-a man had been walking alone through such beauty as might have lifted , [any man]1613-any man 's soul out of shadow . [He]1910-a man had walked a long way and it had not lifted [his]1910-a man . But at last [he]1910-a man had felt tired and had thrown [himself]1910-a man down to rest on a carpet of moss by [a stream]1614-a stream . It was [a clear little stream which ran quite merrily along on [its]1615-a clear little stream which ran quite merrily along on its narrow way through the luscious damp greenness narrow way through the luscious damp greenness]1615-a clear little stream which ran quite merrily along on its narrow way through the luscious damp greenness . Sometimes it made a sound rather like very low laughter as it bubbled over and round stones . [He]1910-a man saw birds come and dip [their]1616-their heads to drink in it and then flick [their]1616-their wings and fly away . It seemed like a thing alive and yet its tiny voice made the stillness seem deeper . [The valley]1617-the valley was very , very still .

As [he]1910-a man sat gazing into the clear running of [the water]1618-the water , [Archibald Craven]41-mr. craven gradually felt [his]1910-a man mind and body both grow quiet , as quiet as [the valley]1617-the valley itself . [He]1910-a man wondered if [he]1910-a man were going to sleep , but [he]1910-a man was not . [He]1910-a man sat and gazed at [the sunlit water]1620-the sunlit water and [his]1910-a man eyes began to see things growing at its edge . There was one lovely mass of blue forget - me - nots growing so close to [the stream]1621-the stream that its leaves were wet and at these [he]1910-a man found [himself]1910-a man looking as [he]1910-a man remembered [he]1910-a man had looked at such things years ago . [He]1910-a man was actually thinking tenderly how lovely it was and what wonders of blue its hundreds of little blossoms were . [He]1910-a man did not know that just that simple thought was slowly filling [his]1910-a man mind filling and filling it until other things were softly pushed aside . It was as if a sweet clear spring had begun to rise in a stagnant pool and had risen and risen until at last it swept the dark water away . But of course [he]1910-a man did not think of this [himself]1910-a man . [He]1910-a man only knew that [the valley]1617-the valley seemed to grow quieter and quieter as [he]1910-a man sat and stared at the bright delicate blueness . [He]1910-a man did not know how long [he]1910-a man sat there or what was happening to [him]1910-a man , but at last [he]1910-a man moved as if [he]1910-a man were awakening and [he]1910-a man got up slowly and stood on the moss carpet , drawing a long , deep , soft breath and wondering at [himself]1910-a man . Something seemed to have been unbound and released in [him]1910-a man , very quietly .

" What is it ? "[1910-a man] [he]1910-a man said , almost in a whisper , and [he]1910-a man passed [his]1910-a man hand over [his]1910-a man forehead . " [I]1910-a man almost feel as if [I]1910-a man were alive ! "[1910-a man]

[I]0-i do not know enough about the wonderfulness of undiscovered things to be able to explain how this had happened to [him]1910-a man . Neither does [any one else]1034-any one else yet . [He]1910-a man did not understand at all [himself]1910-a man but [he]1910-a man remembered this strange hour months afterward when [he]1910-a man was at [Misselthwaite]5-misselthwaite again and [he]1910-a man found out quite by accident that on this very day [Colin]81-colin had cried out as [he]81-colin went into [the secret garden]1969-the secret garden :

" [I]81-colin am going to live forever and ever and ever ! "[81-colin]

The singular calmness remained with [him]1910-a man the rest of the evening and [he]1910-a man slept a new reposeful sleep ; but it was not with [him]1910-a man very long . [He]1910-a man did not know that it could be kept . By the next night [he]1910-a man had opened the doors wide to [his]1910-a man dark thoughts and [they]1625-they had come trooping and rushing back . [He]1910-a man left [the valley]1617-the valley and went on [his]1910-a man wandering way again . But , strange as it seemed to [him]1910-a man , there were minutes sometimes half - hours when , without [his]1910-a man knowing why , the black burden seemed to lift itself again and [he]1910-a man knew [he]1910-a man was [a living man]1627-a living man and not [a dead one]1628-a dead one . Slowly slowly for no reason that [he]1910-a man knew of [he]1910-a man was " coming alive "[1910-a man] with [the garden]146-the garden .

As the golden summer changed into the deep golden autumn [he]1910-a man went to [the Lake of [Como]29-como]1630-the lake of como . There [he]1910-a man found the loveliness of a dream . [He]1910-a man spent [his]1910-a man days upon [the crystal blueness of [the lake]1632-the lake]1631-the crystal blueness of the lake or [he]1910-a man walked back into the soft thick verdure of [the hills]1760-the hills and tramped until [he]1910-a man was tired so that [he]1910-a man might sleep . But by this time [he]1910-a man had begun to sleep better , [he]1910-a man knew , and [his]1910-a man dreams had ceased to be a terror to [him]1910-a man .

" Perhaps , "[1910-a man] [he]1910-a man thought , " [my]1910-a man body is growing stronger . "[1910-a man]

It was growing stronger but because of the rare peaceful hours when [his]1910-a man thoughts were changed [his]1910-a man soul was slowly growing stronger , too . [He]1910-a man began to think of [Misselthwaite]5-misselthwaite and wonder if [he]1910-a man should not go [home]1785-home . Now and then [he]1910-a man wondered vaguely about [[his]1910-a man boy]1635-his boy and asked [himself]1910-a man what [he]1910-a man should feel when [he]1910-a man went and stood by the carved four - posted bed again and looked down at the sharply chiseled ivory - white face while it slept and , the black lashes rimmed so startlingly the close - shut eyes . [He]1910-a man shrank from it .

One marvel of a day [he]1910-a man had walked so far that when [he]1910-a man returned the moon was high and full and all [the world]234-the world was purple shadow and silver . The stillness of [lake]1637-lake and [shore and wood]1638-shore and wood was so wonderful that [he]1910-a man did not go into [[the villa]1639-the villa [he]1910-a man lived in]1640-the villa he lived in . [He]1910-a man walked down to [a little bowered terrace at [the water 's edge]1642-the water 's edge]1641-a little bowered terrace at the water 's edge and sat upon a seat and breathed in all the heavenly scents of the night . [He]1910-a man felt the strange calmness stealing over [him]1910-a man and it grew deeper and deeper until [he]1910-a man fell asleep .

[He]1910-a man did not know when [he]1910-a man fell asleep and when [he]1910-a man began to dream ; [his]1910-a man dream was so real that [he]1910-a man did not feel as if [he]1910-a man were dreaming . [He]1910-a man remembered afterward how intensely wide awake and alert [he]1910-a man had thought [he]1910-a man was . [He]1910-a man thought that as [he]1910-a man sat and breathed in the scent of the late roses and listened to the lapping of the water at [his]1910-a man feet [he]1910-a man heard a voice calling . It was sweet and clear and happy and far away . It seemed very far , but [he]1910-a man heard it as distinctly as if it had been at [his]1910-a man very side .

" [Archie]41-mr. craven ! [Archie]41-mr. craven ! [Archie]41-mr. craven ! "[1910-a man] it said , and then again , sweeter and clearer than before , " [Archie]41-mr. craven ! [Archie]41-mr. craven ! "[1910-a man]

[He]1910-a man thought [he]1910-a man sprang to [his]1910-a man feet not even startled . It was such a real voice and it seemed so natural that [he]1910-a man should hear it .

" [Lilias]119-lilias ! [Lilias]119-lilias ! "[1910-a man] [he]1910-a man answered . " [Lilias]119-lilias ! where are [you]119-lilias ? "[1910-a man]

" In [the garden]146-the garden , "[1910-a man] it came back like a sound from a golden flute . " In [the garden]146-the garden ! "[1910-a man]

And then the dream ended . But [he]1910-a man did not awaken . [He]1910-a man slept soundly and sweetly all through the lovely night . When [he]1910-a man did awake at last it was brilliant morning and [a servant]2629-a servant was standing staring at [him]1910-a man . [He]1910-a man was [an Italian servant]1644-an italian servant and was accustomed , as [all the servants of [the villa]1639-the villa]1645-all the servants of the villa were , to accepting without question any strange thing [[his]1910-a man foreign master]1647-his foreign master might do . [No one]145-no one ever knew when [he]1910-a man would go out or come in or where [he]1910-a man would choose to sleep or if [he]1910-a man would roam about [the garden]146-the garden or lie in the boat on [the lake]1632-the lake all night . [The man]217-the man held a salver with some letters on it and [he]217-the man waited quietly until [Mr. Craven]41-mr. craven took them . When [he]217-the man had gone away [Mr. Craven]41-mr. craven sat a few moments holding them in [his]41-mr. craven hand and looking at [the lake]1632-the lake . [His]41-mr. craven strange calm was still upon [him]41-mr. craven and something more a lightness as if the cruel thing which had been done had not happened as [he]41-mr. craven thought as if something had changed . [He]41-mr. craven was remembering the dream the real real dream .

" In [the garden]146-the garden ! "[41-mr. craven] [he]41-mr. craven said , wondering at [himself]41-mr. craven . " In [the garden]146-the garden ! But the door is locked and the key is buried deep . "[41-mr. craven]

When [he]41-mr. craven glanced at the letters a few minutes later [he]41-mr. craven saw that the one lying at the top of the rest was an English letter and came from [Yorkshire]50-martha . It was directed in [a plain woman]1653-a plain woman 's hand but it was not a hand [he]41-mr. craven knew . [He]41-mr. craven opened it , scarcely thinking of [the writer]1654-the writer , but the first words attracted [his]41-mr. craven attention at once .

" [Dear Sir]3311-dear sir :[0-i]

[I]0-i am [Susan Sowerby]54-dickon that made bold to speak to [you]41-mr. craven once on [the moor]1835-the moor . It was about [Miss Mary]38-mary [I]0-i spoke . [I]0-i will make bold to speak again . Please , [sir]2395-sir , [I]0-i would come [home]1785-home if [I]0-i was [you]41-mr. craven . [I]0-i think [you]41-mr. craven would be glad to come and if [you]41-mr. craven will excuse [me]0-i , [sir]2395-sir [I]0-i think [[your]41-mr. craven lady]1659-your lady would ask [you]41-mr. craven to come if [she]1659-your lady was [here]1771-here .

[[Your]41-mr. craven obedient servant]1661-your obedient servant , [Susan Sowerby]54-dickon . "[54-dickon]

[Mr. Craven]41-mr. craven read the letter twice before [he]41-mr. craven put it back in its envelope . [He]41-mr. craven kept thinking about the dream .

" [I]41-mr. craven will go back to [Misselthwaite]5-misselthwaite , "[41-mr. craven] [he]41-mr. craven said . " Yes , [I]41-mr. craven 'll go at once . "[41-mr. craven]

And [he]41-mr. craven went through [the garden]146-the garden to [the villa]1639-the villa and ordered [Pitcher]49-pitcher to prepare for [his]49-pitcher return to [England]3-england .

In a few days [he]41-mr. craven was in [Yorkshire]50-martha again , and on [his]41-mr. craven long railroad journey [he]41-mr. craven found [himself]41-mr. craven thinking of [[his]41-mr. craven boy]1635-his boy as [he]41-mr. craven had never thought in all the ten years past . During those years [he]41-mr. craven had only wished to forget [him]1635-his boy . Now , though [he]41-mr. craven did not intend to think about [him]1635-his boy , memories of [him]1635-his boy constantly drifted into [his]41-mr. craven mind . [He]41-mr. craven remembered the black days when [he]41-mr. craven had raved like [a madman]1665-a madman because [the child]129-the child was alive and [the mother]560-the mother was dead . [He]41-mr. craven had refused to see [it]129-the child , and when [he]41-mr. craven had gone to look at it at last it had been , such a weak wretched thing that [everyone]174-everyone had been sure it would die in a few days . But to the surprise of [those who took care of it]1669-those who took care of it the days passed and [it]129-the child lived and then [everyone]174-everyone believed it would be [a deformed and crippled creature]1671-a deformed and crippled creature .

[He]41-mr. craven had not meant to be [a bad father]1672-a bad father , but [he]41-mr. craven had not felt like [a father]1673-a father at all . [He]41-mr. craven had supplied [doctors]1674-doctors and [nurses]1901-nurses and luxuries , but [he]41-mr. craven had shrunk from the mere thought of [the boy]792-the boy and had buried [himself]41-mr. craven in [his]41-mr. craven own misery . The first time after a year 's absence [he]41-mr. craven returned to [Misselthwaite]5-misselthwaite and the small miserable looking thing languidly and indifferently lifted to [his]41-mr. craven face the great gray eyes with black lashes round them , so like and yet so horribly unlike the happy eyes [he]41-mr. craven had adored , [he]41-mr. craven could not bear the sight of them and turned away pale as death . After that [he]41-mr. craven scarcely ever saw [him]792-the boy except when [he]792-the boy was asleep , and all [he]41-mr. craven knew of [him]792-the boy was that [he]792-the boy was [a confirmed invalid , with a vicious , hysterical , half - insane temper]1677-a confirmed invalid , with a vicious , hysterical , half - insane temper . [He]792-the boy could only be kept from furies dangerous to [himself]792-the boy by being given [his]792-the boy own way in every detail .

All this was not an uplifting thing to recall , but as [the train]321-the train whirled [him]41-mr. craven through [mountain passes]1679-mountain passes and [golden plains]1680-golden plains [the man who was " coming alive "]3312-the man who was " coming alive "[3312-the man who was " coming alive "] began to think in a new way and [he]41-mr. craven thought long and steadily and deeply .

" Perhaps [I]41-mr. craven have been all wrong for ten years , "[41-mr. craven] [he]41-mr. craven said to [himself]41-mr. craven . " Ten years is a long time . It may be too late to do anything quite too late . What have [I]41-mr. craven been thinking of ! "[41-mr. craven]

Of course this was the wrong Magic to begin by saying " too late . "[81-colin] Even [Colin]81-colin could have told [him]41-mr. craven that . But [he]41-mr. craven knew nothing of Magic either black or white . This [he]41-mr. craven had yet to learn . [He]41-mr. craven wondered if [Susan Sowerby]54-dickon had taken courage and written to [him]41-mr. craven only because [the motherly creature]1681-the motherly creature had realized that [the boy]792-the boy was much worse was fatally ill . If [he]41-mr. craven had not been under the spell of the curious calmness which had taken possession of [him]41-mr. craven [he]41-mr. craven would have been more wretched than ever . But the calm had brought a sort of courage and hope with it . Instead of giving way to thoughts of the worst [he]41-mr. craven actually found [he]41-mr. craven was trying to believe in better things .

" Could it be possible that [she]1681-the motherly creature sees that [I]41-mr. craven may be able to do [him]792-the boy good and control [him]792-the boy ? "[41-mr. craven] [he]41-mr. craven thought . " [I]41-mr. craven will go and see [her]1681-the motherly creature on [my]41-mr. craven way to [Misselthwaite]5-misselthwaite . "[41-mr. craven]

But when on [his]41-mr. craven way across [the moor]1835-the moor [he]41-mr. craven stopped [the carriage]319-the carriage at [the cottage]646-the cottage , [seven or eight children who were playing about]1686-seven or eight children who were playing about gathered in [a group and bobbing seven or eight friendly and polite curtsies]1687-a group and bobbing seven or eight friendly and polite curtsies told [him]41-mr. craven that [[their]1686-seven or eight children who were playing about mother]1688-their mother had gone to [the other side of [the moor]1835-the moor]1689-the other side of the moor early in the morning to help [a woman who had [a new baby]1692-a new baby]1691-a woman who had a new baby . " [[Our]1686-seven or eight children who were playing about [Dickon]54-dickon]1929-our dickon , "[1686-seven or eight children who were playing about] [they]1686-seven or eight children who were playing about volunteered , was over at [the Manor]1863-the manor working in [one of [the gardens]439-the gardens]1694-one of the gardens where [he]41-mr. craven went several days each week .

[He]41-mr. craven crossed [the lawn]1710-the lawn and turned into [the Long Walk by the ivied walls]1274-the long walk by the ivied walls . [He]41-mr. craven did not walk quickly , but slowly , and [his]41-mr. craven eyes were on [the path]459-the path . [He]41-mr. craven felt as if [he]41-mr. craven were being drawn back to [the place [he]41-mr. craven had so long forsaken]1713-the place he had so long forsaken , and [he]41-mr. craven did not know why . As [he]41-mr. craven drew near to [it]1713-the place he had so long forsaken [his]41-mr. craven step became still more slow . [He]41-mr. craven knew where the door was even though the ivy hung thick over it but [he]41-mr. craven did not know exactly where it lay that buried key .

So [he]41-mr. craven stopped and stood still , looking about [him]41-mr. craven , and almost the moment after [he]41-mr. craven had paused [he]41-mr. craven started and listened asking [himself]41-mr. craven if [he]41-mr. craven were walking in a dream .

The ivy hung thick over the door , the key was buried under the shrubs , [no human being]1714-no human being had passed that portal for ten lonely years and yet inside [the garden]146-the garden there were sounds . They were the sounds of running scuffling feet seeming to chase round and round under the trees , they were strange sounds of lowered suppressed voices exclamations and smothered joyous cries . It seemed actually like the laughter of [young things]1716-young things , the uncontrollable laughter of [children who were trying not to be heard but who in a moment or so as]1717-children who were trying not to be heard but who in a moment or so as [their]1717-children who were trying not to be heard but who in a moment or so as excitement mounted would burst forth . Was [he]41-mr. craven losing [his]41-mr. craven reason and thinking [he]41-mr. craven heard things which were not for human ears ? Was it that the far clear voice had meant ?

And then the moment came , the uncontrollable moment when the sounds forgot to hush themselves . The feet ran faster and faster [they]1718-they were nearing [the garden]146-the garden door there was quick strong young breathing and a wild outbreak of laughing shows which could not be contained and the door in the wall was flung wide open , the sheet of ivy swinging back , and [a boy]155-a boy burst through it at full speed and , without seeing [the outsider]1721-the outsider , dashed almost into [his]41-mr. craven arms .
